History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___ year old woman with a history of chronic 
anxiety and dysthymia who is brought to the emergency department 
by EMS due to worsening symptoms of depression, irritability, 
and expressed suicidal ideation. On initial and subsequent 
interviews, patient is unable to describe fully her current 
symptoms, nor precipitants for current symptoms. Although she 
endorses fatigue and diminished motivation, she is unable to 
cite specific stressors or precipitants for decline in mood or 
functioning. Stated, "I feel frustrated and exhausted." 
Explained that she currently lives with her sister and 
step-grandmother in her step-grandmother's home; described 
living arrangements as "cramped" (e.g. "I don't have space to do 
what I want to do"), adding that she has "anxiety about wanting 
to get organized." Has been self-employed as a ___ for 
the past ___ years, working four days per week; describes work as 
"tiring" but "it's the only thing [she knows] how to do for 
work." Also cited intermittent conflict with boyfriend as 
contributing to low mood. Explained, "It feels like I'm losing 
control in these situations. One little thing, and it's like the 
last straw. In those moments I don't know what to do." However, 
patient describes her relationship with her boyfriend as 
supportive; two have been dating for ___ year (met eachother ___ 
years ago). [Should be noted that patient's boyfriend called EMS 
and reported to Dr. ___ patient had not been eating or 
sleeping, and endorsed suicidal ideation]. Regarding thoughts of 
suicide, patient was not able to elaborate further beyond "vague 
thoughts of death." However, affirmed that she feels safe on 
this unit, and would be capable of approaching staff if 
thoughts/urges of self-harm intensified.
 
Past Medical History:
Past psychiatric history notable for previous diagnoses of 
depression and anxiety. No previous hospitalizations. Has 
therapist ___ ___, no consistent 
psychiatrist. Reported previous medication trials of several 
antidepressants (Prozac, Cymbalta, Celexa), none with 
significant improvement in symptoms. Of noted, patient reported 
that "citalopram ___ years ago led to significant weight gain and 
feeling numb, not helpful. Duloxetine ___ to help with 
chronic pain, led to severe exhaustion and did not help." Denies 
previous suicide attempts or self-injurious behavior. 
  
Past medical history:
- myofacial pain syndrome in neck
- recurrent UTIs
- asthma
- chronic pelvic pain
  
Allergies: NKDA; pollen and shellfish

with depression and anxiety; siblings with chronic SI, no known 
suicide attempts

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ year old woman with a history of chronic 
anxiety and dysthymia who is brought to the emergency department 
by EMS due to worsening symptoms of depression, irritability, 
and expressed suicidal ideation. 
  
  
1. LEGAL & SAFETY:  
On admission, the patient signed a conditional voluntary 
agreement (Section 10 & 11) and remained on that level 
throughout their admission. She was also placed on 15 minute 
checks status on admission and remained on that level of 
observation throughout while being unit restricted.
  
  
2. PSYCHIATRIC
#Major Depressive Disorder 
At the time of presentation, the patient had difficulty fully 
describing her current mood state, almost to the point of 
alexithymia. She did endorse recent fatigue, poor sleep, poor 
appetite, anhedonia, decreased motivation, diminished 
concentration, and passive suicidal thoughts. While she denied 
suicidal plan or intent, she did note that she had recently felt 
worried that she may lose control and do something unsafe. 
Collateral from her boyfriend, in addition to patient's 
appraisal of her own functioning, was concerning for recent 
deterioration and heightened irritability and depressed mood. On 
initial exam, she had a restricted affect and made minimal eye 
contact with interviewers. 
  
Her presentation appeared most consistent with major depressive 
disorder, but there was additionally an element of 
trauma-related symptoms contributing to her presentation. 
Patient has a history of sexual assault and also described 
arguments with boyfriend evoking memories from childhood when 
she observed her mother/stepfather arguing. 

She reported previous medication trials of fluoxetine, 
citalopram, and duloxetine which were discontinued either due to 
ineffectiveness or side effects. She was started on Wellbutrin 
XR 150mg daily and Hydroxyzine 25mg BID:PRN anxiety/insomnia. 
She reported feeling jittery, anxious, with racing heart on 
Wellbutrin XR 150mg so was transitioned to Wellbutrin SR 100mg. 
She tolerated this well with no reported side effects. Over the 
course of her admission, she engaged in treatment, including 
individual therapy as well as groups focused on coping. She 
reported improvement in her mood and energy level. She denied 
any suicidal ideation, reporting that she was no longer in a 
dark place. She had a less constricted affect and was brighter 
and more reactive. At the time of discharge, she was 
future-oriented, looking forward to getting back to work. 
  
  
3. MEDICAL
#Chronic pelvic pain: Patient reported intermittent right-sided 
pelvic pain exacerbated by urination, bowel movements, and 
intercourse. She denied heavy or irregular menstrual bleeding 
and stated that she usually does not take anything for the pain, 
as ibuprofen and Tylenol have never seemed to help. Patient has 
had discussions about endometriosis with doctors in the past but 
has never been definitively diagnosed. She reports that her 
symptoms are currently at baseline and tolerable. She declined 
offer for PRN pain medication during this admission.
  
  
4. SUBSTANCE USE: Patient reported intermittent marijuana use.  
She was provided with counseling regarding marijuana use and 
possible negative impact substance use has on her anxiety/mood. 
  
  
5. PSYCHOSOCIAL
#) GROUPS/MILIEU:  
The patient was encouraged to participate in the various groups 
and milieu therapy opportunities offered by the unit.  The 
patient often attended these groups that focused on teaching 
patients various coping skills.  She was also noted to be social 
with her peers in the milieu and pleasant with staff members. 
  
#) COLLATERAL CONTACTS & FAMILY INVOLVEMENT:
Patient provided verbal permission to contact her outpatient 
therapist ___ ___ and her 
outpatient PCP (Dr. ___ ___. Providers were 
contacted for collateral information and for discharge planning. 
Patient also gave verbal permission to contact her boyfriend  
___ who provided the primary team with 
collateral information.
  

INFORMED CONSENT: The team discussed the indications for, 
intended benefits of, and possible side effects and risks of 
starting Wellbutrin and Hydroxyzine, and risks and benefits of 
possible alternatives, including not taking the medications, 
with this patient.   We discussed the patient's right to decide 
whether to take this medication as well as the importance of the 
patient's actively participating in the treatment and discussing 
any  questions about medications with the treatment team, and I  
answered the patient's questions.  The patient appeared able to 
understand and consented to begin the medication.
  
  
RISK ASSESSMENT
On presentation, the patient was evaluated and felt to be at an 
increased risk of harm to herself and/or others based upon 
worsening functioning with passive suicidal ideation, fears of 
losing control and doing something unsafe.  Her static factors 
noted at that time include history of trauma and abuse, chronic 
mental illness, chronic pain (fibromyalgia, myofascial pain 
syndrome, chronic pelvic pain) .  The modifiable risk factors, 
which included lack of outpatient treaters, passive suicidal 
ideation, acute mood episode, and medication noncompliance 
(history of discontinuing several antidepressants due to side 
effects) were also addressed at that time.  The patient engaged 
in individual and group therapy focusing on coping skills during 
her admission; she was also started on Wellbutrin which she 
tolerated well and outpatient follow up was scheduled.  Finally, 
the patient is being discharged with many protective factors, 
including future-oriented thinking, willingness to seek help, 
and sense of responsibility to family.  Overall, based on the 
totality of our assessment at this time, the patient is not at 
an acutely elevated risk of self-harm nor danger to others. 
 
Medications on Admission:
None

groomed, wearing casual home clothing
  -Behavior: sitting up in a chair, making appropriate eye
contact with interviewers, no psychomotor agitation or
retardation
  -Attitude: calm and cooperative with the interview, easily
engaged
  -Mood and Affect: 'fine'; bright, appropriately reactive 
affect smiling several times throughout interview appropriately; 
less anxious appearing than previous
  -Speech: normal volume, rate, tone
  -Thought process: linear, no loose associations, organized
  -Thought content: denies SI and is future oriented, looking 
forward to getting back to work, did not endorse HI or AVH, does 
not appear to be responding to internal stimuli, no evidence of 
paranoia or delusions
  -Judgment and Insight: good

 
Discharge Instructions:
-Please follow up with all outpatient appointments as listed - 
take this discharge paperwork to your appointments.
-Unless a limited duration is specified in the prescription, 
please continue all medications as directed until your 
prescriber tells you to stop or change.
-Please avoid abusing alcohol and any drugs--whether 
prescription drugs or illegal drugs--as this can further worsen 
your medical and psychiatric illnesses.
-Please contact your outpatient psychiatrist or other providers 
if you have any concerns.
-Please call ___ or go to your nearest emergency room if you 
feel unsafe in any way and are unable to immediately reach your 
health care providers.
It was a pleasure to have worked with you, and we wish you the 
best of health.

Brief Hospital Course:
Pt is a ___ y.o female with h.o paranoid schizophrenia, HTN, HL, 
DM who presents s/p CP, SOB and now with ?AMS.  
.  
# AMS: Per her psych facility, she has had increased agitation 
over the past couple of days with mental status changes. Her 
baseline is unknown given paranoid schizophrenia but she 
partially answers some questions and is oriented to month, year 
and hospital (although incorrect hospital). No overt signs of 
aggression but appears withdrawn. CXR negative for signs of 
infection or reason for cough. Pt was continued on haldol as per 
prior regimen. There was no sign of infection, Bcx, Ucx were 
negative. TSH was normal. Pt did not display aggression during 
this hospitalization. Tegretol level was ordered.
.  
# Atypical CP: Pt does have risk factors for ACS including HTN, 
HL and DM. Patient was unable to fully describe her symptoms but 
points to the ___ her chest and says it hurts. Pt has 3 
sets of cardiac enzymes that were negative. She was observed on 
telemetry and did not have any events. Her EKG did not show any 
evidence of ischemia. She was continued on statin, ACEI and her 
ASA was increased to full dose.  
.  
# Paranoid schizophrenia: She was continued on haldol as above 
and klonopin, celexa, tegretol. She was evaluated by psychiatry 
and it was decided that she will require further inpatient 
psychiatric treatment.  
.  
# DM: Pt was continued on home 70/30 15 units BID and humalog 
ISS started.   
.  
# Anemia: Patient has history of anemia (unknown baseline) and 
takes iron supplements at home.  She was continued on iron 
tablets and her HCT monitored. 
.  
# HTN: She was continued on ACE-I and HCTZ. 
.  
# HL: Continued on home simvastatin.  
.  
# Asthma: started on combivent inhaler.
.  
Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, bowel regimen, pain control 
with tylenol  
.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ y.o female with h.o paranoid schizophrenia, HTN, HL, DM who 
presents with incontinence and abdominal pain and UTI and 
several abscesses s/p large MRSA perirectal abscess drainage in 
the OR. 
.
# R buttock abscess and several other sm buttock and thigh 
abscesses: Surgery consulted and drained large perirectal 
abscess in OR ___ and again ___. Cultures grew MRSA 
sensitive to doxycycline, bactrim, and vancomycin (as well as sm 
amt of corynebacterium). Pt initially started on doxycycline but

ERECTILE DYSFUNCTION; INFECTED PENILE PROSTHESIS

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.

Discharge Instructions:
-Please also refer to the instructions provided to you by the 
manufacturer of this prosthesis

-ALWAYS call to inform, review and discuss any medication 
changes and your post-operative course with your primary care 
doctor.

-over the next several days you may experience some increased 
swelling of your phallus (and scrotum) resembling a semi-rigid 
phallus (semi-erect); this is "normal" from the prosthesis and 
related surgery/edema. This may be accompanied by discoloration 
(ecchymosis) involving the phallus and the scrotum; this too is 
normal and will gradually resolve.

-Please remove the surgical dressing over penis and/or under 
scrotum on post-operative day two: no further wound care is 
needed and you may leave the wound open to air. 

-Please keep your phallus at midline, pointed toward your 
umbilicus, taped in place with protective gauze/pads (if 
necessary) for the next ___ days. Of course you may point it 
downward for voiding.

-Use a jock-supporter/strap or jockey-type briefs or tight, 
tighty-whities to facilitate this; Subsequently you may 
transition to loose fitting briefs or boxer-briefs for 
support--they should be cotton and/or breathable.

-Do NOT use prosthesis for 6 weeks and until explicitly advised 
by your urologist

-Complete a 7 day course of antibiotics as directed 
(Ciprofloxacin/Cephalexin)

-You may shower, but do NOT bathe, swim or otherwise immerse 
your incision.

-Do NOT lift anything heavier than a phone book and no sports, 
vigorous physical activity (including sexual).

-Tylenol should be your first line pain medication, a narcotic 
pain medication has been prescribed for breakthough pain >4. 
Replace Tylenol with narcotic pain medication. Max daily Tylenol 
dose is 4gm, note that narcotic pain medication also contains 
Tylenol (acetaminophen)

-Do NOT drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics and do NOT 
operate dangerous machinery. 
For your safety, please do NOT DRIVE FOR ONE WEEK AFTER SURGERY 
or unless otherwise advised. 

-Colace has been prescribed to avoid post-surgical constipation 
and constipation related to narcotic pain medication, 
discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea develops. Colace is a 
stool "softener"- it is NOT a laxative

-Resume your home medications, EXCEPT HOLD NSAIDs (aspirin, and 
ibuprofen containing products such as Advil & Motrin, Excedrin) 
for ONE week or until you see your urologist in follow-up OR you 
are explicitly advised to resume sooner by your PCP, ___ 
or Cardiologist.  DO NOT RESUME medications like VIAGRA, LEVITRA 
or CIALIS.

-If you have fevers > 101.5 F, vomiting, or increased redness, 
swelling, or discharge from your incision, call your doctor or 
go to the nearest emergency room.

Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to ___ after falling at the nursing home, 
when you arrived in the emergency room, multiple radiology 
studies were done, which showed that you did have any bleeding 
your head or any other broken bones.  However, since you were 
still complaining of neck pain, even though the CT scan of the 
bones in your neck was normal, they were unable to remove the 
cervical collar.  Since no one had seen you fall, we were 
concerned about caused the fall, as a result we also did an 
echocardiogram to look at the function of your heart and 
monitored the rhythm of your heart while you were in the 
hospital.  The only concerning finding during your 
hospitalization was that when we restarted your atenolol, your 
heart rate decreased into the 30's while you were sleeping, and 
only increased into the 40's when you were awake, as a result we 
stopped this medication since we were concerned that this could 
have contributed to your fall.   

Please call your doctor or return to the hospital if you have 
any other falls, experience a change in your vision, headaches, 
chest pain, palpitations or any other concerning symptoms.

Studies:
.
CT Abd - IMPRESSION: 1. Unchanged moderate intra- and 
extrahepatic biliary dilation with smooth tapering of the 
hepatic duct below the insertion of the cystic duct. Gallbladder 
distension is likely related to the ductal process rather than 
acute cholecystitis given the lack of wall thickening or 
pericholecystic fluid but clinical correlation is advised. 2. 
Possible 12-mm hypodensity in the head of the pancreas which is 
most likely focal fat deposition and is unchanged from the prior 
study. A mass cannot be entirely excluded and MRCP could be 
obtained if clinically relevant. 3. No findings to explain a 
sterile pyuria. 4. Colonic diverticulosis without evidence of 
acute diverticulitis. 5. Marked degenerative changes of the 
thoracolumbar ___ with further cortical destruction of the T9 
vertebral body. 
.
MR ___ - 1. Findings involving the T9 vertebral body, as on 
the prompting CT, likely represent a relatively acute 
osteoporotic compression fracture with very prominent fracture 
cleft. 2. While there is no significant loss of height, there is 
some retropulsion of its dorsal cortex with possible impingement 
upon the exiting right T9 nerve root. 3. Associated abnormality 
of, particularly, the right anterolateral paraspinal soft 
tissues at this level, with an overall appearance most 
suggestive of associated hemorrhage/granulation tissue, with no 
finding to specifically suggest a neoplastic process. 4. Bone 
marrow signal abnormalities involving the contiguous T10 
vertebral body, supporting underlying osteoporotic nature of 
this process, related to axial- loading injury. 5. Several 
chronic thoracolumbar vertebral wedge deformities with 
retropulsion, as detailed; in particular, there is significant 
spinal canal narrowing at the T12-L1 level, with deformity of 
the distal spinal cord but no discrete signal abnormality. 6. No 
other pathologic focus of enhancement seen to specifically 
suggest neoplastic disease. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old female past medical history of dementia, 
hypothyroid, hip replacement presenting from outside hospital 
with concern for new T9/T10 fracture status post fall who 
developed fevers in the ED.  
.  
#. Mechanical Fall: Initially there was concern for T9/T10 
Fracture at ___. The pt was transfered to ___ for 
orthopedics ___ eval who determined that the fracture was not 
acute. They recommended a TLSO for comfort only. Due to concern 
for possible malignancy, the patient underwent MRI scan of the 
___ on ___ which showed a relatively acute osteoporotic 
compression fracture with very 
prominent fracture cleft but no evidence of neoplastic disease. 
The patient was in a significant amount of back pain initially 
and received a combination of opiates, toradol, standing tylenol 
and lidocaine patch. In discussion with the patient's nursing 
facility it was determined that this pain was not much changed 
from the patient's baseline and that at the nursing facility the 
patient receives oxycontin 30mg BID. The patient was placed on 
this regimen with good improvement in pain although continues to 
have difficulty with turns/sitting/deep breahing. The TLSO brace 
was not yet ready at time of discharge. Discharged with plan for 
further pain management per provider at ___. Of 
note, a vertebroplasty was discussed to help palliate the 
patient's pain however it was decided that the risks outwighed 
benefits in this ___ year-old woman.
.  
#. Fever: The patient develoepd a fever to 102.0 in the ED. No 
clear source was identified initially. A UA showed pyuria 
however no bacteria and was nitrite negative. A CT torso at 
___ without evidence of pulmonary infiltrate.  Pt 
arrived to floor with foley in place, per records it was placed 
at ___ prior to transfer. This foley was removed on 
admission to the floor. Blood and Urine cultures remained 
negative and a respiratory viral screen including influenza was 
negative. The patient was afebrile throughout the remainder of 
her hospital course. 
.  
#Dementia- Pt severely demented at baseline per family. In the 
hosiptial she was oriented to eprson and place. At times able to 
answer questions appropriately. Continued on home donepezil.
.  
#Hypothyroidism- Continued home levothyroxine.
.
#. Transitional Issues:
1) Pain control: Optimize pain regimen with PO medications and 
can consider vertebroplasty as outpatient if not improving.
2) Orthopedics reccomended a TLSO brace for comfort. The brace 
was not yet ready at time of discharge. Can consider ordering at 
___.
3) Was saturating ~90% on RA. Most likely due to splinting from 
pain. On 2L O2 NC on discharge. 
4) Discontinued Seroquel as patient was overly sedated in-house. 
Can re-start if alertness improved at nursing facility.

Brief Hospital Course:
Summary: This is a ___ yo female with h/o ETOH dependence who 
presented to ___ and found to have acute pancreatitis 
whose course c/b CT contrast infiltration into R wrist who was 
transferred to ___ for management of possible wrist 
compartment syndrome.
.
# Alcoholic Pancreatitis: The patient presented with severe 
epigastric pain, an inability to tolerate PO, and abnormal LFTs. 
She was found to have hyperbilirubinemia, transaminitis, 
hyponatremia and an anion gap metabolic acidosis. She was given 
IV fluids and IV morphine for pain control. Over the course of 
her stay, the patient started to tolerate a regular diet without 
nausea and vomiting. Her pain was better controlled and her LFTs 
trended to normal ranges. The patient was discharged with 16 
pills of Percocet and told to followup at her scheduled 
appointment or sooner with her primary care doctor if she 
requires more pain control. 

# ETOH Dependence/Withdrawl: The patient reportedly had been 
drinking heavily over the past year. During her stay, she 
developed increased anxiety, tremulousness, fever, and 
tachycardia. She was started on a CIWA scale and required PO 
Valium to help her. She also reports vivid nightmares. Social 
work consulted with the patient and suggested resources for her 
to explore as an outpatient. The patient has a desire to quit 
alcohol, but has too many life stressors. She was given Valium 
20 mg PO on discharge.

# Right Wrist Swelling: Orthopedics hand surgery evaluated the 
patient and thought that her swelling was possibly due to 
compartment syndrome. They recommended against surgical 
intervention and suggested keeping the arm elevated and 
controlling her pain. With elevation, the pain subsided. The 
hand always remained neurovascularly intact and had normal 
pulses/strength/sensation on discharge. Ortho hand said to 
followup PRN in their clinic.

Normocytic anemia: The patient continued to have a normocytic 
anemia. It was stable throughout her stay. If it persists, it 
will likely need to be assessed as an outpatient. On discharge 
her Hct was 34.8. 

Depression/anxiety: The patient has poor social support and 
psychiatric issues and uses alcohol to cope with her problems. 
Social work spoke with the patient and provided outpatient 
resources. She was given a three day supply of Ativan 1 mg BID: 
PRN anxiety.

Uninsured: The patient reports having no insurance and said it's 
difficult to fill prescriptions and see doctors. ___ social 
worker here linked the patient to a state-sponsored health 
insurance plan.

Brief Hospital Course:
Summary: ___ yo F w/ h/o bipolar disorder, anxiety, ETOH abuse 
transferred from OSH for valproic acid overdose.
.
# Overdose, unresponsiveness: In the MICU, Valproic acid and 
ammonia levels trended down after patient received L-carnitine.  
Remainder of tox screen was negative.  Lactate, AG acidosis 
trended down after getting ivfs.  Patient was extubated on 
hospital day 2 and transferred to the floor, where her ammonia 
and valproic acid levels continued to decline.  Patient denies 
any memory of ingesting anything.
.
# Suicide Attempt / Bipolar disorder with predominant 
depression:  Initially medications were held at the 
recommendation of the consult psychiatry team.  Seroquel was 
started on hospital day 3.  The pt was kept ___ with a 
1:1 sitter.  She was transferred to a psychiatry floor when 
medically stable, for further treatment of her depression. 
.
# Etoh abuse: Pt with significant alcohol use.  CIWA protocol 
was used, pt intially scoring for withdrawal, later for anxiety 
related to her underlying psychiatry diagnosis and a headache 
felt to be tension headache.  Thiamine, folate, and MVI were 
initiated. She will continue to be monitored for withdrawal on 
the psychiatry unit.
.
# Epigastric pain:  Gerd/gastritis were possibilities.  Was 
improving with tylenol.  Amylase and lipase were normal, and she 
tolerated a full diet prior to discharge to psychiatry.  
.
# Headache: Tension headache, improved with tylenol. Initially 
treated with ibuprofen as well as tylenol, but this was stopped 
given the concern for gastritis.
.
----
Transitional issues:
.
# O/D:  Pt does not remember taking, does have history of 
suicide attempt in past.
.
# Abdominal pain: Likely related to gastritis or reflux, treated 
conservatively with tylenol. Try to avoid NSAID use given 
gastritis concern.  Started on ranitidine, consider stopping 
when symptoms have resolved.
.
# Tension Headache:  Treated with tylenol.
.
# Alcohol withdrawal:  Intially in withdrawal, later was scoring 
on CIWA for anxiety and headache, likely unrelated to alcohol 
withdrawal.
.
# Medication reconcilliation:  Unclear what regimen pt was 
currently on.  She will need titration of her psychiatric 
medications while on the psychiatry floor.  At the consult 
team's rec, pt received seroquel 150mg QHS to help with sleep.

Brief Hospital Course:
This is a ___ year old female history of bipolar disorder, ___ 
transferred from MICU/medicine s/p OD of neurontin, depakote, 
alcohol; event possibly suicide attempt in the setting of 
numerous psychosocial stressors and being unable to obtain her
prescription medications.

Axis I: GAD, History of bipolar, polysubstance abuse, r/o MDD 
Axis II: deferred
Axis III: s/p Depakote and neurontin overdose 
Axis IV: severe: unemployed, lives at home with dysfunctional
parents, lost custody of children, multiple psych issues. 
Axis V: 30

#). Anxiety: Pt reports long history of severe anxiety with 
chest pressure, racing thoughts, diaphoresis, inner feeling of 
restlessness previously treated with numerous high-dose 
medication (thorazine, seroquel, neurontin). 
- Although akathesia was certainly on the differential, pt 
described feelings of restlessness prior to initiation of 
antipsychotics. In addition, stated anxiety sxs were best 
controlled on neurontin, thorazine, seroquel.  
- Due to concerns of polypharmacy in the setting of two prior 
overdoses, we initially held the patient's Depakote, Neurontin, 
Thorazine, and continued Seroquel 150 mg bid. 
- Started mirtazapine 30 mg qhs for anxiety and depression, 
however, pt continued to c/o severe anxiety symptoms. Eventually 
added Luvox that was tapered up to 150 mg qhs as well as 
thorazine 75 mg tid and 175 mg qhs, Neurontin 600 mg tid, and 
atenolol that was tapered to 50 mg po qd with careful monitoring 
of BP and HR. 
- Pt expressed concern that she would not be able to receive 
thorazine as an outpatient, so d/c'ed thorazine and started 
perphenazine 8mg tid, 16 qhs with significant improvement in 
anxiety symptoms. 

#). Ethanol dependence/PSA: Per OMR, pt reported drinking 
approximately 2 pints of hard liquor per day. Also h/o opiate 
dependence.
- CIWA scale initially started. Vital signs remained stable 
throughout hospitalization with no complications. 
- group/milieu therapy.

#). Depression, History of bipolar disorder: difficult to assess 
validity of diagnosis at this time, as the patient's only period 
of sobriety was during her pregnancies. However, no evidence of 
mania on this admission and no clear history of mania in the 
past. 
- The patient met diagnostic criteria for MDD, but has been 
abusing alcohol to control her anxiety symptoms. To target 
depressive and anxiety symptoms, we started mirtazapine and 
Luvox. 
- Held lithium and depakote therapy, particularly considering 
the hx of recent SA per overdosing. 
 
#) s/p overdose of depakote and neurontin: clinically stable. 
LFT's normalized, last depakote level= 30's. Not 
encephalopathic. 
- Patient remained medically stable throughout this admission. 

#). Legal/Safety: Pt was admitted to ___ on CV. She was 
able to maintain her safety throughout the admission on q15 
minute checks 

#). Dispo: Patient will be discharged to ___ 
Services in ___ as noted below.

left in place.  During admission, patient was treated with 
vancomycin (___) and zosyn (___). Patient had a history 
of osteomyelitis and endocarditis in ___, so these were 
evaluated with a TTE, TEE (requiring conscious sedation) and a 
CT spine which did not show evidence of current endocarditis or 
osteomyelitis. ID followed this patient throughout the admission 
and felt that given lack of fevers, negative blood blood 
cultures, and no obvious source, they felt he could go back to 
prison without antibiotics.
.  
# ESRD: Pt gets MWF dialysis, which was continued throughout the 
admission. Renal transplant service was made aware of patient's 
admission, as they are planning to create a brachiocephalic 
fistula for dialysis. Pt is on transplant list, transplant 
surgery elected to defer surgery while patient is being worked 
up for infection.  Continued home sevelamer, doxercalciferol and 
given lenient renal diet (per patient insistence) and was fluid 
restricted (1L/day). Patient will be seen by trasnplant shortly 
after discharge.
.  
# Joint pains: Pt w/ chronic pain of back, as well as L ankle 
and L great toe, which he attributes to gout. Patient remained 
on allopurinol during admission. Was not started on colchicine, 
and renal fellow recommended against this medication in ESRD 
patients. Ortho consult felt his back pain may be secondary to 
sacroiliitis. A pelvic xray did not show any fracture, 
dislocation, or acute osteo. A CT spine of his back did not show 
signs concerning for osteomyelitis either. Patient was continued 
on his home regimen of MS contin 30mg BID for chronic pain as 
well as started on NSAIDs for management of pain. Additonally 
complaining of locked DIP and PIP joints bilaterally, which was 
not actively assessed as an inpatient. Patient has outpatient 
follow up with orthopedic surgery.
.
# Hypertension: Patient's blood pressure ranged from the 
120s-140s in the hours after dialysis, to the 160s-190s in the 
day and a half leading up to the next dialysis session.  Patient 
c/o frequent HAs with elevated pressures and had an episode of 
vomitting with a BP of 177/90. During this time, pt had no 
papiledema or AMS. A CT head was negative for intracranial 
process and HA improved with hydralazine. Patient required 
several additional doses of hydralazine and lisinopril, and on 
the day prior to discharge, his standing lisinopril was 
increased from 5mg to 10mg PO daily with improved BPs 
(140s/80s).

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You were admitted to the hospital because you were having low 
grade fevers during your dialysis session.  You were being 
treated for a bacteria in your blood at your outpatient dialysis 
unit for the past 2 weeks, and so we were worried that the 
antibiotics you were on were not treating your infection.  While 
you were in the hospital, we gave you 2 strong antibiotics.  You 
did not have a fever in the hospital and we never found any 
bacteria growing in your blood.  The blood drawn at your 
dialysis unit also never had any bacteria growing in it. We did 
some imaging of your back and heart because we were concerned 
that you may have an infection in either of these areas, however 
there was no evidence of infection on these studies.  Because 
there is not evidence that you are still infected, we have 
stopped your antibiotics.  It is common to have low grade fevers 
while getting dialysis, so this may be a chronic event for you. 
If you remain afebrile over the next week (with a temperature 
not greater than 100.4F), you should be able to have a fistula 
or graft placed soon.  We have made an appointment with your 
transplant surgeon, Dr. ___, for next week (see 
details below), so that you will have close follow up and so the 
procedure will be done as soon as possible.

You were noted to have a lung nodule of unknown significance on 
CXR. You should follow up with your PCP and should be scheduled 
for an outpatient Chest CT to follow this.

Please continue your home medication as prescribed.  You no 
longer need to take Ceftazidime, the antibiotic you were getting 
at dialysis.

The following changes have been made to your medications:
- please INCREASE lisinopril to 10 mg daily
- please START ibuprofen 400 mg every 8 hours, if this isn't 
managing your pain, you can increase to 600 or 800 mg every 8 
hours.  Please be sure to take ibuprofen with food, do not take 
it on an empty stomach.
- please STOP taking ceftazidime.  There is no active evidence 
of infection, so you do not need any antibiotics right now.

The rest of your medications have not changed.  Please continue 
to take them as originally prescribed.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old incarcerated male with ESRD secondary to Polycystic 
Kidney Disease on HemoDialysis with recent E. coli bacteremia 
diagnosed by Blood culture from outside hospital on ___ 
believed secondary to HD line infection, presented this time 
with fevers, chills/rigors, found to have 1 out of 4 bottle E 
coli bacteremia. He was stable and discharged on Bactrim for 1 
week. 
.
# Fevers: Patient admitted to ___ for the third time in the 
past month with fevers and rigors. Patient last had 
blood-culture proven E. coli bacteremia in ___. The 
source of infection is most likely the tunneled right-sided HD 
line, but blood cultures during this admission only grew E. coli 
in one bottle, so contamination of the sample by multiple 
hospital admission acquired skin flora cannot be ruled out and 
bacteremia cannot be ruled in. Patient's history is also 
significant for chronic osteomyelitis of his lumbar spine, but 
no acute infection was evident on MRI. Patient was initially 
treated wtih ceftazidime in the ED, broaded to 
vancomycin/cefepime, and after the culture returned GNR, 
narrowed to cefepime only. After speciation and sensitivity 
returned, and given question of bacteremia, patient was treated 
conservatively with Bactim DS once a day at evening for a total 
of 7 days without need for a line change at this time.
.  
# ESRD: He continued to receive MWF dialysis in-house. Renal 
transplant service and Transplant surgery were aware of pt on 
previous admission and were informed of current admission. 
Patient continued his home sevelamer, doxercalciferol, renal 
caps, and renal diet in-house.  
.  
# Chronic joint pains: Patient has chronic pain of back, knees 
and ankles which he attributes to gout. Previous ortho consult 
felt his back pain may be secondary to sacroiliitis, pelvic xray 
did not show any fracture, dislocation, or acute osteomyelitis, 
and CT spine did not show signs concerning for osteomyelitis 
either. Diagnosis of gout is questionable given chronicity of 
pains, location, and pain without signs consistent with acute 
gout flares. Rheumatology at the ___ has seen the patient and 
doubts gout. Have been unable to attain original documentation 
of how the gout was diagnosed, but pt was most recently treated 
for a flare in ___ with prednisone, ___, and 
allopurinol. MRI of lumbar spine was done this admission and 
showed signs of chronic osteomyelitis and bilateral neural 
foramina narrowing and compression of the L5 nerve roots and 
abutting the S1 nerve roots, likely the source of the pain. No 
evidence of acute osteomyelitis was seen. Patient's pain was 
controlled with his home regimen of MS contin and allopurinol.
.
# Hypertension: Controlled in house with home dose of lisinopril 
and metoprolol.
.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ M with ESRD on HD, HTN, chronic osteomyelitis and multiple 
admissions for fevers presenting with fever following HD.

# Fevers - Patient has had multiple admissions for transient 
fevers, often following HD, with blood cultures occasionally 
positive for E.coli.  Fevers only began once tunnel catheter was 
placed, after AVF clotted.  ESR and CRP are at patient's 
baseline so unlikely acute on chronic osteomyelitis.  In 
addition, patient had no worsening of his low back pain.  
Radiography showed stable process as well. CXR showed no acute 
cardiopulmonary process.  Patient given vancomycin/cefepime x1 
in ER.  Overnight on HD1/2 patient spiked fevers to 103.2 and on 
HD2, tunneled catheter line was pulled and patient was started 
on vancomycin and ceftazadime with dialysis. Patient was given a 
line holiday for 2 days prior to replacement of line.  Line tip 
culture grew strep viridans, coag negative staph, non hemolytic 
strep and corynebacterium consistent with skin or oral flora. 
Blood cultures were negative to date on the day of discharge.  
Patient was afebrile following removal of HD line and did not 
have further fevers.  He completed a 7 day course of vancomycin 
and cefepime following the discontinuation of the HD line.  
Other potential sources of occult infection were investigation 
with a CT abdomen, prostate ultrasound, WBC tagged scan and bone 
scan.  All of these studies were negative for infection.  

# ESRD on HD - Patient gets dialysis ___. 
He was continued on his home sevelamer, doxercalciferol and 
nephrocaps while inpatient. He was dialyzed on ___ 
prior to removal of original tunneled HD line, and spiked a 
fever to 105.  The line was removed following dialysis and 
patient had a "line holiday" until ___ when a 
new tunneled cath was placed without issue.  Patient was 
dialyzed on ___ and ___ as scheduled following 
replacement of catheter.  He had no fevers during or following 
dialysis.  Patient has follow-up scheduled with surgical team 
regarding AV fistula v graft.

# Leukopenia/Thrombocytopenia - Has had WBC as low as 2.8 back 
in ___, this appears to be the first time platelets have 
dipped so low. Patient recently on bactrim which ended 1.5 weeks 
ago, and working diagnosis was residual thrombocytopenia due 
this antibiotic.  In addition, with history of HepC, may be due 
to decreased liver function.  Platelets initially trended down, 
but were increasing above admission levels at the time of 
discharge.

# Chronic pain - Has chronic joint pains which have been 
associated with gout in the past. Also with history of chronic 
osteomyelitis as above.  Pain was at baseline and well 
controlled on home regimen of amitriptyline, MS contin 30mg BID, 
ropinirole.  
  
# Hypertension: Patient was intiially continued on lisinopril 
and metoprolol at home doses.  On HD 4, blood pressures were 
elevated, likely in the setting of volume overload due to 
dietary indiscretions and no HD over the weekend.  Patient was 
given hydralazine 25mg q6h, and following dialysis with removal 
of 4.5L, pressures remained elevated.  Lisinopril was increased 
to 40mg daily as well and patient was discharged on hydralazine 
and new dose of lisinopril.   Consider titrating off of 
hydralazine as full effect of lisinopril is seen.
  
# Hepatitis C: Chronic hep C with prior interferon treatment 
dc'ed for GI bleed and ineffectiveness. He is not currently 
being treated.  
  
# Anemia: On prior admission Hct ranged from ___ throughout 
admission, baseline appears to be around 28, secondary to 
chronic renal disease and possibly iron deficiency.  Hematocrit 
remained at baseline throughout admission.

# Transitional issues:
- Please titrate down and discontinue entirely if blood 
pressures well controlled on increased dose of lisinopril.
- 8-mm rim calcified nodular opacity within the left lung base 
noted on CXR, patient will need a non-emergent CT scan to better 
evaluate  
- Patient will have follow-up with surgical team regarding AV 
fistula/graft.  This should be done as soon as possible to avoid 
further tunneled line infections.

Brief Hospital Course:
On ___, he underwent renal transplant from a HCV positive 
donor (recipient's HCV VL was 1,100,000 cop/ml on ___ 
right iliac fossa with neo ureterocystostomy over a ___ 
double-J stent with JP drain placed. Small amounts of urine were 
made immediately. Surgeon was Dr. ___. A peritoneal 
tear occurred during mobilization of the peritoneum during 
vascular exposure. Per report the kidney was decapsulated. A old 
stent was also removed from left forearm. Please refer to 
operative note for details. Postop, vital signs.   

Urine output was scant. IV hydration was given. Creatinine 
remained elevated. On postop day 1, potassium was elevated to 
7.0. He experienced delayed renal graft function (DGF). 
Hemodialysis was performed via the tunnelled right IJ line. 
Urine output was scant averaging 32-0cc/day. IV fluid was 
stopped and hemodialysis continued with last treatment on ___ 
for 2300ml. Weight was 75.5kg on ___.  

He was given a total of 4 doses of ATG, Cellcept and tapering 
doses of steroids per protocol until off (last dose ___. 
Prograf was started on postop day 0. Trough levels were low 
(goal 10)and dose was up titrated to 10mg bid on ___. 

Labs were notable for hct that trended down daily to 24 on 
___. Epogen was planned for dialysis days. 

He was tolerating a regular diet, ambulating independently 
(steady on feet)and RLQ incision was clean, dry and intact with 
staples. The JP drain output was high initially (720ml/day)and 
thus the drain remained in place. Output decreased to 115 ml by 
postop day 5. JP drain fluid was serosanguinous and creatinine 
of this fluid was 6.8 ruling out a urine leak (similar to 
serum). He did have a small amount of scrotal edema and was 
instructed to elevate scrotum on a towel. 

Left forearm incision was intact with staples without 
redness/drainage. 

He was discharged back to prison.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ year-old man with PMH of APCKD s/p CDC high 
risk donor transplant on ___ who presented from ___ with 
hyponatremia. 

#. Hyponatremia - The patient presented with a sodium of 121. 
This was thought to be related to decreased PO intake recently 
as he has been on a religious fast. Also had been drinking more 
when told to increase hydration for better kidney perfusion (see 
below). Exercises vigorously daily and likely loses salt in that 
setting. The patient's sodium improved while here with simple PO 
intake encouragement. Never had MS changes. Sodium was 133 on 
day of dsicharge. 

#. Renal txpt, AOCKD - The patient's Cr has been elevated since 
___ to 2.2 from a baseline ~1.8. No clear etiology and this 
remained stable while here. He was continued on all 
immunosupressives and taro level was at goal between ___. 
Urinalysis was unremarkable as was a renal ultrasound. Further 
follow-up as an outpatient is warranted. Continued on bactrim 
PPx. 

#. Hyperkalemia - The patient's potassium was elevated in house. 
Never had ECG changes. Switched to a low-K diet and Ace-I 
stopped. Potassium was 5.4 on day of discharge. 

#. Leukopenia - The patient had a mild leukopenia in house. 
Unclear etiology and resolved on its own prior to discharge. Was 
on azithro when admitted for a possible sinus infection, however 
had no infectious symptoms in-house and this was stopped. 

#. HTN - Lisinopril was held due to ___ and hyperkalemia. The 
patient remained normotensive in-house.

#. Osteoporosis - Continued home medications.

- Ensure patient is eating three meals daily and staying well

Pain began last night after eating dinner, sudden onset, 
initially periumbilical later migrating to the lower right 
quadrant and right flank. States that the pain is "right in the 
transplanted kidney." Pain is now constant, cramping/aching. 
Induced vomiting several times to help relieve discomfort, but 
did not help. NBNB emesis, no hematochezia/melanotic stool. Pain 
worse with movement; he has not eaten since last night before 
the pain began.  Has never had this pain before, had eaten 
earlier that night w/ no pain. No hematuria, dysuria. +bilateral 
___ swelling. Denies f/c, CP, SOB. No missed doses of medicine.  

In the ED, initial VS were: 99.2 108 132/82 100% RA. HRs 
improved to ___. sBPs variable, but mostly in 110-130s (some 
values in 160-180s). Other vitals remained stable.
 
Exam notable for:   On exam, has enlarged and tender RLQ renal 
allograft, also tender in periumbilical area. 1+ b/l pitting 
edema. Lungs clear. Tachycardic. RUE brachiocephalic fistula 
without flow. systolic murmur LUS/LLSB

Labs showed: Cr 3.1 -> 3.2. K 5.4, repeat 5.6. Mg 1.1, improved 
to 1.6 w/ IV mag. Phos 1.7. LFTs and coags unremarkable. Lactate 
normal, flu negative.  UA with blood and proteinuria.

Imaging showed:  
CT A/P W/O contrast 
Nonspecific perinephric stranding surrounding the transplant 
kidney. No perinephric abscess or hydronephrosis. Nonspecific 
stranding around the third portion of the duodenum without wall 
thickening. Mild duodenitis is possible in appropriate clinical 
setting. No additional acute process within the abdomen or
pelvis.

RENAL TRANSPLANT U/S
No hydronephrosis or perinephric fluid collection. Elevated 
resistive indices compared to prior studies. Whether there is 
true diastolic flow within the intrarenal arteries or artifacts 
with possible loss of diastolic flow is difficult to discern. 
Close follow-up with repeat ultrasound is recommended.

Consults:  renal transplant recommended CT abdomen and 
transplant surgery c/s. continue immunosuppression meds, hold 
Bactrim for hyperK. Transplant surg found no indication for 
surgery.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ w/ ESRD s/p deceased donor renal 
transplant in ___ complicated by chronic allograft dysfunction 
(antibody-mediated rejection ___, biopsy-confirmed chronic 
transplant glomerulopathy, interstitial fibrosis & tubular 
atrophy ___, HTN, GERD, HCV s/p ledipasvir-sofosbuvir, & 
hyperparathyroidism s/p sub-total parathyroidectomy ___ who 
presented with increasing shortness of breath. 

# Dyspnea
# ?Acute CHF Exacerbation 
The patient presented with a history of orthopnea & dyspnea w/ 
CXR findings of bilateral effusions & pulmonary vascular 
congestion consistent with fluid overload state. His weight was 
noted to be higher recently from prior discharge. No medication 
non-adherence or dietary changes although the recent addition of 
sodium bicarbonate may be contributing due to increased Na load. 
Patient's blood pressures were uncontrolled & likely further 
increased his left-sided afterload. A TTE on ___ revealed 
elevated PCWP and E/E' with preserved EF. Overall patient 
reported symptomatic improvement with diuresis and his daily 
weights continued to trend down. Although there are no concerns 
of rejection based on a bland urine sediment and an unremarkable 
renal ultrasound, the etiology of the patient's volume overload 
may have been in part also been caused by worsening renal 
function as evidenced by creatinines in the 4s compared to his 
baseline of creatinine in the 3s. Patient was diuresed with IV 
furosemide PRN and transitioned to oral diuretics. His 
electrolytes are monitored and repleted as needed. His labetalol 
was increased to 600 mg 3 times daily and he was continued on 
his nifedipine 30 mg daily.

# ___:
# ESRD w/p transplant c/b chronic rejection:
Cr 4 on presentation, up from discharge 3.2 on ___. His elevated 
creatinine may be cardiorenal in etiology given clinical context 
and possible end-organ damage in setting of hypertension but 
worsening overall renal function cannot be ruled out given lack 
of significant improvement with diuresis. His renal US had no 
evidence/concern for hydronephrosis and there was less concern 
for rejection at this time given bland urine and lack of 
characteristics findings on renal US. The patient's renal 
function was trended daily. He was continued on his 
immunosuppressive regimen of mycophenolate, tacrolimus, and 
prednisone. His tacrolimus levels were trended daily. He was 
continued on atovaquone prophylaxis. His MAPs were maintained 
above 65. He is also continued on calcium and cinacalcet. Sodium 
bicarbonate was held in the setting of his volume overloaded 
state. His blood pressure was better controlled as noted.

# HTN:
The patient was noted to have systolic blood pressure readings 
in the ___. He was previously on losartan & labetalol last 
hospitalization but losartan was held on discharge given 
persistent hyperkalemia. At that time, labetalol dosing was 
increased to 400mg TID from 200mg BID & nifedipine ER 30mg QD 
was initiated. No evidence of renal artery stenosis in 
transplant kidney as though no changes in resistive indices. The 
patient's labetalol was increased to 600 mg 3 times daily and he 
was continued on nifedipine along leading to better blood 
pressure control.

# Mild Hyperkalemia:
Patient presented with mild hyperkalemia and on review of 
records, it appeared that patient was chronically mildly 
hyperkalemic. His hyperkalemia improved with ongoing IV diuresis 
with Furosemide. 

# Normocytic anemia:
His home hemoglobin was similar to baseline values in setting of 
end-stage renal disease. His CBCs were trended daily and he did 
not require a blood transfusion during his hospitalization.

# GERD:
Continued on his prior dose of ranitidine.

# Insomnia:
Continued on his prior dose of amitriptyline. His ramelteon was 
held due to concerns of possible toxicity to the renal 
transplant.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ y/o male with a history of ESRD ___ PCKD s/p 
deceased donor renal transplant (___) c/b chronic allograft 
dysfunction, now back on HD since ___, HCV s/p Harvoni, and 
HTN who presented with left flank/hip/testicular pain. 
Infectious work up was unremarkable. MRI spine was notable for 
degenerative disc disease, likely causing radicular pain. 
Chronic pain service and orthopedic surgery were consulted and 
recommended ongoing pain management. 

ACUTE ISSUES:
=============
#Left flank/hip/back pain, severe uncontrolled pain
#Neuropathic pain
The patient presented with ___ weeks of left flank pain that 
then moved into his left hip, thigh, groin and left testicle. 
Initial evaluation was notable for CVA tenderness and left 
testicular tenderness concerning for UTI/nephrolithiasis vs 
epididymitis. CT abd/pelvis showed an atrophic kidney without 
nephrolithiasis or pyelonephritis and testicular ultrasound was 
equivocal for epidimyitis. He was initially started on broad 
spectrum antibiotics, which were discontinued after urine 
culture, GC & chlamydia returned negative. Given persistent 
pain, MRI L-spine and pelvis were done, demonstrating L5-S1 
changes c/w chronic spondyloarthropathy ___ ESRD vs sequela of 
prior discitis, as well as severe left-sided L4-L5 neural 
foraminal narrowing. The L4-L5 was felt to be the etiology of 
his pain given the correlating location. Chronic pain service 
and orthopedic surgery were consulted and provided recommends 
for pain management. He was continued on oxycodone, 
amitriptyline and started on tizanidine as well as lyrica with 
improvement in his pain. He will follow up in the ___ spine 
clinic for further management. 

#ESRD ___ PCKD s/p renal transplant c/b rejection now on HD
Presented with moderate volume overload, particularly noted to 
have bilateral pleural effusions on CXR. He underwent multiple 
daily sessions of dialysis with improvement and then was 
transitioned to his normal regimen. He had significant weight 
gain between sessions and required tighter fluid restriction, 
which should be continued as an outpatient. Additionally, his 
home prednisone and tacrolimus were continued.

#Acute hypoxic respiratory failure
#Acute pulmonary edema
Patient noted to have rapidly worsening hypoxia one evening 
during his hospitalization briefly requiring a non-rebreather. 
Repeat CXR showed significant pulmonary edema with bilateral 
effusions. He was started on a nitroglycerin gtt and underwent 
urgent bedside dialysis overnight with improvement in his 
clinical status. He was rapidly weaned to room air and remained 
stable for the remainder of the hospitalization. 

#NSTEMI
Troponin 0.08 on admission and continued to rise to 0.45 in the 
setting of fluid overload and acute hypoxic respiratory failure. 
EKG showed borderline submillimeter ST depressions in I, V5-V6 
(different from baseline), which was stable/improving on serial 
EKGs. He denied having any chest pain during this time. 
Cardiology was consulted and felt the presentation was 
consistent with type II NSTEMI due to fluid overload. Follow up 
TTE did not demonstrate a wall motion abnormality. Ultimately, 
cardiology decided against stress test at this time. He was 
discharged on his home aspirin with the addition of atorvastatin 
and metoprolol. 

#Atrial fibrillation 
Noted to be in atrial fibrillation on ___, which rapidly 
resolved within hours to a day. This was a new diagnosis for the 
patient, felt to be ___ fluid shifts vs less likely cardiac 
ischemia. TSH normal. His home labetalol was switched to 
metoprolol and his heart rate and rhythm remained stable. Given 
a CHADSVASC of 1, anticoagulation was not started.  

#Access
Newly placed fistula with some ulceration. He should follow up 
with Dr. ___ in Nephrology to evaluate as an outpatient. 

CHRONIC ISSUES:
===============
#Hypertension
He was continued on his home nifedipine. He refused several 
daily doses of labetalol, stating the dose was too high. Given 
new episode of atrial fibrillation, possible cardiac disease, 
and normotensive pressures without labetalol, he was switched to 
metoprolol and remained stable on this regimen.  

#Normocytic anemia 
Hemoglobin stable from prior, felt to be ___ anemia of chronic 
disease ___ ESRD
and iron deficiency. He was continued on his on iron 
supplementation. 

#GERD
- Continued ranitidine 

#BPH
- Continued tamsulosin

Regarding his ulcers, per outpatient notes, Mr. ___ has a

history of manipulative and self-injurious behavior. The wound 
on
the right hand started as a small cut likely from trimming his
finger nails. Without adequate wound care or dressing changes,
this progressed into a blister and then further progressed to

necrotic lesion.

He had an ultrasound of the right subclavian to rule out 
thrombus
and an echo which showed no vegetations. ANCA panel and
cryoglobulins were negative. He had a period where the hand
became edematous and erythematous, with elevated ESR and CRP and
was treated with IV vanco and ceftaz with improvement in the
wound appearance, edema and erythema. Despite this, he continued
to be non-compliant with wound care.

He was seen by Vascular Surgery at ___ and on ___ an
arteriogram was done there showing:

The right subclavian artery axillary and brachial arteries were
all widely patent.  The right ulnar artery was the primary
outflow to the hand as the radial artery occluded in the distal
forearm.  On the left the subclavian axillary and brachial
arteries were all widely patent.  There was reversal of flow
distal to the fistula, the fistula filled very quickly.  With
fistula compression the ulnar artery had improved flow and was
the primary runoff to the hand as the radial artery occluded in
the mid forearm.  Of note, there was significant sluggish flow
throughout all of his vessels concerning for a possible central
source.

Dr. ___ performed the study, had no good explanation
for the very sluggish flow in this patient whose last EF was
normal. There were no treatable lesions as above.

Dr. ___, the transplant physician who has been managing his 
left upper extremity fistula, felt that ligating the fistula 
would be recommended in this setting to optimize flow to the 
left hand and help healing as much as possible, although patient 
has declined in the past. This may be an elective option in the 
future.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ y/o male with a history of ESRD ___ PCKD s/p 
deceased donor renal transplant (___) c/b chronic allograft 
dysfunction, now back on HD since ___, HCV s/p Harvoni, and 
HTN who presented with bilateral digital ulcers, with imaging 
concerning for possible osteomyelitis. Broad workup sent to rule 
out vasculitic process and embolic source. Presentation 
ultimately thought secondary to peripheral vascular disease with 
associated dry gangrene of the digits.

ACUTE/ACTIVE PROBLEMS: 

# Foot/Hand ulcers
# Concern for osteomyelitis
Patient presented with worsening pain, swelling, and necrotic 
changes of the R index/middle and L index fingers in the setting 
of progressively worsening chronic hand ischemia. Duration seems 
likely ___ months, as not noted on prior admission discharged in 
___. Per outpatient notes, injury was apparently incurred and 
resulted in worsening appearance and apparent concern for 
superinfection which was treated with IV Vanc/Ceftaz at ___ 
additionally, reportedly ANCA and Cryoglobulins were sent and 
were negative. When not improved, patient was sent to ___ 
where arteriogram shows sluggish flow without evidence of a flow 
limiting lesion. This may be seen in the presence of a central 
lesion or can also be seen in advanced heart failure, however EF 
was noted to be preserved. Broad differential was considered for 
decreased perfusion and vasculopathy including peripheral 
arterial disease, embolic (hypercoagulability, infectious, 
central lesion) vasculitis(small/medium/large vessel 
involvement, cryoglobulinemia) with work up unrevealing. He also 
underwent CTA chest which did not show a central lesion in his 
aorta. He had ABIs of the lower extremities which showed 
significant vascular occlusive disease. Calciphylaxis was 
considered, dermatology was consulted but thought unlikely given 
isolated involvement of fingertips. For potential benefit of 
increased perfusion via vasodilation, nifedipine was uptitrated. 
Tacrolimus was discontinued after discussion with renal given 
limited benefit to graft and known side effect of 
vasoconstriction. Admission radiographs concerning for R digit 
osteomyelitis and as such MR was obtained which was not fully 
completed, but did not show osteomyelitis. Repeat MRI was not 
pursued as hand surgery did not think it would change 
management. Vascular surgery and hand surgery were consulted. 
Vascular surgery did not recommend intervention. Hand surgery 
felt his presentation was most likely consistent with dry 
gangrene related to his peripheral vascular disease and the 
fingers would likely self-demarcate/self-amputate. Pain was 
aggressively controlled with OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) 15 mg 
PO Q8H:PRN Pain on discharge. He was also started on gabapentin 
100 mg daily as adjuvant medication which discussed with the 
nephrology team.

#Atypical pneumonia
Found to incidentally have multifocal opacities on CTA chest per 
above. He was asymptomatic without leukocytosis, fever, cough. 
Differential diagnosis for the opacities included vasculitis 
given the above workup, however was ultimately felt to be most 
consistent with an atypical pneumonia. He received azithromycin 

#ESRD ___ PCKD s/p DDRT ___ c/b chronic allograft dysfunction 
(antibody-mediated rejection ___, biopsy-confirmed chronic 
transplant glomerulopathy, interstitial fibrosis & tubular 
atrophy ___ 
Patient maintained on HD ___ schedule for dialysis. Discharge 
weight was around
148lb on prior admission. On admission 140lbs. Discharge weight

Labetolol switched to metoprolol succinate 50 daily last

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

It was a pleasure taking care of you at ___ 
___.  During your hospitalization, you had surgery to 
remove unhealthy tissue on your lower extremity.  You tolerated 
the procedure well and are now ready to be discharged from the 
hospital.   Please follow the recommendations below to ensure a 
speedy and uneventful recovery.

LOWER  EXTREMITY AMPUTATION (bilateral first hallux) 
DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS

ACTIVITY 

You should keep your amputation site elevated whenever 
possible.It is very important that you put WEIGHT BEAR FOR 
ESSENTIAL DISTANCES ONLY UNTIL YOU ARE SEEN IN FOLLOW UP. 

MEDICATION

Before you leave the hospital, you will be given a list of all 
the medicine you should take at home.  If a medication that you 
normally take is not on the list or a medication that you do not 
take is on the list please discuss it with the team!  

You will likely be prescribed narcotic pain medication on 
discharge which  can be very constipating.  If you take 
narcotics,  please also take a stool softener such as Colace.   
If constipation becomes a problem, your pharmacist can suggest 
an additional over the counter laxative. 

You should take Tylenol ___ every 6 hours, as needed for 
pain.  If this is not enough, take your prescription narcotic 
pain medication.  You should require less pain medication each 
day.  Do not take more than a daily total of 3000mg of Tylenol.  
Tylenol is used as an ingredient in some other over-the-counter 
and prescription medications.  Be aware of how much Tylenol you 
are taking in a day.

BATHING/SHOWERING: 
You may shower when you feel strong enough but no tub baths or 
pools until you have permission from your surgeon and the 
incision is fully healed.  DO NOT SOAK YOUR INCISION.
After your shower, gently dry the incision well.   Do not rub 
the area. 

WOUND CARE:
Please keep the wound clean and dry. It is very important that 
there is no pressure on the wound.    If there is no drainage, 
you may leave the incision open to air.  

Your staples/sutures will remain in for at least 3 weeks.  At 
your followup appointment, we will see if the incision has 
healed enough to remove the sutures. 

CALL THE OFFICE FOR: ___
Opening, bleeding or drainage or odor from your wound incision 

Redness, swelling or warmth in your wound.
Fever greater than 101 degrees, chills, or worsening 
incisional/wound pain  

NO OTHER PROVIDER, EXCEPT YOUR VASCULAR SURGEON, SHOULD 
DETERMINE IF YOUR SUTURES ARE READY TO BE REMOVED FROM YOUR 
WOUND!   
IF THERE ARE ANY QUESTIONS, THE PROVIDER SHOULD CALL THE 
VASCULAR SURGERY OFFICE AT ___ TO DISCUSS.   THE 
SUTURES WILL BE REMOVED IN THE OFFICE AT YOUR FOLLOWUP 
APPOINTMENT WHEN IT IS DETERMINED BY THE VASCULAR SURGEON THAT 
THE WOUND HAS SUFFICIENTLY HEALED.

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the orthopaedic surgery service and 
was taken to the operating room for above described procedure. 
Please see separately dictated operative report for details. The 
surgery was uncomplicated and the patient tolerated the 
procedure well. Patient received perioperative IV antibiotics.

Postoperative course was remarkable for the following:
POD#2  Tm 102.9 overnight (11pm)), UA sent which was negative, 
no further fever workup pursued given pod#1 and has not been 
using IS nor ambulating much.  No pulmonary sx, no urinary sx, 
likely atelectasis and continued to monitor closely.
POD#3 was tachycardic to Tm 101.9 at 3am, tachy to 114, 95%2L 
denied sob/pleuritic chest pain, reported that uses O2 at home 
sometimes, no urinary sx, reports ear pain, no calf pain. 
Incision c/d/i with small area of ecchymosis/erythema.  
Cxr/ua/blood cultures ordered with close monitoring for any 
changes in symptoms and to determine need for further workup 
with PE CT if does not improve given fever/tachy/O2 requirement 
overnight. Also received 1u prbc for drop in hematocrit.
POD#4 Tachycardia improved s/p prbc transfusion, decreased O2 
requirement overnight, afebrile, chest x-ray shows decreased 
lung volume, ua negative. Remained afebrile and asymptomatic 
with no further O2 requirement throughout day, was mildly 
somnolent, but A&Ox3 and easily arousable.  Incision c/d/i with 
___ erythema. Otherwise pain well controlled and no 
acute symptoms 

Otherwise, pain was initially controlled with a PCA followed by 
a transition to oral pain medications on POD#1.  The patient 
received lovenox for DVT prophylaxis starting on the morning of 
POD#1.  The foley was removed on POD#2 and the patient was 
voiding independently thereafter. The surgical dressing was 
changed on POD#2 and the surgical incision was found to be clean 
and intact without erythema or abnormal drainage. The patient 
was seen daily by physical therapy. Labs were checked throughout 
the hospital course and repleted accordingly. At the time of 
discharge the patient was tolerating a regular diet and feeling 
well.  The patient was afebrile with stable vital signs.  The 
patient's hematocrit was acceptable and pain was adequately 
controlled on an oral regimen. The operative extremity was 
neurovascularly intact and the wound was benign. 

The patient's weight-bearing status is weight bearing as 
tolerated on the operative extremity.
 

Ms. ___ is discharged to home with services/rehab in 
stable condition.

Mental Status: Clear and coherent.

Discharge Instructions:
1. Please return to the emergency department or notify your 
physician if you experience any of the following: severe pain 
not relieved by medication, increased swelling, decreased 
sensation, difficulty with movement, fevers greater than 101.5, 
shaking chills, increasing redness or drainage from the incision 
site, chest pain, shortness of breath or any other concerns.
2. Please follow up with your primary physician regarding this 
admission and any new medications and refills. 
3. Resume your home medications unless otherwise instructed.
4. You have been given medications for pain control. Please do 
not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while 
taking these medications. As your pain decreases, take fewer 
tablets and increase the time between doses. This medication can 
cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily 
and take a stool softener (such as colace) as needed to prevent 
this side effect.  Call your surgeons office 3 days before you 
are out of medication so that it can be refilled.  These 
medications cannot be called into your pharmacy and must be 
picked up in the clinic or mailed to your house.  Please allow 
an extra 2 days if you would like your medication mailed to your 
home.
5. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your 
surgeon.
6. Please keep your wounds clean. You may shower starting five 
(5) days after surgery, but no tub baths or swimming for at 
least four (4) weeks. No dressing is needed if wound continues 
to be non-draining. Any stitches or staples that need to be 
removed will be taken out at your follow-up visit in three (3) 
weeks after your surgery.
7. Please call your surgeon's office to schedule or confirm your 
follow-up appointment in three (3) weeks.
8. Please DO NOT take any non-steroidal anti-inflammatory 
medications (NSAIDs such as celebrex, ibuprofen, advil, aleve, 
motrin, etc).
9. ANTICOAGULATION: Please continue your lovenox for four (4) 
weeks to help prevent deep vein thrombosis (blood clots).  If 
you were taking aspirin prior to your surgery, it is OK to 
continue at your previous dose while taking this medication.  
___ STOCKINGS x 6 WEEKS.
10. WOUND CARE: Please keep your incision clean and dry. It is 
okay to shower five days after surgery but no tub baths, 
swimming, or submerging your incision until after your four (4) 
week checkup. Please place a dry sterile dressing on the wound 
each day if there is drainage, otherwise leave it open to air. 
Check wound regularly for signs of infection such as redness or 
thick yellow drainage. Staples will be removed at your follow-up 
visit in three (3) weeks.
11. ___ (once at home): Home ___, dressing changes as 
instructed, and wound checks.
12. ACTIVITY: Weight bearing as tolerated on the operative 
extremity. Mobilize. CPM/ROM as tolerated. No strenuous exercise 
or heavy lifting until follow up appointment.
Physical Therapy:
ACTIVITY: Weight bearing as tolerated on the operative 
extremity. Mobilize. CPM/ROM as tolerated. No strenuous exercise 
or heavy lifting until follow up appointment.
Treatments Frequency:
WOUND CARE: Please keep your incision clean and dry. It is okay 
to shower five days after surgery but no tub baths, swimming, or 
submerging your incision until after your four (4) week checkup. 
Please place a dry sterile dressing on the wound each day if 
there is drainage, otherwise leave it open to air. Check wound 
regularly for signs of infection such as redness or thick yellow 
drainage. Staples will be removed at your follow-up visit in 
three (3) weeks.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ year-old female with a history of multiple 
previous abdominal surgeries who presented this admission with 
abdominal pain and emesis. CT abd/pelvis revealed a small bowel 
obstruction with a transition point in the right lower quadrant 
adjacent to ventral hernia repair mesh.  She was made NPO, had a 
NGT placed to low continuous wall suction and started on IVF.  
On HD1, the patient passed flatus and had minimal NGT output, so 
her NGT was removed. Her admission EKG showed new ST depressions 
in the anterior, left axis and troponins were sent which were 
negative. CXR was unremarkable. 

On HD2, the patient was advanced to a regular diet which was 
well-tolerated. The patient was ordered oxycodone for a 
migraine. The patient was later febrile to 103,  urinalysis, 
urine culture and blood culture were ordered.  There was no 
leukocytosis.  CXR was unremarkable.  

On HD3, the patient reported facial and ear pain and she was 
diagnosed with acute sinusitis.  Given her allergy to 
penicillin, she was started on Azithromycin.  The patient has a 
history of migraines and PO fioricet prn was started. A social 
work consult was placed to address her current housing and 
coping issues. 

On HD4, the patient was again febrile to 103 at night time and 
she received acetaminophen with good effect.  On HD5, the 
patient reported her facial pain had greatly improved, was 
afebrile and reported no abdominal pain.  She had a bowel 
movement and was passing flatus. 

The patient was alert and oriented throughout hospitalization; 
pain was initially managed with po oxycodone and acetaminophen.  
Oxycodone was discontinued as she reported her pain had 
improved. The patient remained stable from a cardiovascular 
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. The patient 
remained stable from a pulmonary standpoint; vital signs were 
routinely monitored. Good pulmonary toilet, early ambulation and 
incentive spirometry were encouraged throughout hospitalization. 
The patient's intake and output were closely monitored.  The 
patient's blood counts were closely watched for signs of 
bleeding, of which there were none. The patient received 
subcutaneous heparin and ___ dyne boots were used during this 
stay and was encouraged to get up and ambulate as early as 
possible.

At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
and hemodynamically stable.  The patient was tolerating a diet, 
ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.  The patient received discharge with the aid of 
___ interpreter services.  Teaching and follow-up 
instructions were discussed with understanding verbalized and 
agreement with the discharge plan. A follow-up appointment was 
scheduled with the patient's Primary Care Provider.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___, 

You were admitted to the hospital with a small bowel 
obstruction. You were managed non-operatively and had a tube 
placed in your nose into your stomach to help decompress your 
abdomen.  Your obstruction resolved on its own and the tube was 
removed.  You are now having bowel function, tolerating a 
regular diet, and your pain is better controlled.  

You were also diagnosed with acute sinusitis, an infection of 
your sinuses which can cause facial pain and fevers.  You were 
started on an antibiotic called Azithromycin and will be 
discharged with a prescription.  

You are now medically cleared to be discharged home to continue 
your recovery.  Please note the following discharge 
instructions: 

Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the 
Emergency Department for any of the following:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.
*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.
*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience a discharge.
*Your pain in not improving within ___ hours or is not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or 
back.

Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.

you.

Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed.

Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times 
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. Avoid lifting 
weights greater than ___ lbs until you follow-up with your 
surgeon.

Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain 
medications.

Brief Hospital Course:
PATIENT SUMMARY
___ year old woman with a PMH DM, HTN, HLD, Asthma, and multiple 
abdominal surgeries after a complicated oophorectomy, who 
presents with 2 weeks worsening epigastric pain and acute kidney 
injury. She was resuscitated with fluids with subsequent 
resolution of ___. Given persistent abdominal pain concerning 
for PUD vs gastritis, she underwent endoscopy on ___ which 
showed patchy erythema. Biopsies were taken, and she was 
discharged with close GI and PCP ___. 

ACUTE ISSUES:
===============
#Abdominal Pain, possible dyspepsia
Patient presented with 2 weeks of epigastric pain, worse with 
meals, unrelieved by PPI therapy. She has a prolonged history of 
abdominal
surgeries following an oophorectomy with subsequent sigmoid 
perforation. On admission, CT showed no evidence SBO or 
pathology at her previous anastomosis. She was empirically 
treated with IV antibiotics over concern for intraabdominal 
infection. However, she remained afebrile with no leukocytosis, 
with overall low concern for infection, so antibiotics were 
stopped upon arrival to the floor. Recal occult blood test was 
negative. Her pain is likely secondary to gastritis vs peptic 
ulcer disease. 

GI was consulted for endoscopy given her history of gastritis 
and failure of a PPI trial. Endoscopy was performed on ___ and 
showed patchy erythema. Biopsies were taken, and patient will 
follow up in GI clinic with Dr. ___ (fellow). Her home 
omeprazole 20 mg PO BID was continued. Dicyclomine was changed 
to four times a day. H. pylori antibody testing was negative.

#Acute kidney injury
Creatinine was 2.3 on admission, likely secondary to pre-renal 
zotemia, ___ to hypovolemia in the setting of poor po intake 
from continued abdominal pain. Her Creatinine was 1.0 on 
discharge. Furosemide was held on admission and at discharge. 
Lisinopril was held on admission and restarted at discharge. 

CHRONIC PROBLEMS
================
# Pancytopenia: Stable throughout admission. 

# HTN: Furosemide was held on admission and at discharge. 
Lisinopril was held on admission and restarted at discharge. 

# HLD: Home simvastatin was continued.

# Chronic back pain: Gabapentin was continued at reduced renal 
dose until resolution of ___. Tylenol and Tramadol were given 
PRN. 

# Asthma:
Home regimen was continued: Fluticasone-Salmeterol Diskus, 
Fluticasone Propionate, Cetirizine and Montelukast.

# Psych: Home regimen was continued: Fluoxetine, Clonazepam, 
Quetiapine

# Diabetes Mellitus: Lantus 20 units in the morning and HISS 
were given in the hospital. Metformin, glipizide and sitagliptin 
were held. She will resume her home regimen. 

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
===================

were stable in the 110s-120s/60s-70s while in hospital.
