Brief Hospital Course:
Patient is a ___ with history of NASH, anemia/thrombocytopenia, 
T2DM, multiple prior abdominal surgeries, GERD/gastritis, 
dyslipidemia, HTN, asthma, depression/anxiety, and migraines who 
presented with occipital pain and swelling found to have 
occiptal scalp cellulitis which progressed to occipital scalp 
abscess.  

ACUTE ISSUES:  
==========================    
#FEVER:
#OCCIPTAL SCALP CELLULITIS:
#OCCIPTAL SCALP ABSCESS 
Patient presented with ___ of worsening occipital scalp
tenderness and swelling, found to have a 3-4cm area consistent 
with cellulitis. Patient was febrile to 102.7 in the ED, 
otherwise was without leukocytosis (neutrophilic predominant, no 
bands). Given signs of possible systemic toxicity (fever, 
borderline BP upon arrival to the floor), continued MRSA in 
addition to strep coverage with vancomycin which was then 
transitioned to cefazolin.  Additionally, due to persistent 
fever on antibiotics as well as neck pain, a CT neck, and torso 
were obtained which showed emerging abcess. Abscess developed 
with purulent discharge. ACS was consulted and she underwent 
I&D. A She did well and antibiotics were narrowed to cephalexin 
to complete ten day course from day of I&D, end date ___. 

#NAUSEA AND ABDOMINAL PAIN:   
Patient has a history of multiple intraabdominal surgeries, 
additional GERD/gastritis (taking meloxicam daily). No BM for 
over 24 hours upon admission. The patient complained of 
worsening abdominal distention with associated nausea/emesis. 
Etiologies considered were bowel obstruction vs. PUD vs. 
evolving gastritis vs. SBP with known history of NASH +/- 
cirrhosis. Of note, patient was admitted ___ with abdominal 
pain and nausea/vomiting, symptoms thought to be related to 
gastritis/PUD. RUQUS without e/o ascites. KUB without evidence 
of ileus or obstruction. The morning that the day team picked up 
the patient, her abdominal exam was significantly improved and 
she only had mild tenderness to palpation. There were no further 
issues with this. 

#ACUTE KIDNEY INJURY:  
Cr was previously ~1, though increased to 1.3 ___ iso ED 
presentation for N/V/D. Suspected prerenal iso GI losses and 
poor PO intake, exacerbated by ongoing ACE-I and furosemide 
administration. No signs of UTI on UA. s/p 3L IVF in ED. Held 
home lisinopril and furosemide. After further IVF and stopping 
vancomycin the patient's ___ resolved. 
  

CHRONIC ISSUES:  
==========================
#THROMBOCYTOPENIA: 
#NORMOCYTIC ANEMIA: 
Chronic, possible related to underlying liver disease (reported 
___, patient was previously referred to the ___ though 
was not evaluated). Hb and plts were stable and at baseline.
 
#HYPERTENSION: 
Borderline BPs upon presentation to the floor.  Held home 
lisinopril, furosemide, clonidine during admission. Upon 
discharge these medications were resumed. 
 
#Type II Diabetes Mellitus (HbA1C 9.4%)  
- Continued home lantus, held home standing short acting 
insulin, and used a sliding scale. Also held metformin and 
sitagliptin.

ACUTE/ACTIVE PROBLEMS:
# Suspected pyelonephritis: 
  Ms. ___ was admitted with dysuria, R flank pain, 
positive urinalysis c/f pyelonephritis.  She was initially 
treated with IV CTX - with good symptomatic improvement.  Urine 
cx grew Ecoli - which was sensitive to cephalosporin.  She was 
placed on PO cefpodoxime (allergic to quinolones) and observed 
overnight.  She continued to do well - and was discharged for 8 
additional days to complete a 10 day course. Pain control with 
Tylenol as needed

# Acute kidney injury: Baseline Cr 1.1, admit Cr 1.9. Likely 
pre-renal azotemia in setting of hyperglycemia with osmotic 
diuresis. After hydration, Cr stabilized to 1.3.  She may 
benefit from ___ in setting of diabetes - to be explored as 
an outpt. 

# DM2 with hyperglycemia: She presented with dizziness, 
polyuria, polydipsia, and hyperglycemia in setting of infection 
as above. Elevated lactate.  Although there was an elevated 
anion gap,   U/A ket neg, betahydroxybutyrate 0.3 making DKA 
unlikely.  Metformin, glipizide were held and restarted on

Discharge Instructions:
Dear ___,

   It was a pleasure looking after you.  As you know, you were 
admitted with dizziness and back pain.  You were found to have a 
urinary tract infection which likely involved your kidney as 
well.  This may partly account for your back pain.   You were 
treated with intravenous antibiotics and switched to oral 
antibiotics once the urine cultures identified the bacteria 
(E.coli) and confirmed its sensitivity to the antibiotic you are 
being prescribed.
   
   Please complete the antibiotics (Cefpodoxime) for an 
additional 8 days to complete a 10 day course.  Otherwise, to 
avoid future urinary tract infection, please ensure that you are 
well hydrated and that your diabetes is in good control.  This 
will prevent future urinary tract infections from happening.  

 You were also found to be dehydrated and with mild acute kidney 
injury.  After hydration, your kidney function improved.  Please 
insure good oral intake of fluids and good control of sugars 
(higher sugars can lead to loss of water). 

 You may have a component of musculoskeletal back pain too.  For 
this, we recommend following with your medical doctor and taking 
acetaminophen (Tylenol) as needed. 

There are otherwise, no changes to your medication.  We wish you 
a quick recovery!

Your ___ team.

Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the acute care surgery service for 
perihepatic/pelvic fluid collections.
 
Please call your doctor or go to the emergency department if:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
*You develop new or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or 
wheeze.
*You are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.
*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons.  Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience an unusual discharge.
*Your pain is not improving within 12 hours or is not under 
control within 24 hours.
*Your pain worsens or changes location.
*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*You develop any concerning symptoms.
 
___ Discharge Instructions:
Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication.  Please take any 
new medications as prescribed.
Please take the prescribed analgesic medications as needed.  You 
may not drive or heavy machinery while taking narcotic analgesic 
medications.  You may also take acetaminophen (Tylenol) as 
directed, but do not exceed 4000 mg in one day.
Please get plenty of rest, continue to walk several times per 
day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids.  Avoid strenuous 
physical activity and refrain from heavy lifting greater than 20 
lbs., until you follow-up with your surgeon, who will instruct 
you further regarding activity restrictions.  Please also 
follow-up with your primary care physician.

narrowing in distal MCAs but without any significant occlusive 
disease. The etiology of this small stroke is likely small 
vessel disease. The patient underwent a stroke workup including 
echocardiogram, toxic/metabolic studies, ___.

panel showed total cholesterol 224, HDL 60, LDL 125 and

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital and brought to the 
operating room on ___ where the patient underwent AVR (25mm 
tissue), MVrepair (32mm ring), and Ascending Aorta Replacement 
(28mm gelweave graft) with Dr. ___.  Overall the patient 
tolerated the procedure well and post-operatively was 
transferred to the CVICU in stable condition for recovery and 
invasive monitoring. POD 1 found the patient extubated, alert 
and oriented and breathing comfortably.  The patient was 
neurologically intact and hemodynamically stable on no inotropic 
or vasopressor support.  Beta blocker was initiated and the 
patient was gently diuresed toward the preoperative weight.  The 
patient was transferred to the telemetry floor for further 
recovery.  Chest tubes and pacing wires were discontinued 
without complication.  Free water was restricted for mild 
hyponatremia, which improved prior to discharge.  He had a brief 
episode of rapid Atrial Fibrillation, which converted to SR with 
IV lopressor and titration of Atenolol. 
The patient complained of nausea and "wretching".  SLP evaluated 
the patient and he passed the swallow study without difficulty.  
The patient was evaluated by the physical therapy service for 
assistance with strength and mobility.  By the time of discharge 
on POD 5 the patient was ambulating freely, the wound was 
healing and pain was controlled with oral analgesics.  The 
patient was discharged to ___ in good condition with 
appropriate follow up instructions.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ s/p recent surgical AVR, MV repair and asending aorta 
replacement discharged on high dose furosemide now admitted with 
hypovolemia, hypotension and afib with RVR not responsive to 
metoprolol, but rate controlled with atenolol and sotalol.

# Paroxysmal Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular 
response: 
High dose Metoprolol 100 mg po TID was ineffective at rate 
control. So was started on atenolol 50 mg po BID and sotalol. 
His QTc stayed 440-470 on sotalol. He had brief episodes of HR 
dropping to the ___ due to concealed PACs. Atenolol was 
decreased to 25 mg po BID.

Patient started on warfarin this admission, received nutrition 
education for warfarin. INR will be followed by Dr. ___.

# Arrythmia: concealed PACs which blocked at AV node and sinus 
giving bradycardia. Dose of atenolol decreased. Pt also had 2.2 
sec run of WCT (6 beats, CL 400ms). No Sx. Will follow with Dr. 
___.

# Hyponatremia: Most likely from daily furosemide use vs 
hypovolemic hyponatremia as improved with IVF and improvement of 
hypotension, but then downtrended slightly with increased dose 
of furosemide.

# Leukocytosis: Noted to have WBC 17K at rehabilitation, which 
continued to downtrend until normal this admission without 
antibiotics. Urine cultures and chest xray as well as blood 
cultures were unrevealing. No diarrhea noted to suggest c. diff. 
Surgical incision without signs of infection.  

# CHF: He was not volume overloaded at admission. In fact, he 
was dehydrated due to increase in dose of diuretics at rehab in 
the week prior to admission. CHF and decline in LV systolic 
function was indication to replace AVR. Dry weight at discharge 
is 157 lbs. Attention to whether he needs diuretic and at what 
dose will be done as outpatient as he resolves ___ space pleural 
fluid in the post-op course. Systolic blood pressures were in 
the ___ this admission, so ACEI or spironolactone were not 
added to regimen.

# Cough: Most likely viral URI with post nasal drip causing 
cough, but also possibly from GERD, atelectasis, or URI. Given 
prolonged sx and constellation of symptoms, did not suspect 
influenza. CXR showed left post surgical pleural effusion and 
bibasilar atelectasis. Patient was afebrile throughout admission 
and leukocytosis resolved without intervention. He was treated 
with benzonatate and guaifenesin cough syrup. 

# Recent cardiac surgery: Wound appeared clean and dry, no sign 
of infection, bypass access sites with healing ecchymosis  as 
well. Cardiac surgery made aware of admission, Mr. ___ has 
outpatient follow up with them. 

# GERD: continued PPI. There was a report of guaiac positive 
brown stool from rehabilitation center when he was not on 
warfarin. CBC was stable, no bloody or melanotic stools 
observed. Stool guiac near end of admission when he was on 
warfarin was negative for occult blood.

# Elevated TSH: ___ sick euthyroid picture gien recent cardiac 
surgery. Will have outpatient follow up after recovery from 
acute illness/recent surgery

# Nutrition: iron supplement

# Anxiety: lorazepam 0.5mg PO daily prn

# Rehab: HE was able to walk 60+ feet on level ground and climb 
1 flight of stairs. He should continue walking and stairs 
exercise at home.

 Prior to her admission at ___, she had been drinking much more

pint of vodka daily. Prior to that, she had been drinking 1 pint 
of vodka daily, ___ days per week. She does not identify any 
inciting factors.  
 She sustained a fall at home, while inebriated, and many 
ecchymoses, with a large R foot hematoma. After 3 days at home, 
her husband urged her to seek medical care; she then presented 
to ___.  
 Per review of the ___ records:  
 - She was initially hypotensive, requiring fluid resuscitation 
(which resulted in anasarca) and pressors. Once she recovered, 
pressors were weaned and home nadolol was restarted. She 
underwent a TTE that showed unchanged moderate pulmonary 
hypertension  
 - Stool was positive for occult blood; no intervention taken, 
given the risk. Transaminases trended up, then down, then back 
up (though trend not available in records).

 - Given fever and elevated transaminases, alcoholic hepatitis 
was considered. ___ DF score = 45. Prednisolone therapy 
not initiated, given concern for adherence upon discharge.  
 - Initial urinalysis was grossly positive. No treatment 
documented, though repeat urinalysis 5 days later showed clean 
urine.  
 - MRCP showed no obstruction  
 - She also had ileus/small bowel obstruction on imaging, with 
diarrhea, which was attributed to pain medication. C. difficle 
PCR was negative.  
 - Hematomas remained stable; she received 12 u pRBC, DDAVP x3, 
as well as transfusions of FFP and vitamin K to lower the INR, 
which was unsuccessful (INR initially elevated to 1.6)  
 - She was noted to be febrile, without leukocytosis; attributed 
to blood product transfusion. She was given clindamycin x48 
hours.  
 - TSH was elevated to 7.3, due to noncompliance. Levothyroxine 
was restarted.  
 - She had waxing/waning periods of visual hallucinations and 
decreased competency. She did attempt to leave AMA at one point, 
so PICC line was removed.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ is a ___ year old woman with alcoholic cirrhosis and 
alcohol abuse who presented to an OSH with a large hematoma 
after sustaining a fall, with anemia, as well as alcoholic 
hepatitis and further decompensation of her liver cirrhosis, is 
transferred to ___ for further care.   
 
#TRAUMATIC HEMATOMAS: patient sustained a large left hematoma on 
her left thigh as well as a deeper small lesion on the right 
foot, per history due to falling while inebriated. Both areas 
were tender to palpation and warm to touch, but there was no 
evidence of increase in size. There was no evidence of deep 
venous thrombosis. Patient was initially followed by the 
Orthopedics team, and then followed by the Plastics team, who 
debrided the right foot and recommended conservative wound care 
management and discharge on a wound vac. There was surrounding 
erythema and pain over the foot lesion, and given its open 
nature, she was initially covered on vancomycin and ceftriaxone, 
especially given fevers noted on ___. Patient did well on IV 
antibiotics with which she remained afebrile with stable vital 
signs, and was transitioned to PO Cephalexin for a 10 day total 
course for presumed soft tissue infection. Patient to follow up 
with outpatient Plastics clinic. 

#SEIZURE: Patient had a reported partially witnessed episode of 
shaking of both upper and lower extremities of unclear etiology 
or trigger. She has a prior history of seizures, and has been on 
Keppra as a home medication although with no recent neurologic 
followup. Her electrolytes were stable, with no recurrence of 
the episode. She was placed on 24 hour EEG monitoring, with 
preliminary results were negative for epileptiform changes, 
showing some minor encephalopathy. Patient's mental status 
remained stable and she was discharged with no new medication 
changes.

#NAUSEA: patient reported continued nausea during the course of 
the hospitalization, infectious workup revealing, with no 
notable new medications. High dose opioids were avoided, and 
symptoms seemed to be from prolonged poor nutrition. Her 
symptoms mildly improved after placement of Doboff tube for 
nutrition. Nausea was controlled with ondansetron and compazine 
as needed. 

#LIVER CIRRHOSIS, WITH CONCERN FOR DECOMPENSATION: MELD-Na on 
admission to ___ 27, was approximately 34 during her course. 
Possible factors inciting decompensation included alcoholic 
hepatitis, infection, anemia (patient had hgb 5.4 on admission 
to OSH and required 12 units pRBCs). Clinical picture on 
admission to OSH appeared consistent with alcoholic hepatitis, 
with a ___ DF score of 45. Corticosteroids were not given, 
and given time course of presentation, further steroids were 
avoided, especially in the setting of concern for infection. 
There was no appreciable ascites on exam or ultrasound with 
prior no history of SBP. She was continued on empiric 
antibiotics as above, was continued on Pantoprazole 40 mg BID. 
Patient was seen by social work for resources for alcohol 
counseling outpatient. 

#HYPONATREMIA: likely from hypovolemia in setting of blood loss 
and also poor oral intake, improved with tube feeds. There were 
no signs of renal function impairment, any hypervolemic state 
such as pulmonary edema or ascites.

# POOR PO Intake: complicated by nausea , suboptimal energy 
currently and need for nutrition given alcohol hepatitis. 
Patient was initiated and discharged on Jevity tube feeds with 
home ___ care.

# ACUTE BLOOD LOSS ANEMIA, ON ANEMIA OF CHRONIC DISEASE: Patient 
with chronic anemia, with initial bleeding from right foot 
hematoma for which she had required transfusion of 12 u pRBC at 
outside hospial. Her iron studies were consistent with liver 
disease/chronic disease. Pantoprazole was continued given 
history of guaic positive stools. Patient does have history of 
grade I varices (last EGD ___. Given stable blood pressures 
and no signs of acute infection, home nadolol was resumed.

#COAGULOPATHY: patient was given vitamin K for her coagulopathy, 
note did have nausea/abdominal pain to IV dosing, to be avoided 
in future care.
 
#THROMBOCYTOPENIA:  Secondary to hepatic cirrhosis, stable. 

CHRONIC ISSUES  
# SEIZURES: continued on home leviteracetam.  
# HYPOTHYROISIDM: continued on home levothyroxine.  
# PERIPHERAL NEUROPATHY: likely related to EtOH abuse, continued 
on home gabapentin.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ y/o woman with a history of alcoholic 
cirrhosis who presented to OSH with chest and flank pain after a 
fall, found to have severe anemia, possible cholangitis, and 
positive blood culture. MRCP at ___ was negative for 
cholangitis. Positive blood culture thought to be contaminant. 
The patient was transfused 2 units pRBCs for her anemia. The 
patient then developed an oxygen requirement to 6L and was found 
to have bibasilar infiltrates concerning for HCAP. She completed 
an 8-day course of vancomycin/cefepime with improvement in her 
oxygen requirement; she was discharged on room air. For her 
alcoholic hepatitis and cirrhosis, she was initiated on steroids 
once her pneumonia was well-controlled. A Dobhoff was placed for 
nutritional support with tube feeds. The patient was started on 
PCP prophylaxis with dapsone. She underwent EGD with 3 cords of 
grade I varices and was initiated on nadolol.

===================
ACTIVE ISSUES:
===================

# Alcoholic hepatitis and cirrhosis: The patient has a history 
of alcoholic cirrhosis. She had been sober for 7 months, but two 
weeks prior to admission she began drinking again. No history of 
complications including hepatic encephalopathy, ascites, or 
variceal bleeding. She presented with a DF of 32 on admission, 
and was given prednisolone 40 mg x1. Prednisone was not 
initially continued due to pending infectious evaluation. 
Patient was subsequently diagnosed with HCAP (see below) and 
treated with 8 days of vancomycin/cefepime. Once her infection 
was well-controlled she was started on prednisone 40 mg on ___ 
for 28 days (taper TBD). She was noted to have improvement in 
Tbili and INR s/p steroid initiation. ___ was placed ___ 
and advanced via ___ ___ for Jevity tube feeds. She was started 
on dapsone for PCP ___ (neg for G6PD deficiency; Bactrim 
allergy). She also underwent EGD that showed 3 cords of grade I 
varices so she was initiated on nadolol. She was continued on 
folate, thiamine, and a multivitamin.

# ___: Patient presented with ___ (creatinine increased to 2.0) 
in setting of acute illness, likely initially pre-renal and 
subsequently secondary to possible overdiuresis in setting of 
hypoxia (below). Given albumin 1 mg/kg x 2 days without 
significant improvement. Subsequently diuresed due to concern 
for volume overload. Creatinine improved after diuretics were 
discontinued. Creatinine back to 1.0 at discharge (baseline).

# HCAP: Patient with worsening hypoxia to 6L and found to have 
bibasilar infiltrates on CXR. Initially thought to be component 
of volume overload secondary to albumin challenge for ___ as 
above, so patient diuresed with Lasix IV 20 mg. She completed 
8-days of vancomycin/cefepime with improvement in her 
respiratory status. Discharged on RA.

# Hyponatremia: Admitted with hyponatremia to 124 in setting of 
decompensation and infection. Resolved to 134 on discharge.

# CoNS bacteremia: Noted on 1 set of blood cultures at ___ 
___ to grow CoNS, believed to be contaminant. However, 
patient arrived to ___ febrile and tachycardic and therefore 
started on vancomycin. Patient was continued on vancomycin for 
HCAP treatment as above.

# Anemia: Patient presented from OSH with Hgb 6.2 and had 
appropriate increase in hemoglobin after 2 units pRBCs. There 
was no evidence of a GIB but she did report menorrhagia, which 
resolved.

Brief Hospital Course:

colitis now presenting with ___.  

ACTIVE ISSUES
==============
# ___
Patient was recently admitted with infectious colitis and had 
normal renal function at that time.  She returned with ___ (Cr 
3.5) which was ultimately thought to be pre-renal in nature 
given her history of vomiting/poor PO intake and downtrending Cr 
with IVF.  On the day of discharge, her cr had downtrended to 
1.5.  Given that she has a history of hepatitic C, cryoglobulins 
were checked and were pending at the time of discharge, and 
subsequently returned negative. RF, checked as a marker for 
cryoglobulinemia, was WNL. Given significant improvement of Cr 
with hydration as well as resolution of nausea, vomiting, and 
diarrhea, pt was discharged with plans for Cr recheck within 5 
days of discharge. Hospital course and transitional issues 
including Cr f/u were discussed directly with covering PCP by 
telephone on the day of discharge.

# Nausea
Patient was admitted with complaint of two days of nausea with 
one episode of non-blood emesis.  Patient was given IV zofran 
and nausea/vomiting resolved over the course of her stay.  Given 
patient's report of leg weakness, her acute episode of 
hypertension, her past history of seizures and hyponatremia, as 
well as her intermittent nausea/vomiting/abdominal pain, if 
patient experiences another acute episode, testing for acute 
intermittent porphyria could be considered in outpatient 
setting.

# Black stools
Patient reported having "black stools" over the 24-hours prior 
to admission.  Hct upon admission was stable and HR was not 
elevated to suggest acute blood loss. She denied taking any iron 
or supplements which would turn her stool black. On discharge, 
patient reported that her stools were more formed compared to 
prior to admission, and were of normal brown color.  

# Elevated blood pressures
During prior admission, patient had elevated BPs to the 
systolics of 170s, she was asymptomatic at the time.  She was 
started on amlodipine 5mg PO daily but this was discontinued at 
her PCP appointment two days prior to admission given 
normotensive readings.  Upon admission patient's blood pressure 
was elevated to SBP 185 and she was reinitiated on amlodipine.  
On the day of discharge, patient was once again normotensive and 
amlodipine was discontinued. Markedly elevated BPs were likely 
associated with ___. She will followup with her PCP as an 
outpatient for further blood pressure monitoring.

================
#  Hyperthyroidism: Continued home dose propylthiouracil 
#  Hepatitis C c/b hepatocellular carcinoma: Thrombocytopenia 
and transaminitis at baseline.

Brief Hospital Course:
BRIEF HOSPITAL SUMMARY
=====================
Ms. ___ is a ___ woman with history of HCV s/p Harvoni c/b 
Childs A cirrhosis, history of prior hepatic lesion that 
spontaneously regressed on serial imaging, hyperthyroidism, and 
osteopenia who was transferred from ___ for continuity of care 
and biopsy. She initially presented to ___ with abdominal 
pain, nausea, and vomiting, where imaging showed a ~5cm liver 
lesion. She was then transferred to ___ where she had 
unsuccessful biopsy attempt, and therefore transferred to ___ for 
further workup and to see her regular providers. On arrival her 
symptoms had resolved. Radiology reread her images and 
recommended EUS-guided biopsy, lymphoma protocol (results 
pending). She had persistent hypertension after the biopsy that 
improved with medications. She also had tachycardia with 
exertion that improved with bolus of IVF. She was discharged 
with close follow up. 

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES
=================
[ ] We recommend the PCP follow up on the biopsy results. The 
oncology team here will also call the patient to schedule follow 
up when the biopsy results. 
[ ] Follow up on plasma metanephrine level and consider 24-hour 
urine metanephrine for further workup of possible 
pheochromocytoma if her symptoms persists
[ ] Will need EGD as follow up for cirrhosis management of 
variceal monitoring
[ ] If ___ has persistently poor appetite, consider starting 
mirtazapine QHS for appetite stimulation
[ ] Please titrate blood pressure medications as needed. 

# CONTACT: ___, Daughter, ___

MEDICATION CHANGES
==================
Increased lisinopril from 5mg daily to 20mg daily 
Started amlodipine 7.5mg daily for hypertension
Started marinol 2.5mg BID for appetite stimulation
Prescribing Zofran ODT for PRN use 

ACUTE ISSUES
===========
# Liver lesion with extension into portal vein 
At ___, CT torso showed heterogenous liver mass with invasion 
into the portal vein. An MRI showed a heterogenously enhancing 
mass predominantly intravascular in the main portal vein. ___ was 
unable to do the biopsy due to the location. GI was unable to 
collect tissue via EUS. Their plan was to consult surgical 
oncology for biopsy but after discussion with Dr. ___ was 
transferred to ___ for continuity of care. On arrival she 
reported her pain, nausea, and vomiting had resolved. CDs were 
obtained from ___ and ___ radiologists reread the films and 
recommended EUS. The ERCP fellow did a biopsy (results pending). 
___ had nausea and vomiting after the procedure that resolved 
with Zofran. 

# Hypertension
Well controlled on presentation. She reports she was recently 
diagnosed with hypertension but upon review of her atria's 
records it appears that she has been hypertensive in the clinic 
for several years and has declined antihypertensive medications. 
SBP 200s after procedure likely secondary to nausea, vomiting, 
and pain. However, hypertension persisted despite uptitration of 
medications. Workup for pheochromocytoma was initiated with 
plasma metanephrines because patient reported recent episodes of 
sweating. She was discharged on higher dose of lisinopril and 
amlodipine. 

# Tachycardia
#Orthostasis
Intermittent tachycardia after the biopsy worse with activity, 
not sustaining. Likely volume depleted in the setting of poor PO 
intake. We bolused her with fluids which improved her 
orthostasis.

# Nausea/Vomiting
Nausea and vomiting after biopsy likely secondary to MAC during 
the procedure. Resolved with zofran. 

# Anorexia
Patient reported poor appetite for several weeks, perhaps 
secondary to malignancy. We started marinol and nutrition was 
consulted who felt she met criteria for severe malnutrition. 

CHRONIC ISSUES
=============
# Cirrhosis
No evidence of decompensation. Childs A. 

# Osteoporosis
Continued home alendronate

# Hyperthyroidism
Continued home PTU

# Choledocholithiasis with biliary obstruction: Patient 
presented
with abdominal pain, found to have gallstone pancreatitis and
choledocholithiasis with biliary obstruction, now improving. 
Evaluated by ERCP team, and underwent EUS, which found no stone 
in CBD.  Therefore an ERCP was not pursued.  Tbili peaked at 
2.5, and was trended during hospital course. It decreased on a 
daily basis.  Transplant service was consulted, and they were 
not keen on doing a CCY until patient's MELD score was low 
enough. MRCP showed no choledocholithiasis, but Cholelithiasis.  
In the future, she will likely need a cholecystectomy.  
Initially needed pain control with Tylenol (max daily dose 
2grams), oxycodone as
needed, but on final three days of admission, was totally pain 
free and eating a regular diet.

antibiotics to control your infection, and insulin for your

Brief Hospital Course:
BRIEF SUMMARY STATEMENT:
=============================
___ w/ Afib, seizure disorder, systolic CHF, and dementia, who 
presented with altered mental status, had a cardiac arrest in 
the ED, and was admitted to the ICU for post-arrest management. 
Course was complicated by UTI and acute renal failure, and she 
improved with fluids and antibiotics. Code status changed to 
DNR/DNI. 

ACTIVE ISSUES:
=============================
# CARDIAC ARREST: Patient had transient episode of asystole in 
the ED after getting calcium gluconate/insulin/dextrose for 
hyperkalemia. ROSC achieved after brief (around 10 seconds) of 
chest compressions. Unclear precipitant but concerning 
elevations in aVR and depressions in lateral leads on EKG. 
Cardiac enzymes reassuringly negative. Long pause vs asystole 
potentially from calcium gluconate infusion in the setting of 
elevated dig level. Patient w/ known CAD and documented stents 
in RCA territory. EKG changes potentially demand in the setting 
of being hyperdynamic due to hypovolemia and infected. She was 
closely monitored on telemetry, and remained hemodynamically 
stable throughout rest of hospitalization. 

# URINARY TRACT INFECTION: Patient presented w/o documented 
fevers but with leukocytosis w/ neutrophilic predominance and UA 
suggestive of infection. CXR w/o acute process. LFTs wnl. No 
imaging evidence of pyelonephritis. Chronic ulcers to coccyx and 
___ as potential sources of infection.  New G-tube oozing at 
site, cultured- growing ___ albicans. IP adjusted 
bumper. Afebrile. She was thought to have a UTI, and was started 
initially on Vanc/Zosyn, and Vanc was stopped on ___. 
Vancomycin should continue for 7day course, to end on ___. 

# ___: Patient presented w/ Cr elevated to 4.3 and BUN 123 w/ 
anion gap metabolic acidosis and several electrolyte 
abnormalities including K of 7.3 prior to treatment. Initially 
oliguric.  UA c/w UTI and reportedly from daughter has been 
hospitalized from sepsis w/ urinary origin in the recent past 
resulting in some degree of chronic kidney damage. Electrolytes 
and kidney function improved with fluid resuscitation and 
pressors. Renal US without evidence of obstruction. K now 
normalized. At discharge, Cr was 0.9.
 
CHRONIC ISSUES: 
=============================
# HISTORY OF SEIZURES: Patient w/ baseline dementia but 
reportedly able to participate in conversations w/ family. About 
___ hours of noted increasing lethargy at her facility. NCHCT 
reassuringly w/o acute intracranial abnormality and non-focal 
neuro exam. She has multiple sources of potential toxic 
metabolic encephalopathy due to her presumed infection and acute 
renal failure. EEG with significant posterior predominant 
epileptiform discharges and triphasics. Improved with addition 
of phenytoin, which was discontinued prior to discharge. At 
discharge, she was stable on Keppra 1000mg POBID.

# Atrial fibrillation: Initially required levophed and was 
tachycardic to 110s on this. Rates have been in ___ off

was stopped. Her Metoprolol was also stopped due to soft blood 
pressures

Brief Hospital Course:
1. LEGAL & SAFETY:  
On admission, the patient signed a conditional voluntary 
agreement (Section 10 & 11) and remained on that level 
throughout her admission. She was also placed on 15 minute 
checks, our lowest checks status, and remained on that level of 
observation throughout her stay, while being unit-restricted.  

2. PSYCHIATRIC:
#) Major depressive disorder: 
On arrival to the unit, patient was tearful and endorsed 
"depressed" mood with labile affect. She did state that she was 
having suicidal thoughts about the "world being better off 
without me" before getting into the ___ water, and that then 
the tide swept her away. Stated that she was very happy to have 
survived, but that she was struggling with guilt surrounding 
hurting her husband and child. Also expressed remorse 
surrounding the idea of losing custody of her child. She was 
accepting of care, and able to contract for safety while on the 
unit. Denied any acute suicidal ideation, intent, or plan. 
Stated that in the past the medication that had worked the best 
for her was Prozac. She was maintained on trazodone 50mg PO QHS 
for sleep.
During her stay, her home Paxil was downtitrated and Prozac was 
started and uptitrated. She was increased to Prozac 20mg PO QD. 
Additionally, she was started on Depakote for possible 
hypomania. She was increased to Depakote 500 mg QHS. She 
reported improvement in mood, as well as increased ability to 
cope with her circumstances. Patient and her family were very 
pleased and relieved to have a diagnosis of bipolar II disorder 
as they strongly believe her past problematic behavior is 
accurately explained by this condition. At the time of 
discharge, ___ was attending groups, was interactive in 
the milieu, and was able to participate in individual therapy. 

On discharge, patient reports "better" mood, has euthymic 
affect, and denies any suicidal thought, intent, or plan. She is 
future-oriented, with plan to attend intensive outpatient 
program and live at her parents' house before trying to go back 
to work. She will be discharged to home on Prozac 20 mg PO QD, 
trazodone 50mg PO QHs and Depakote 500 mg QHS.

3. SUBSTANCE USE DISORDERS:
#)Alcohol use disorder: 
Patient arrived to the ED with BAL 285, reported that she drank 
a pint of vodka prior to going into the ___. She was kept on a 
CIWA scale for withdrawal while on the inpatient unit, though 
she did not score. She reports a history of binge drinking, and 
states that she attended AA meetings a few times in the past, 
though not recently. She did attend AA and Smart Recovery while 
here on the unit. Was referred to both outpatient, and states 
that she plans to attend.

4. MEDICAL
#) Anion gap acidosis: Patient arrived to the ___ with an 
anion gap acidosis on serum testing, likely in setting of recent 
alcohol use. This resolved with conservative management in the 
ED. 

#) Hypothyroidism: Patient with TSH of 6.1 on admission to the 
inpatient unit. Her home Synthroid was increased to 50mcg PO QD. 
It is possible that hypothyroidism could have contributed in 
part to her mood episode.

5. PSYCHOSOCIAL
#) GROUPS/MILIEU:  
The patient was encouraged to participate in the various groups 
and milieu therapy opportunities offered by the unit.  The 
patients primary team met with her daily and various 
psychotherapeutic modalities were utilized during those times. 
She was increasingly able to engage in groups and therapy during 
her stay, as her mood and emotional lability improved. 

#) COLLATERAL CONTACTS & FAMILY INVOLVEMENT
A family meeting was held with the patient's mother, ___ 
___. The patient reported not wanting to be a part of 
this meeting, as she felt that it would agitate her further. 

#) INTERVENTIONS
- Medications: Prozac
- Psychotherapeutic Interventions: Individual, group, and milieu 
therapy.
- Coordination of aftercare: Intensive outpatient program

INFORMED CONSENT: The team discussed the indications for, 
intended benefits of, and possible side effects and risks of 
starting this medication, and risks and benefits of possible 
alternatives, including not taking the medication, with this 
patient.   We discussed the patient's right to decide whether to 
take this medication as well as the importance of the patient's 
actively participating in the treatment and discussing any  
questions about medications with the treatment team, and I  
answered the patient's questions.  The patient appeared able to 
understand and consented to begin the medication.

RISK ASSESSMENT
On presentation, the patient was evaluated and felt to be at an 
increased risk of harm to herself and/or others based upon 
attempted suicide attempt by drowning in the ___. 
Their static factors noted at that time include history of 
suicide attempts, chronic mental illness, history of substance 
abuse, Caucasian race, age, marital status.  She also had 
several modifiable risk factors addressed at that time, 
including disorganized and unpredictable behavior, hopelessness, 
agitation, recklessness, social withdrawal, limited coping 
skills, no established outpatient treatment, and active 
substance abuse. We addressed these risk factors by restarting 
her on Prozac, holding a family meeting, and connecting her with 
outpatient treaters and an intensive outpatient program. 
Finally, the patient is being discharged with many protective 
risk factors, including help-seeking nature, future-oriented 
viewpoint, sense of responsibility to family, lack of suicidal 
ideation, and family support. Overall, based on the totality of 
our assessment at this time, the patient is not at an acutely 
elevated risk of self-harm nor danger to others. Our prognosis 
of this patient is fair, given the above.

FINDINGS:

NON-CONTRAST HEAD CT: ACom aneurysm clip with associated 
metallic artifact is noted. Again seen is a hypoattenuating area 
within the right temporal and inferior frontal lobe consistent 
with evolving infarct. There is also expanding and increasingly 
conspicuous hypoattenuation within the right basal caudate, 
putamen, and internal capsule consistent with new/progressive 
infarction of this region. High-density right extra-axial fluid 
collection with small locules of air is unchanged measuring 13 
mm in greatest diameter. There is slightly increased mass effect 
on the subjacent sulci and increasing transtentorial and 
subfalcine herniation with leftward midline shift of 8 mm, 
previously 7 mm. Left ventriculostomy catheter terminates within 
the left lateral ventricle at the midline and the ventricles are 
stable in size. There is worsening effacement of the suprasellar 
and ambient cisterns consistent with increasing mass effect. The 
13-mm subgaleal fluid collection overlying the right frontal 
craniotomy is stable.

CTA OF THE HEAD: The cervical portions of the carotid arteries, 
vertebral arteries, and basilar artery are patent. There is 
improved opacification in the circle of ___ and its major 
branches. Specifically, there is marked improvement of vasospasm 
involving the distal right M1 and right M2 segments of the MCA. 
There is improvement in vasospasm of the A1 segments bilaterally 
(right greater than left) though the right A1 segment still 
shows moderate vasospasm. The A2 segments bilaterally also 
demonstrate markedly improved caliber. The left MCA and its 
branches are unremarkable. The bilateral PCA arteries are also 
unremarkable.

CT PERFUSION: There is patchy perfusion abnormality with 
decreased blood volume in the bilateral temporal lobes and also 
right frontal lobe, which likely relate to vasospasm.

IMPRESSION:

1. New/progressive infarction within the right basal ganglia.

2. Increasing mass effect and transtentorial herniation with 
worsening effacement of the suprasellar and ambient cisterns.

3. Improving vasospasm within the right MCA, and bilateral A1 
and A2 segments of the ACA. There is, however, persistent 
moderate vasospasm within the A1 segments, in close proximty to 
the ACOM aneurysm clip.

FELLOW: Dr. ___.

Dr. ___ attending interventional neuroradiologist, was 
present and supervised throughout the procedure.

INDICATION: ___ female status post surgical clipping of 
an anterior communicating artery aneurysm, now post-operative 
day number seven. Rule out vasospasm.

COMPARISON: ___.

TECHNIQUE: Written informed consent was obtained from the 
patient's daughter after discussing the indications for the 
procedure, the risks of the procedure, and the alternative 
management. The discussed risks include stroke, loss of vision 
and/or speech which may be temporary or permanent, with possible 
treatment with stents and/or coils if needed. Additionally the 
indications, risks, and alternative management for possible 
intervention was explained.

The patient was brought to the interventional neuroradiology 
suite and placed on the biplane table in the supine position. 
Both groins were prepped and draped in the usual sterile 
fashion. A pre-procedure timeout was performed using two patient 
identifiers and verifying the procedure to be performed.

Access to the right common femoral artery was obtained using a 
19-gauge single-wall needle with 1% lidocaine mixed with sodium 
bicarbonate for local anesthetic. A 0.35 ___ wire was 
introduced through the needle, and the needle was removed. A 5 
___ vascular sheath was placed over the wire and connected to 
a saline infusion (mixed with heparin 500 units in 500 cc of 
saline) with a continuous drip. Through the sheath, a 4 ___ 
___ catheter was introduced and connected to a continuous 
saline infusion (mixed with heparin 1000 units in 1000 cc of 
saline). The following vessels were selectively catheterized, 
and arteriograms were performed from the following locations: 
Right common carotid artery, right internal carotid artery, left 
vertebral artery, left common carotid artery, and left internal 
carotid artery. After review of the study, the catheter and the 
sheath were withdrawn. Hemostasis was achieved using manual 
compression. The patient tolerated the procedure well without 
any immediate post-procedure complications.

FINDINGS:

RIGHT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY: The bifurcation is normal. There is 
no evidence of a vascular malformation.

RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY: The cervical, petrous, cavernous, 
and supraclinoid segments of the internal carotid artery are 
normal. There is a surgical clip identified in the region of the 
anterior communicating artery with no residual aneurysm 
identified. There is mild stenosis of the M1 segment of the 
middle cerebral artery and moderate stenosis of the M2 middle 
cerebral artery branches. Additionally there is moderate 
stenosis of the A1 segment of the anterior cerebral artery with 
a focus of luminal irregularity in its proximal portion. There 
is decreased parenchymal phase blood flow identified within the 
right anterior watershed vascular distribution.

At this point, the decision was made for an intervention. 5 mg 
of verapamil was gently infused selectively into the right 
internal carotid artery over 1 minute. A right internal carotid 
artery angiogram was then repeated at approximately 10 minutes 
after the infusion of verapamil which demonstrated residual 
mild-to-moderate narrowing of the right A1 segment of the 
anterior cerebral artery, and right M1 and M2 segments of the 
middle cerebral artery.

LEFT VERTEBRAL ARTERY: The left vertebral artery and the left 
posterior inferior cerebellar artery appear unremarkable. There 
is no reflux identified into the right vertebral artery. The 
basilar artery appears unremarkable.

5 mg of verapamil was gently infused selectively into the left 
vertebral artery over ___AROTID ARTERY: The bifurcation is normal. There is 
no vascular malformation.

LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY: The cervical, petrous, cavernous, 
and supraclinoid segments of the left internal carotid artery 
are normal. There is mild narrowing of the A1 segment of the 
left anterior cerebral artery. The left middle cerebral artery 
as well as its major branches appear unremarkable. A surgical 
clip is identified in the region of the anterior communicating 
artery with no residual aneurysm seen.

5 mg of verapamil was gently infused selectively into the left 
internal carotid artery over 1 minute. A post-infusion angiogram 
the left internal carotid artery demonstrates mild narrowing of 
the A1 segment of the anterior cerebral artery.

MODERATE SEDATION: 100 mcg of intravenous Fentanyl and 4 mg of 
intravenous Versed were administered in divided doses by a 
registered nurse, who was monitoring the patient throughout the 
2 hour and 15 minute intraservice time. Please refer to the 
nursing record for further detail.

IMPRESSION:
1. Status post surgical clipping of an anterior communicating 
aneurysm with no residual aneurysm identified.

2. Moderate narrowing of the right M1 and M2 segments of the 
middle cerebral artery and right A1 anterior cerebral artery, 
and mild narrowing of the left A1 segment of the anterior 
cerebral artery consistent with vasospasm. 5 mg of verapamil was 
selectively infused into the right internal carotid, left 
vertebral, and left internal carotid arteries for a total of 15 
mg of verapamil. Post- infusion angiogram demonstrated residual 
mild-to- moderate narrowing of the right M1 and M2 segments of 
the middle cerebral artery and right A1 segment of the anterior 
cerebral artery and residual mild narrowing of the A1 segment of 
the anterior cerebral artery.

Discharge Instructions:
DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS FOR CRANIOTOMY/HEAD INJURY

Have a family member check your incision daily for signs of 
infection
Take your pain medicine as prescribed
Exercise should be limited to walking; no lifting, straining, 
excessive bending
You may wash your hair only after sutures and/or staples have 
been removed 
You may shower before this time with assistance and use of a 
shower cap
Increase your intake of fluids and fiber as pain medicine 
(narcotics) can cause constipation
Unless directed by your doctor, do not take any 
anti-inflammatory medicines such as Motrin, aspirin, Advil, 
Ibuprofen etc. 
If you have been prescribed an anti-seizure medicine, take it 
as prescribed and follow up with laboratory blood drawing as 
ordered
- clearance to drive will be discussed at your post 
hospitalization office visit.

CALL YOUR SURGEON IMMEDIATELY IF YOU EXPERIENCE ANY OF THE 
FOLLOWING:

New onset of tremors or seizures
Any confusion or change in mental status 
Any numbness, tingling, weakness in your extremities
Pain or headache that is continually increasing or not 
relieved by pain medication
Any signs of infection at the wound site: redness, swelling, 
tenderness, drainage
Fever greater than or equal to 101 F

It was a pleasure looking after you, Ms. ___.  As you know, 
you underwent an ERCP here to retrieve the wire basket stuck in 
the common bile duct.  You tolerated the ERCP here well: the 
wire was removed along with the stones within the common bile 
duct.  A bile duct stent was also placed to ensure adequate 
passage of biliary stones.   
   Please complete 5 days of ciprofloxacin and flagyl 
(antibiotics) to treat the infection within the bile duct.  
Thereafter, you can start the other antibiotics (prilosec, 
amoxicillin, clarithromycin) to treat H.Pylori.  Since treatment 
of H.Pylori is not urgent, you may elect to delay the H.Pylori 
treatment until there is enough time to recover from the 
cholangitis and ensure that you are not infected with C.diff.  
We will contact you with the stool Cdiff results. 
   You will be contacted by our ERCP department to schedule a 
follow up ERCP to remove the stent.

___ year old female with DMII, HTN, HLD, history of ICH w/ 
residual R-sided blindness and a recent stress MIBI suggestive 
of a small area of decrease perfusion that reversed with rest 
presented from her PCPs office with chest pain concerning for a 
coronary etiology.

ACTIVE PROBLEMS
================
# Chest Pain
The patient presented with chest pain that she described as 
"pressure" in her neck. Given concern for coronary artery 
disease, troponins were checked (negative x3) and EKGs were 
obtained (no acute ischemic changes). A more robust history was 
elicited, which suggested that she feels this chest pain 
intermittently (no daily but several times per week) and has not 
noted any correlation with rest or exercise. She takes her 
sublingual nitroglycerin when she is feeling pain, which helps 
sometimes but not always. She also recalls some events that were 
relieved with rest and some that lasted for several hours. Based 
on this, it remains unclear if her chest pain is coronary in 
origin. She also had an echocardiogram that was unremarkable. 
Given the negative objective work up and the very questionable 
history of her chest pain, cardiac catheterization was deferred 
at this time. Her metoprolol succinate and lisinopril were 
continued, and she was started on 81mg aspirin daily (after 
consultation with neurosurgery). Consideration was made to 
initiate nitrate therapy, however he blood pressures remained 
too soft. This can be further considered in the outpatient 
setting.

CHRONIC/STABLE PROBLEMS
========================
# DMII - held metformin while inpatient and initiated Humalog 
sliding scale

# HTN - held HCTZ in favor of lisinopril and metoprolol

# HLD - continued atorvastatin

# Anxiety - continued Wellbutrin 100mg BID

PATHOLOGY:
======================

___ LYMPH NODE BIOPSY
SPECIMEN: LYMPH NODE, RIGHT AXILLARY, CORE NEEDLE BIOPSY.
DIAGNOSIS:
HIGH GRADE B-CELL LYMPHOMA, NOS, WITH IGH/BCL2 REARRANGEMENT. 
SEE NOTE.
Note: Sections of a core lymph node biopsy show three distinct 
areas comprising roughly a third of the core biopsy each. One 
zone shows a lymphoid proliferation composed almost entirely of 
medium size and large lymphocytes with irregularly shaped 
nuclei, blastic chromatin, small amounts of cytoplasm and 
inconspicuous nucleoli. Frequent mitoses, including atypical 
mitoses and apoptotic cells are seen. The second zone shows a 
proliferation of smaller lymphocytes with round nuclei, blastic 
chromatin and inconspicuous nucleoli in a background of loose 
connective tissue. Yet a third zone shows complete coagulative 
necrosis. By immunohistochemistry, CD20 highlights B-cells 
occupying the vast majority of the viable tissue. CD3 and CD5 
highlights scattered interspersed T-cells and few dense large 
aggregates. CD10 is variably positive, it stain the lymphocytes 
in the zone containing medium and large cells, but not the one 
primarily made up of small lymphocytes. MUM is variably positive 
and BCL6 is diffusely positive. BCL2 is immunoreactive in all 
lymphocytes. CD21 highlights scattered background follicular 
dendritic cell meshwork remnants. CD23 and BCL1 are negative. By 
Ki67 (MIB1) staining, the proliferation index is variable, with 
the zone of larger cells showing 90-100% staining, and 70-80% in 
the zone dominated by small blastic lymphocytes. Immunostains 
for CMYC shows staining in an average of 20% of cells.
FISH: POSITIVE for IGH/BCL2 and GAIN of MYC. Approximately 50% 
of the interphase right
axillary lymph node cells examined in this high grade lymphoma 
FISH panel had probe signal
patterns consistent with ___ extra intact copies of MYC and the 
IGH/BCL2 gene rearrangement
characteristic of follicular lymphoma and diffuse large B-cell 
lymphoma of germinal center origin.
There was no evidence of rearrangements of the BCL6 and MYC 
genes.

___ IMMUNOPHENOTYPING
INTERPRETATION 
Nondiagnostic study. Cell marker analysis was performed, but was 
nondiagnostic in this case due to insufficient numbers of 
cells/insufficient amount of tissue for analysis. Clonality 
could not be assessed in this case due to insufficient numbers 
of B cells. If clinically indicated, we recommend a repeat 
specimen be submitted to the flow cytometry laboratory. 
Correlation with clinical, morphologic (see separate pathology 
report ___-___) and other ancillary (see separate cytogenetics 
report ___-___) findings is recommended. Flow cytometry 
immunophenotyping may not detect all abnormal populations due to 
topography, sampling or artifacts of sample preparation.

___ PLEURAL FLUID
Nonspecific T cell predominant lymphoid profile; diagnostic 
immunophenotypic features of involvement by leukemia/lymphoma 
are not seen in this specimen. Correlation with clinical, 
morphologic (see separate pathology report ___-___) and other 
ancillary (see separate cytogenetics report ___) findings 
is recommended. Flow cytometry immunophenotyping may not detect 
all abnormal populations due to topography, sampling or 
artifacts of sample preparation.

___ IMMUNOTYPING

cells/insufficient amount of tissue for analysis. Clonality

Correlation with clinical and other ancillary (see separate

Patient found to have large left effusion on CT after CXR for 
PICC placement demonstrated effusion. He underwent chest tube 
placement on ___ which drained 1L fluid and was subsequently 
removed on ___. Pleural fluids studies were exudative effusion, 
cytology negative for malignant cells however FISH positive 
suggestive of disease involvement. Pleural fluid cx negative. 
Additionally, he had significant wheezing on exam though no 
documented history of COPD. He underwent PFTs ___ notable for 
FEV1/FVC ratio 69% consistent with COPD. He was started on daily 
tiotropium and scheduled duonebs. He continued to have 
productive cough with crackles and rhonchi on exam. He had CT 
chest ___ showing pulmonary congestion that improved with 
diuresis. Repeat CT chest ___ showed continued congestion and 
nonspecific opacities, and he was started on metronidazole for 
possible aspiration pneumonia and completed a coarse from 
___. He was discharged on advair and tiotropium for his 
COPD. He should follow up with his PCP for further evaluation, 
consideration of referral to a pulmonologist.

Per pt, most recent stent ___ year ago. Cardiology was consulted 
for cardio-onc evaluation given plan for chemo regimen with 
anthracyclines as above. Baseline TTE was obtained which 
demonstrated normal EF. He will require repeat echo within ___ 
months after the completion of anthracyclines and outpatient 
follow-up with Dr. ___ in cardio-oncology. Additionally, his 
home metoprolol was transitioned to carvedilol for

vascular medicine, and vascular surgery. Per vascular surgery 
there was no indication from their standpoint for antiplatelet 
agent. Plavix was held in setting of thrombocytopenia. There was 
plan to begin aspirin, which was initially held given multiple 
procedures (LP, port replacement). He was asymptomatic and blood 
pressure remained controlled BP 110-120/60-70 until discharge. 
His aspirin and Plavix were held at discharge given he will be 
receiving further chemotherapy, with plan to rediscuss starting 
them as outpatient.

# UTI: Urine was cultured in setting of fever that grew 
vancomycin-resistant enterococcus. He was started on daptomycin 
given risk of serotonin syndrome with linezolid and home 
amitriptyline. He completed a 7-day course of daptomycin from 
___.

# Left vocal cord paralysis
# Aspiration risk: He presented with a hoarse voice; no 
respiratory symptoms aside from coughing. He was evaluated by 
ENT which found left vocal cord paralysis in the setting of 
hilar and mediastinal adenopathy and soft tissue encasing the 
trachea. A video swallow was performed and showed aspiration 
with thin and nectar thick liquids. He was kept on thick liquids 
using a straw with chin tuck. He was recommended to follow-up 
with ENT as an outpatient for vocal cord injection. Repeat video 
swallow was unchanged from prior. After goals of care discussion 
with patient and his wife, he was discharged home with an 
understanding of aspiration risk. He should follow up with ENT 
for further management. 

# Tremors: He was noted to have bilateral upper extremity 
tremors at rest and with movement. There was no evidence of 
withdrawal, hyperthyroidism, or focal neurologic deficits. It 
has been chronic for several months and continues to be 
nonfocal. Likely to be drug-induced (steroids) or functional or 
Parkinsonian. The tremors remained stable through discharge.

# Maculopapular rash:
He developed a nontender, non-pruritic, blanching maculopapular 
erythematous rash across his back and flanks. The rash was 
consistent with neutrophilic eccrine hidradenitis related to his 
chemotherapy medication. He was evaluated by Dermatology and no 
treatment was indicated given the rash was asymptomatic. His 
rash remained stable throughout his hospital stay.

# Transaminitis:
He developed transaminitis while in house. It was felt to be 
most likely secondary to chemotherapy. RUQUS w/ Doppler 
unremarkable. HBV, HCV serologies were negative on admission. 
EBV/CMV viral load and serologies were negative. His 
allopurinol, home statin, and Tylenol were held in the setting 
of transaminitis. His liver function tests returned to normal at 
discharge.

# RUE PICC-associated DVT:
He was found to have a RUE PICC associated DVT, of which the 
PICC was subsequently removed. LENIS with question of chronic 
non-occlusive thrombus within popliteal vein. This was discussed 
with vascular medicine and there was initially a plan to 
reimage, however he was subsequently started on enoxaparin for 
the RUE DVT. Repeat RUE ultrasound and LENIS several weeks later 
showed no evidence of clot. Given no indication for 
anticoagulation, his enoxaparin was discontinued.

# ___ on CKD III
Cr 3.1 on presentation. Baseline Cr unknown, most recently 2.3 
in ___. Suspect pre-renal in the setting of hypercalcemia. 
Renal US was obtained which was unremarkable. Cr subsequently 
improved to 2.1 with IVF. His medications were renally dosed.

12%. B12, folate wnl. Retic index c/w hypoproliferation. He 
received intermittent transfusions during this hospitalization 
for Hb<7. There was no evidence of active bleeding.

#Febrile neutropenia
While neutropenic, he developed a fever without a localizing 
source. Aspiration pneumonia was possible given high aspiration 
risk but CXR was without major changes. GI infection was 
possible given diarrhea but C.diff/stool cultures were negative, 
he was without abdominal pain, and the diarrhea had been 
improving. Soft tissue/skin infection was also possible with L 
upper thigh rash, but rash had also been improving. Cultures 
were negative. He was started on vanc/cefepime/flagyl, and 
ultimately transitioned to Levaquin. He then completed a seven 
day course of antibiotics. 

#Orthostatic Hypotension
He was having baseline SBP 90-100s, which would lower to SBP 
60-70s upon standing. The ddx for his orthostatic hypotension 
was thought to be due to poor PO intake, autonomic dysfunction 
(amitriptyline, carbidopa/levodopa, diabetes), and vincristine. 
He was started on midodrine 7.5mg TID, medications that could 
effect BPs (amitriptyline and carbidopa/levodopa) were 
discontinued, and vincristine was avoided. His AM cortisol was 
within normal limits. His SBPs improved and were in the ___ 
upon discharge.

WHY WAS I ADMITTED TO THE HOSPITAL?
- You were admitted to the hospital because you passed out when

- You were given medicine to help remove the excess fluid from 
your body.

not pumping as well as it should.

to see you in the hospital and recommended chemotherapy.

service and started on chemotherapy.

started you on broad-spectrum antibiotics.

improved with a medication called midodrine.

- You should continue to take your medications as prescribed.

or you develop swelling in your legs, abdominal distention, or 
shortness of breath at night.

ACUTE ISSUES
=============
#Hypoxemic respiratory failure
Presented with subjective worsening of dyspnea with increased O2 
requirements from baseline of 2 L O2. His respiratory failure 
thought to be multifactorial secondary to COPD, acute systolic 
heart failure exacerbation, pleural effusion, and COPD. He was 
treated with 5 days of empiric antibiotics, initially broad 
spectrum, then de-escalated to CAP coverage. Infectious workup 
was negative. He was treated with prednisone (post-chemotherapy 
dosing) and nebulizer treatments. He was given IV diuresis and 
seen by IP with placement of L sided chest tube. His breathing 
improved and he was satting well on room air prior to discharge.

#NSTEMI
#CAD and recent DES of the proximal LAD on ___
Presented with troponemia in setting of recent DES. He was 
initially medically managed with heparin gtt, which was later 
discontinued in consultation with cardiology when it was felt 
his presentation was more consistent with demand ischemia. He 
was continued on atorvastatin 80 mg daily, aspirin 81 mg daily, 
clopidogrel 75 mg daily, metoprolol succinate.

#NSVT
He had multiple episodes of NSVT during his hospitalization. He 
was asymptomatic and hemodynamically stable during these 
episodes. His metoprolol succinate was increased from 25 mg to 
37.5 mg QD. The patient was amenable to ICD implantation despite 
being DNR/DNI, but further workup was deferred pending 
clarification of his cancer prognosis.

#Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (EF 24%)
TTE on ___ with moderate to severe regional LV dysfunction, 
normal RV. He was given IV diuresis. He was given IV diuresis in 
setting of pulmonary edema, otherwise did not appear 
decompensated. He was treated with the above medications.

Orthostatics were negative and the patient was able to ambulate

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,  

It was a privilege taking care of you at ___ 
___.  

WHY WAS I IN THE HOSPITAL?  
- You were admitted to the hospital because you were having 
increased shortness of breath.

WHAT HAPPENED TO ME IN THE HOSPITAL?  
- You were initially admitted to the intensive care unit where 
you had several treatments to improve your breathing. You had 
the fluid drained from your lung with a needle (thoracentesis). 
You were given water pills to remove extra fluid from your 
lungs. You were also given inhaled medications to decrease the 
inflammation in your lungs and make it easier for you to breath. 
Your breathing improved with these treatments and you no longer 
required supplemental oxygen by the end of your hospital stay.
- You were given 5 days of antibiotics because we were 
suspicious that you might have an infection in your lungs 
(pneumonia) when you first came in. We sent several tests to 
look for an infection, however, and these all came back 
negative. Consequently, we stopped your antibiotics.
- Your water pill, torsemide, was decreased from 60 mg once a 
day to 20 mg once a day. 
- You blood pressure medication, midodrine, was stopped because 
your blood pressure was well controlled during your admission.

WHAT SHOULD I DO AFTER I LEAVE THE HOSPITAL?   
- Please weigh yourself every day. If your weight increases by > 
3 lb, increase your torsemide to 40 mg daily. If your weight 
decreases by more than 3 lb, stop taking your torsemide until 
your weight returns to normal. 
- If you start to become lightheaded when standing up from 
sitting, or you faint, please call your doctor to discuss 
re-starting midodrine.

AM at the ___ on the ___ floor
- Please attend your appointment with the diabetes doctors on 
___ at 1:00 ___ at ___ located at ___ 
___, ___. ___. 
- Please make an appointment to see your PCP, ___, 
___ after leaving rehab.

We wish you the best.

Sincerely,  
Your ___ Team

IMPRESSION: 1) No hydronephrosis. 2) Solid bladder mass 
measuring 3.1 cm 
which is slightly larger than the prior ultrasound as described 
above. 3) No additional pelvic mass identified on limited 
imaging. 
.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ male with dementia, ischemic cardiomyopathy EF 50%, DM, CKD, 
and relatively recent diagnosis of urothelial carcinoma/bladder 
mass, admitted with increasing fatigue and somnolence for three 
weeks, eventually thought most likely related to MRSA UTI.
.
#Fatigue/somnolence - A broad differential was considered, 
including possible toxic or metabolic causes. The patient's 
electrolytes were normalized and folate, B12, TSH, free T4, RPR, 
and LFTs (including ammonia) were all checked and were within 
normal limits. An initial infectious workup was negative. The 
neurology service was consulted as the patient was initially 
referred in from neurology clinic and due to concern of dilation 
of the lateral ventricles on head CT. Their impression was that 
an element of NPH was a possible contributing factor to the 
patient's presentation, but that this was unlikely to be the 
only cause. Additionally, effective evaluation of NPH would 
require the patient to be as well and stable as possible, and 
able to walk, so that he could undergo detailed testing before 
and after LP with CSF removal. An additional complication was 
that the question of NPH had been raised to the patient when he 
was more lucid, and he declined to undergo evaluation stating he 
would not want surgery for shunt placement. Outpatient neurology 
follow-up was suggested. After several days in the hospital the 
patient developed a fever, and an ongoing infectious work-up was 
continued. A urine culture eventually grew out >100,000 colonies 
of MRSA. With treatment of this infection, the patient's mental 
status improved significantly, although his overall level of 
interaction and verbal communication remained fairly low. Per 
his son, this was close to his initial baseline several weeks 
before the deterioration leading to his admission. It seems 
likely that an element of depression may also be contributing to 
the patient's overall picture; consideration was given to 
possible initiation of pharmacotherapy (such as methylphenidate 
or mirtazapine), however ultimately this was deferred, at least 
temporarily, while the patient's other medical issues reach 
resolution.
.  
#Fevers/UTI: Beginning on the patient's third hospital day, he 
began experiencing fevers. An infectious work-up, including two 
UAs, was non-revealing. He received approximately two days of 
empiric vancomycin and Zosyn out of concern for impending 
clinical deterioration. Eventually his urine culture grew MRSA, 
and this was felt to be the source of his fevers. He was at risk 
for MRSA having had urologic procedures in the last few months, 
as well as Foley catheter placement during this hospitalization. 
His catheter was removed, his antibiotic therapy narrowed to 
vancomycin alone, and his fevers resolved. Several days later, 
lower-grade temperature returned (as high as 100.8). A repeat 
infectious and non-infectious work-up was again undertaken, 
which did not reveal a cause. Drug fever was felt to be a 
possibility, and vancomycin was stopped after seven days of 
total therapy. He promptly defervesced with this and had no 
further elevated temperatures prior to discharge. 
.
#RLE and knee swelling: This was first noted several days into 
the patient's hospitalization. It began with warmth and swelling 
of the patient's right knee. An x-ray was obtained demonstrating 
the presence of previously placed orthopedic hardware and 
degenerative changes. A RLE ultrasound was negative for clot. 
The right knee was tapped on ___ to differentiate between 
gout versus possible septic arthritis; the tap was consistent 
with gout. Over the next several days, the patient developed 
ascending edema of the RLE. A repeat ultrasound was again 
obtained, to evaluate both for thrombus or a possible 
compressive pelvic mass; neither of these were identified. In 
the last two days of hospitalization, the swelling appeared to 
improve mildly. Of note, the patient had been off his diuretics 
given his renal failure. If this swelling continues to persist, 
an abdominal CT scan should be considered, however this was not 
pursued prior to discharge given the patient's rapidly changing 
renal function.
.
#Acute renal failure: The patient's baseline SCr is thought to 
be approximately 1.3-1.4. At admission, his creatinine was 
mildly elevated at 1.6. His furosemide and ___ were held. His 
creatinine subsequently improved, however several days into his 
hospitalization he was noted to have an unexplained bump in both 
his SCr (peak 2.7) and his LFTs (predominantly a transaminitis, 
peak ALT 458, peak AST 867). The etiology of both these 
processes was unclear, however they appeared to be most 
consistent with an ischemic episode of some kind (of note, no 
hypotensive episodes, even mild hypotension, were ever 
documented). Cardiac biomarkers were cycled and an echo was 
obtained, both of which were non-revealing. The patient's renal 
function and LFTs improved (SCr back to 1.5). Later on his 
hospital course, his renal failure worsened again slightly; this 
was thought to be due to poor PO intake and responded to fluid 
administration.
.
#Transient rise in LFTs: Please see section on acute renal 
failure as above. This was thought to be related to transient 
hepatorenal ischemia, although the exact etiology was not 
completely clear.
.
#Poor PO intake/electrolyte abnormalities: The patient was felt 
to have poor PO intake throughout his stay, primarily related to 
his mental status. Without IV fluid support, he would trend 
towards a pre-renal, hypernatremic picture (serum Na 146 on day 
of discharge). The patient would respond well to feeding by 
family members and the nursing staff. It is hoped that with 
rehabilitation and further improvement in his mental status, his 
ability to take POs will improve.
.
#Aspiration: The patient is felt to aspirate his sections and 
oral intake frequently. He was empirically placed on a pureed 
and thickened diet, which seemed to improve this issue somewhat. 
His did not have a formal Speech and Swallow evaluation and it 
was thought unlikely this would change the nature of his care. 
He was not thought to have frank aspiration pneumonia at any 
point in his stay.
.
#Pruritus/rash: This was a chronic issue for the patient, 
beginning many months ago. Dermatology was consulted since the 
patient was itching his skin to the extent breakdown was 
occurring. Topical therapies, including triamcinolone as needed, 
were recommended and are included in the discharge medication 
list. 
.
#Conjunctivitis/corneal abrasion: The patient had seen his 
optometrist just prior to admission and was thought to have a 
left sided conjunctivitis. In the hospital, he was empirically 
treated with erythromycin ointment and tobramycin drops. His 
right eye was also bothering him, and ophthalmology was 
eventually consulted. The patient was found to have a right eye 
corneal abrasion, probably caused when the patient was 
scratching. An eye patch and keeping the eye lid closed were 
recommended; antibiotic drops were also initiated. The patient 
is scheduled for ophthalmology follow-up at ___ tomorrow, 
___.
.
#Hematuria/urothelial cell carcinoma: The patient had been 
previously known to have a bladder mass; this was diagnosed as a 
carcinoma by urine cytology shortly before admission. At 
admission, the patient was having significant hematuria. A Foley 
catheter was placed to allow for flushing of the bladder; his 
hematuria persisted, and he eventually required continuous 
irrigation for several days. In this setting, he required a 
total of three units pRBCs transfusion (two units, followed by 
an additional unit several days later). His hematuria improved 
significantly and all catheters were able to be discontinued 
within approximately the first week of his stay. The patient has 
planned urology follow-up for resection of the mass in the 
coming weeks.
.
#anemia: This was thought to be multifactorial in etiology 
(iron-deficiency, chronic blood loss, chronic disease). The 
patient's HCT ranged in the mid-20s for most of his stay, with 
one dip as low as 21 while he was having hematuria. This 
responded to RBC transfusion.  
.  
#Ischemic cardiomyopathy: The patient was felt to by dry to 
euvolemic during most of his admission, despite the holding of 
his furosemide (and ___ due to his ARF. He also tolerated the 
administration of several liters of fluid without any evidence 
of volume overload except, possible, his RLE swelling. An echo 
was checked and was unchanged. He was continued on his home beta 
blocker and ASA.
.  
#CAD: The patient's home ASA, beta blocker and statin were 
continued.
.  
#DM: The patient's home glipizide was held. He was managed with 
fixed dose/sliding scale insulin. 
.  
#HTN: As above, the patient's home beta blocker was continued 
but his ___ was held. He was mildly hypertensive during his stay 
but not to a degree that required intervention.
.
.
#Contact: If further information concerning this complex patient 
is desired, please contact ___, MD, ___, 
pager ___.

CTA CHEST: The pulmonary arterial vasculature is normally 
opacified to the subsegmental level, without evidence of filling 
defect to suggest pulmonary embolism. The aorta is normal in 
size and caliber without acute aortic pathology. The remaining 
great mediastinal vessels are normal.  
  
In the right lower lobe, there is a large consolidative opacity, 
measuring approximately 8.6 x 6.8 cm in maximum cross-sectional 
dimension (image 3:87).  Pulmonary arterial branches normally 
traverse through the consolidation area, compatible with the "CT 
angiogram sign". There are no pleural effusions or pneumothorax. 
No other pulmonary nodule or mass is noted.  
  
The heart is normal in size without pericardial effusion. The 
central tracheobronchial tree is patent. There is no 
mediastinal, hilar, or axillary lymphadenopathy. 
  
The study is not designed for subdiaphragmatic diagnosis. A 
subcentimeter hypodensity in the right hepatic lobe (image 
3:106) is too small to be fully characterized and a sub-cm 
hypodensity in the left lobe of the liver (3:100) is likely a 
cyst. The right adrenal is not visualized. The left adrenal is 
only partially imaged, but no abnormality is noted. 
  
BONE WINDOW: There are no suspicious lytic or sclerotic lesions. 

  
IMPRESSION: 
1. No pulmonary embolism or acute aortic pathology. 
2. Right lower lobe airspace consolidation, with demonstration 
of the "CT angiogram" sign. Differential diagnosis includes 
pneumonia, bronchioloalveolar carcinoma, and lymphoma. Recommend 
followup imaging after treatment to ensure clearance. 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo female with DM I, osteopenia, recent L olecranon fracture 
fix 2 weeks ago presenting with SOB, fever, cough, and found to 
have RLL opacity on CXR  
.  
# Fever: Pt presented with fever, cough, SOB, and pain on deep 
inspiration consistent with pneumonia.  CXR and CTA chest 
revealed RLL opacity concerning for PNA.  (In setting of recent 
surgery of olecranon fracture, CTA chest was performed to rule 
out PE.)  However, given atypical appearance of consolidation, 
malignancy could not be ruled out.  Pt was advised to have 
repeat imaging upon resolution of pneumonia and was scheduled 
for outpatient CT chest.  She was started on oral levofloxacin 
for CAP.  Gram stain of sputum revealed 1+ gram positive cocci 
in pairs; culture grew sparse commensal respiratory flora.  
Urine legionella was negative.  Despite her recent hospital 
stay, she was not started on treatment for HCAP as she appeared 
nontoxic and improved significantly over 24 hours on 
levofloxacin.  She was discharged home with instructions to 
complete a 7 day course of levofloxacin.  
.  
# Left olecranon fracture: Pt reported having been at an OSH for 
two days for surgery for her left olecranon fracture two weeks 
prior to presentation to ___.  Left arm was kept in a sling.  
She reported no pain in the arm.  Incision was clean, dry, and 
intact.  
. 
# DM type I: Pt had humalog insulin pump which was continued 
during her hospital stay.  Per protocol, she was evaluated by 
the ___ diabetes team and seen by the nutritionist.  Per 
___ recs, she was continued on her home pump settings as 
blood glucose remained grossly within target range.  She was 
continued on her home aspirin.  
.  
# Depression: No acute issues.  She was continued on her home 
citalopram  
.  
# Osteopenia: Pt had history of multiple fractures, most 
recently a fracture of her left olecranon which was repaired two 
weeks prior to admission.  She was continued on her calcium and 
vitamin D.  She was also taking alendronate once a week which 
should be continued as outpatient.
