Brief Hospital Course:
SUMMARY:
========
Ms. ___ is ___ female with past medical history of 
___ disease, advanced dementia, esophageal dysmotility 
w/ chronic aspirations s/p PEG for feeding, reactive airway 
disease on chronic glucocorticoids who presented with increased 
work of breathing and increased cough with sputum/secretions, 
found to have acute hypoxic/hypercarbic respiratory failure, 
MRSA and pseudomonas pneumonia, frequent bradycardia, and 
hypotension. 

ACUTE ISSUES 
=============== 
# Acute hypoxemic hypercarbic respiratory failure 
Initially presenting with hypoxia. Her respiratory failure 
worsened and was started on HFNC and eventually was intubated on 
___ after goals of care discussions with the family. She was 
given aggressive pulmonary toilet. Attempts to wean the 
ventilator were not successful, so she ultimately underwent 
tracheostomy placement and bronchoscopy on ___. Patient 
continued to have intermittent low minute ventilation so 
required switching from pressure support to volume control. She 
will need ongoing ventilator weaning after discharge. 

# Sepsis secondary to HAP
# MRSA pneumonia
# Pseudomonas PNA
CXR demonstrated findings concerning for multifocal pneumonia. 
Her sputum grew MRSA and Pseudomonas. For her MRSA pneumonia, 
she was given 10 days of vancomycin. For her Pseudomonas 
infection, she was initially treated with cefepime, but 
ultimately transitioned to IV ciprofloxacin for an additional 7 
days after her Pseudomonas developed intermediate sensitivities 
to cefepime. Last day of ciprofloxacin is ___. 

# Hypotension
Requiring pressors after being intubated. Likely ___ sedatives 
and sepsis. Given norepi for goal MAP >65. She did 
intermittently have brief hypotensive episodes throughout 
hospitalization that were fluid responsive. There may have been 
a component of difficulty measuring BPs given frequent 
movements. 

# Reactive airway disease/COPD
# Chronic aspiration
Patient has been on long-standing prednisone. Concern for 
chronic aspiration in the setting of esophageal dysmotility with 
kyphosis and dyskinesias from ___. Given high dose 
prednisone (50 mg) for 5 days followed by taper in addition to 
aggressive nebulizer regimen. She will be maintained on her home 
prednisone dose of 10 mg PO daily afterwards. 

# Recurrent episodes of bradycardia 
Before intubation, patient would intermittently have bradycardic 
episodes including a 10-second pause on telemetry in the setting 
of hypoxia and discomfort. Electrophysiology was consulted who 
did not feel that this regard prior to pacemaker placement. 
These episodes did not recur after intubation. Likely related to 
vagal episodes. 

# Coag negative staph in blood cultures 
Grown in one set of cultures, thought to be ___ contamination. 

# Diarrhea
C. diff negative. Likely ___ tube feeds. 

# Skin excoriations in groin
Foley placed for skin breakdown on external genitalia ___ 
urinary incontinence. 

# Hypernatremia
Likely ___ poor PO intake. Resolved with increased free water 
flushes. 

# Anemia
# Thrombocytopenia
Likely secondary to sepsis and antibiotics. Improved with 
treatment of infections. 

CHRONIC PROBLEMS:
=================
# Subacute and chronic rib fractures
Found on prior admission and thought to be due to chronic cough 
and osteoporosis. Continued Tylenol, ibuprofen and lidocaine 
patches. 

# ___ Disease
# Advanced dementia
Continued home carbidopa-levodopa and carbidopa. 

# Esophageal dysmotility
Continued tube feeds through PEG

# HLD
Continued home atorvastatin daily 

# GERD
Continued home lansoprazole 30 mg PO BID 

# Hypothyroidism
Continued home levothyroxine 25 mcg daily 

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
====================
[] Continue IV ciprofloxacin to end on ___
[] Please attempt to wean ventilator support 
[] Continue goals of care discussions if unable to be weaned 
from ventilator 
[] Please remove foley and attempt voiding trial
[] Pseudomonas developed resistance to cefepime, ceftazadime, 
and piperacillin-tazobactam. Please avoid use of these 
antibiotics in the future if concern for pneumonia
[] Prednisone taper
___: 20 mg x2 days
___: 10 mg PO daily indefinitely

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,  

It was a pleasure taking care of you at the ___ 
___!  

Why was I admitted to the hospital?  
=================================
- You were admitted because you were having difficulty breathing 
and were found to have a pneumonia.

What happened while I was in the hospital?  
====================================
- You had testing done to figure out what kind of pneumonia you 
had.  This showed you had 2 infections call MRSA and 
Pseudomonas.
 You were given IV antibiotics to treat these infections.
 You were given higher dose prednisone to help with 
inflammation in your lungs. 
 We placed you on a breathing machine called a ventilator to 
help you breath. Because you could not breathe without this 
machine, a tracheostomy (breathing tube in the neck) was placed, 
which will help you to breathe with the support of the 
ventilator, but be more comfortable. 

What should I do after leaving the hospital?  
============================================
- Please take your medications as listed in discharge summary 
and follow up at the listed appointments. 

Thank you for allowing us to be involved in your care, we wish 
you all the best!  

Sincerely,

Your ___ Healthcare Team

Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old woman with history of advanced ___, 
bilateral blindness, reactive airway disease on chronic 
prednisone, HTN, HLD, COPD, hypothyroidism, and recent admission 
for MRSA and pseudomonas PNA, which resulted in trach/peg, now 
with vent dependence, who now presents from her rehab (___) 
with persistent fevers and leukocytosis despite broad spectrum 
ABX for PNA, found to have bilateral UE DVT. Fevers likely 
non-infectious, so antibiotics discontinued. Patient stable and 
discharged back to ___. 

ACUTE ISSUES 
=============== 
# Fevers
Patient presents from ___ with persistent fevers and 
mild leukocytosis despite broad spectrum coverage for her 
resistant PNAs. ID was consulted and felt that her culture data 
likely reflects colonization, given her non-inflammatory sputum 
studies, stable vent settings, and stable secretions. The most 
likely etiology of her fevers is non infectious such as drug 
fever or ___ DVT. Notably, she was found to
have RUE DVT of brachial, basilic, and cephalic veins of the 
RUE. She was also found to have LUE DVT of axillary veins (with 
PICC still in place). It is possible this could be contributing 
to her fevers. Less likely new or persistent bacterial 
infection, though viral infection could be considered. Flu neg. 

# Bilateral UE Catheter Associated DVT:
Patient presented with RUE edema, found to have RUE thrombi of 
the brachial (non-occlusive), cephalic (occlusive), and basilic 
(non-occlusive) veins. This occurred in the setting of RUE PICC 
placed in the R basilic vein last admission (subsequently 
removed). She was also found to have partially occlusive LUE 
thrombi within the axillary (deep) and proximal basilic veins, 
with PICC still in place due to necessity of frequent lab draws. 
After extensive conversation with the patient's son (HCP) re: 
risks and benefits of anticoagulation, it was ultimately decided 
to anticoagulate with warfarin, with lovneox bridge. She will 
need repeat ultrasounds to assess for clot resolution on 
anticoagulation, minimum planned duration 3 months. Will also 
need to monitor for e/o active bleeding.

# L UE Erythema
The patient was found to have L upper arm erythema in the 
setting of L UE DVT, with some excoriations of the skin. Given 
improvement with topical emollients and without antibiotics, 
this was thought to be excoriation in the setting of her chronic 
steroid use, and less likely an overlying cellulitis. This 
should continue to be monitored at ___.

# Chronic Hypoxic respiratory failure: 
The patient is trached and vent dependent in the setting of 
advanced dementia. Her Trach cuff pressures were within normal 
limits(28). She was continued on her outpatient ventilator 
settings of CMV overnight and PSV during day. Trach sputum 
cultures grew pseudomonas, but given low PMNs and scant sputum 
production with stable vent settings, suspect colonization as 
opposed to active infection.

# Normocytic Anemia
The patient has a recent baseline Hgb of 7.5-8.5, and has 
required 2u PRBC while at
___. Did have guaiac + stools there, though no evidence of 
overt bleeding. Could represent a slow GIB vs marrow suppression 
in the setting of recent infections. s/p 1UPRBC with robust 
response supporting that acute bleed is less likely. Iron 
studies suggest anemia of chronic inflammation.

CHRONIC ISSUES 
=============== 
# Esophageal dysmotility: s/p PEG: The patient was continued on 
nutrition's final tube feed recs from her last admission

# ___: Continued home carbidopa/levodopa regimen

# HLD: Continued home statin

# Chronic pain: Continued APAP. Home NSAIDs were held in the 
setting of anemia. 

# Reactive airway disease, copd: Continued home prednisone 10mg 
daily and home inhalers

Dear Ms. ___,

WHY WAS I ADMITTED TO THE HOSPITAL?
===================================
- You were admitted to the hospital because you were found to 
have fevers at your rehab. 

WHAT HAPPENED WHILE I WAS IN THE HOSPITAL?
==========================================
- There was a concern that you had pneumonia and you were 
continued on antibiotics. However your symptoms appeared to be 
unlikely from an infection and your antibiotics were stopped. 
- You had an ultrasound of your arm which showed blood clots. It 
is possible that these blood clots were causing your fevers. We 
discussed the risks and benefits of starting a blood thinner 
with your family, and we ultimately chose to start a blood 
thinner.
- You had low blood counts and needed a blood transfusion. Your 
blood counts improved.   

WHAT SHOULD I DO AFTER I LEAVE THE HOSPITAL?
============================================  
- Please continue to take all your medications and follow up 
with your doctors at your ___ appointments.  
- Your blood counts will need to be monitored closely in the 
setting of your new blood thinner. You will also need a repeat 
ultrasound of your arms in the future to look for interval 
change in the clots.

We wish you all the best!

Sincerely,  
Your ___ Care Team

=============== 
# Fever (noted x 1)

here, CXR w/o PNA. No leukocytosis and maintains baseline

antibiotics ___ weeks ago at ___. White count stable, no 
tachycardia. Afebrile other than 1 ED rectal temperature. One

#Chronic hypoxemic respiratory failure
#Trach dependent

weaned as tolerated. She transitioned to trach mask, and 
intermittently used the ventilator if she appeared to be in

discharge, with oxygen saturations 98-100% on 35% FiO2 and no 
respiratory distress. She did not need mechanical ventilation 
for 36 hours prior to discharge.

ultrasound here showed no evdience of DVT in upper extremity 
veins in setting of Warfarin since discharge in ___. Plan to

with consideration of transitioning to enoxaparin ___omplete for lifelong anticoagulation, as she has a 
propensity to develop venothromboemboli.

studies from her last admission suggest anemia of chronic 
inflammation. She requires intermittent transfusions.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ female with advanced ___, 
chronic respiratory failure s/p trach, chronic aspiration with 
PEG, dementia, hypertension, hyperlipidemia who is presenting 
with distal fibula (?tibial as well) fracture and found to have 
concerns for UTI in the ED. She was admitted to the ICU given 
chronic respiratory failure and brief hypotension in the ED 
which responded to IVF.

#Comminuted distal fibula fracture
Presenting with distal fibula fracture after having trauma on
stationary bike. She was initially placed in a right lower 
extremity splint, which was subsequently casted by the 
orthopedics service. She received her home acetaminophen dose 
and oxycodone as needed for pain control. She has follow-up 
scheduled with orthopedics. 

#Hypotension, improved
Patient was briefly hypotensive in the ED with SBPs in the ___, 
Improved with 1L NS. Lactate within normal limits. Etiology 
likely either hypovolemia vs. sepsis. Given hyponatremia, 
possibly related to hypovolemia, especially given rapid 
improvement after small amount of IVF. Some concerns for UTI as 
noted below. 

#UTI
Patient found to have pyuria on UA in setting of leukocytosis. 
No other clear source of infection. She was given a 7 day course 
of ceftriaxone as treatment for urinary tract infection which 
was then transitioned to Keflex. 

#Chronic respiratory failure 
Respiratory status appears at baseline, patient has a 
tracheostomy. CXR without evidence of consolidation. Home 
settings on trach were continued with trach mask during the day 
and ventilator at night, and her home medications were 
continued. 

___: Her home carbidopa/levodopa regimen was continued. 
She had some episodes of agitation overnight and her outpatient 
neurologist Dr. ___ was consulted, who recommended an 
additional 1.5 tabs of Sinamet as needed at 3 am for agitation. 
This was noted to improve her agitation overnight. 

#Bradycardia: While in the ICU, the patient had intermittent 
episodes of sinus bradycardia overnight in the setting of being 
off the ventilator and while episodes of agitation. EKG showed 
no evidence of bundle branch block or heart block. This was 
thought to be secondary to the vasovagal episodes given timing 
with episodes of agitation as well as being off the ventilator. 
She did not have any hypotension during these episodes and 
continued to be monitored throughout her stay.  Her son, ___, 
expressed interest in a cardiology evaluation for which we 
provided him the contact information to schedule an outpatient 
appointment as her bradycardia resolved with improvement in 
agitation and pain control.

Brief Hospital Course:
SUMMARY
=======
Ms. ___ is a ___ year old woman with chronic respiratory 
failure s/p tracheostomy ___ (nocturnally ventilated), chronic 
aspiration s/p PEG, dementia, advanced ___, HTN, 
hyperlipidemia, recent admission for a right fibula fracture, 
and other issues who presented on ___ with apparent 
lethargy (reported by her son, as the patient is variably 
interactive) in the setting of a reported right lower lobe 
pneumonia apparently noted on outpatient imaging on the day 
prior to presentation. On repeat imaging on presentation to 
___, there were no definite signs of pneumonia and there were 
no clinical indications of acute systemic inflammation or 
infection. She remained on her home ventilator settings at night 
and trach mask during the day. Although very broad spectrum 
antibiotics were provided on presentation in the ED, given the 
absence of infection on chest imaging and the lack of clinical 
symptoms of an acute infection, all antibiotics were stopped 
upon ICU admission, and she was monitored off of antibiotics for 
24 hours without any signs of clinical instability. She was 
subsequently discharged home without antibiotics.

ACUTE ISSUES 
============
# Concern for right upper lobe pneumonia (without radiographic 
or clinical evidence of right upper lobe pneumonia) 
# Chronic respiratory failure 
Ms. ___ has a tracheostomy tube in place in the setting of 
chronic respiratory failure, and requires ventilator support at 
night. During the day, she uses a humidifier with 3L of 
supplemental oxygen. Per history provided by her son (who is her 
primary caregiver at home), Ms. ___ has had increased 
secretions over the last week and an out-patient chest x-ray on 
___ was concerning for potential right upper lobe pneumonia. 
However, on presentation to ___, there was no compelling 
radiographic or clinical evidence of pneumonia. Blood cultures 
and a MRSA screen were negative. She specifically had minimal 
secretions on tracheal suctioning, no leukocytosis on her 
complete blood counts, no fever, no hypotension, no tachycardia, 
and no radiographic evidence of pneumonia (although her lung 
apices were not well visualized on chest x-ray to 
kyphoscoliosis). Ms. ___ was continued on her home 
ipratropium and levalbuterol nebuliizer treatemetns, and 
fomoterol(home med). Her ventilator settings should remain at RR 
___, PEEP 5, TV 300 (reduced from 400cc at home, given her 
height and predicted tidal volume), and FiO2 30%

# History of UTIs
In the ED, the patient did not urinate but on the floor she has 
been incontinent of urine. She has a history of UTIs, and during 
a recent prior hospitalizations, on ___ she grew Klebsiella 
and was appropriately treated. She had another UTI while at home 
prior to this hospitalization which was treated empirically with 
cephalexin and then switched to Bactrim. Urinalysis here ___ 
was without evidence of acute cystitis, and while there was 
initial concern for urinary retention she began to void 
spontaneously prior to discharge, and did not have any more 
issues with retention while inpatient.

# ___ disease 
# Dementia
During her last admission, Ms. ___ had some episodes of 
agitation overnight and her outpatient neurologist Dr. ___ 
___ was consulted. At that time, he recommended an additional 
1.5 tabs of Sinamet as needed at 3AM for agitation. During that 
prior hospitalization, this medication change was noted to 
improve her agitation overnight. Her son says that she 
communicates with him, is normally oriented to person and place, 
and can speak with Passy-Muir valve. We continued Sinamet at her 
home doses this admission.

CHRONIC ISSUES 
==============
#B/l UE catheter associated DVT
She had bilateral upper extremity DVTs diagnosed in ___, 
with repeat US in ___ showing no evidence of DVT. Now that she 
has been treated for more than six months, she remains on 
enoxaparin prophylaxis, which we continued during this 
hospitalization (and on discharge). 

#Hypothyroidism: We continued her home levothyroxine. 

#Esophageal dysmotility: s/p PEG: We continued the Nutrition 
service's final tube feed recommendations from her last 
admission. 

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES
===================
[] Follow up on respiratory secretions and respiratory status 
off of antibiotics
[] Continue to monitor for signs of urinary retention, consider 
outpatient urodynamic studies if persistently retaining.
[] Ventilator settings at discharge: RR 13, TV 300, PEEP 5, FiO2 
30%

Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted for occasional wheezing and cough. There was 
concern for pneumonia but your chest X-ray did not show 
pneumonia and your symptoms quickly improved with nebulizers. 
Antibiotics were stopped and you tolerated this just fine. 
Overall, your presentation is most consistent with a post 
infectious bronchitis or asthma like syndrome.

You were evaluated by speech and language pathology who felt you 
would benefit from a ground diet with thin liquids to minimize 
your risks of accidentally inhaling some of your food when you 
eat (which can predispose to pneumonia and coughing fits).

You were deconditioned and had difficulty moving around and 
physical therapy recommended going to a rehab facility. You did 
not qualify for acute level rehab and so you and your family 
elected to go home with maximal services in order to work on 
getting stronger at home.

risk and recommended acute rehab however son declined as pt not 
accepted to first choice rehab. Patient admitted after fall from

a walker. Imaging including CT C spine, CT Head, CXR, Pelvis XR, 
bilateral knee XR and L ankle XR without fracture or acute 
pathology. There were no focal neuro signs on exam. ___ was 
consulted who recommended disposition to rehab. She was 
discharged to ___.

# Respiratory distress/Aspiration
While in the ED the patient developed respiratory 
distress/labored respirations requiring NC. The etiology was 
concerning for aspiration as she had been eating her medications 
with applesauce prior to the event. A repeat CXR in the ED was 
negative for aspiration, but may have been premature to 
visualize any changes. The differential also included airway 
reactivity, given the recent admission for reactive airways. She 
was quickly weaned to room air with nebulizer treatments. Given 
the concern for mild respiratory distress a third CXR was done 
on the floor, again without any signs of infiltrate or acute 
pathology. There was evidence of mild volume overload and pt 
received 10mg IV lasix. On the previous admission the patient 
was evaluated by SLP who recommended a diet of ground solids and 
thin liquids. SLP was re consulted this admission, and the 
patient underwent a video swallow due to concerns for bedside 
aspiration, which revealed penetration and trace aspiration, and 
the patient was initiated on a diet of ground solids and nectar 
thickened liquids. She was also seen by nutrition who 
recommended supplementation with ensure plus TID. She was 
continued on atrovent and albuterol nebulizer treatmens, and 
fluticasone inhaler. Of note, albuterol was used cautiously as 
caused pt to become tachycardiac.

# Hyponatremia - RESOLVED
Patient with new mild hyponatremia to 130, with concomitant 
hypochloremia. Likely secondary to hypovolemia given improvement 
with IVF. 
 
# Coagulopathy Elevated PTT - RESOLVED
Patient with newly elevated PTT on admission. On recent 
admission patient appears to have been on heparin 5000 U TID, 
though patient is of normal BMI, likely the etioloy of the 
elevated PTT. No concomitant elevation in INR, no 
thrombocytopenia to suggest DIC. No history of elevated PTT in 
the past to suggest the presence of an acquired or intrinsic 
inhibitor. Resolved with holding subC heparin. The patient was 
restarted on subC heparin for VTE prophylaxis with BID dosing 
without elevation in PTT

about a week prior to presentation and appeared to be at his 
baseline) with ED course notable for grandiosity, irritability,
disorganized and tangential thought process, as well as 
agitation requiring numerous physical and chemical restraints. 
Interview on my examination was significantly more reassuring, 
with patient notably calm, cooperative with thought process that 
is linear, goal and future oriented. Of note, he denies AVH and 
he does not appear to be responding to internal stimuli. 
. 
In terms of etiology, presentation seems most consistent with 
substance induced psychosis, although the patient denies recent 
illicit substance use and his tox screen was negative on 
admission. Differential also includes brief psychotic disorder, 
bipolar disorder (although no clear history of mania in the 
past-- remains on the differential given young age with ?family 
history of bipolar). Has reportedly been depressed in the past, 
but denies depressive symptoms on examination and does not 
appear dysthymic or dysphoric on examination.  
. 
#. Legal/Safety: patient admitted to Deaconess ___ on a ___, upon admission, he declined to sign a CV, stating he wished 
to be discharged home. Patient maintained his safety throughout 
his hospitalization on 15 minute checks and did not require 
physical or chemical restraints. Given his good behavioral 
control with resolution of psychotic symptoms with consistent 
denial of SI/HI, he did not meet 7&8b criteria and was 
discharged upon expiration of his ___. 
.
#. Psychosis: as noted above
- Patient declined initiation of psychotropic medications during 
his hospitalization. He was offered prn Ativan, which he did not 
require. 
- Mr. ___ maintained excellent behavioral control in the 
milieu and was compliant in attending groups, where he 
participated appropriately 
- Of note, during his hospitalization, his psychosis cleared 
rapidly with thought process that became linear, logical, goal 
and future oriented. He was calm, cooperative on examination 
with full range of affect, consistently denying AVH with no 
evidence that he was responding to internal stimuli. 
- Patient was counseled to avoid using illicit drugs, including 
cannabis, as this may increase his risk for a recurrent episode 
of psychosis. The patient understood this risk and stated he 
would abstain. 
- Patient declined referral to a PHP and will follow up with 
outpatient treaters as noted in the discharge worksheet. 
.
#. Medical: no acute issues during this admission

starts to drain, cover it with a clean dry dressing and change 
it  as needed to keep site clean and dry.

 * You may need pain medication once you are home but you can 
wean it over the next week as the discomfort resolves.  Make 
sure that you have regular bowel movements while on narcotic 
pain medications as they are constipating which can cause more 
problems.  Use a stool softener or gentle laxative to stay 
regular.

* No driving while taking narcotic pain medication.

* Take Tylenol  ___ mg every 6 hours in between your narcotic.  

* Continue to stay well hydrated and eat well to heal your 
incisions

* Shower daily. Wash incision with mild soap & water, rinse, pat 
dry
 * No tub bathing, swimming or hot tubs until incision healed
 * No lotions or creams to incision site

* Walk ___ times a day and gradually increase your activity as 
you can tolerate.

symptoms that concern you.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ woman with multiple vascular risk factors, including 
prior stroke, atrial fibrillation on River Oxilan and aspirin, 
hypertension, hyperlipidemia, insulin-dependent diabetes 
mellitus, who initially presented with persistent vertigo.  She 
reported a positional vertigo that did not dissipate initially 
on rest.  ED evaluation was notable for hyperglycemia to 430.  
She reported some recent changes with her diabetes medications, 
followed usually by her primary care.  There were no neighboring 
signs or symptoms, or additional review of system features 
suggestive of a peripheral vestibulopathy, such as neuronitis, 
or Mnire's disease,.  Her exam was not suggestive of central 
vertigo, though given her risk factors, she was admitted for 
stroke workup.  Her CTA was unremarkable.  MRI did not reveal 
any stroke, but did show an evolution of white matter disease in 
the periventricular areas.  Therefore, the most likely etiology 
of her symptoms was felt to be hyperglycemia causing 
vertigo-like symptoms, versus benign paroxysmal positional 
vertigo.  Her vertigo-like symptoms dissipated overnight into 
the next morning after admission.  Her blood sugars were better 
controlled while admitted, though her A1c was 12.7 reflecting 
likely poorly controlled diabetes as an outpatient. She 
indicated a desire to follow-up with her primary care provider, 
but as well as the ___ further 
management.  She was advised to stay hydrated to avoid the 
effect of glucose related diuresis.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

Your admitted to the hospital for vertigo, or a room spinning 
sensation.  Sometimes, vertigo is caused by stroke in part of 
the brain, so you are admitted for close monitoring and further 
workup.  Thankfully, your MRI did not show any strokes.  You 
felt better the next day in terms of vertigo, and you were able 
to walk around the hospital without any issues.  The most likely 
explanation for your symptoms therefore is something called 
benign paroxysmal positional vertigo, which can occur when the 
inner ear has problems with debris that builds up over time.  
The other possibility is your elevated blood sugars, which can 
certainly cause dizziness that may mimic vertigo.  In addition, 
the sugar in your blood can act as a diuretic medicine, removing 
more fluid than you are able to make up for by drinking.  This 
may lead to additional lightheadedness and feelings of dizziness 
which may have contributed to her symptoms.  If this happens 
again, you may be referred either to a neurologist or ___ 
rehab to help you with the symptoms, during which they may 
perform certain maneuvers to clear the debris from your year.  
Please contact your primary care provider if the symptoms recur. 
 However, if the symptoms persist, or are accompanied by changes 
in vision, including double vision, or weakness or sensation 
changes, please report to the nearest emergency department as 
they may reflect stroke.  Otherwise, please continue all of your 
medications as directed and do not miss doses.

It was a pleasure taking care of you.

___ neurology

Weigh yourself every morning, call MD if weight goes up more 
than 3 lbs.

Dear Ms. ___,

It was a pleasure taking care of you at ___ 
___.

WHY WAS I ADMITTED TO THE HOSPITAL?
- You were admitted to the hospital because of shortness of 
breath and an irregular heartbeat.

WHAT HAPPENED WHILE I WAS IN THE HOSPITAL?
- In the hospital, we performed some lab tests to determine the 
reason for your shortness of breath. We also performed 
measurements of the electrical activity of your heart, which 
showed that it was beating in an irregular rhythm. We gave you a 
pill that would reduce the amount of water your body held onto 
as well as medications to decrease the resistance against which 
your heart pumped. These medications also decrease your 
heartrate. We also performed some imaging to look at your heart. 
Because your heartbeat was so fast and irregular, it wasn't 
pumping blood efficiently. The medications helped with this, but 
you required an electrical shock to convert your heart back into 
regular rhythm. We are glad you are feeling better after these 
procedures.

WHAT SHOULD I DO WHEN I GO HOME?
- Please take all of your medications exactly as prescribed and 
attend all of your follow-up appointments listed below.
- It is particularly important that you do NOT miss ___ dose of 
your apixaban.

We wish you the best!
Your ___ Care Team

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ was admitted to the ___ Medical service and did 
very well.  He had only 1 loose stool after arriving to the 
floor (after having had several in the ED).  He was supported 
with IVF and stress dose steroids as well as potassium 
repletion.  CT scan showed colitis as well as incidentally noted 
prostatic enlargement.

Stool cultures were without growth.
.
On the of discharge, he was ambulating without difficulty, 
reported he felt fine, had no further loose stool x > 24 hours 
and wished to return home.
.
His case was discussed with the on-call Endocrinologist who 
agreed that 36 hours of IV steroids was likely sufficient for a 
stress dose and that he could be discharged on 1 mg po 
dexamethasone x 1 week and then resume his regular dose of 0.5 
mg po dexamethasone daily.  He should continue his Florinef.
.
He reports he drinks 1 can tomato juice daily and this was 
encouraged for potassium repletion and he was also prescribed 40 
mEq po potassium for ___.
.
Dr. ___ reviewed the case with the patient and 
his mother who reported that she would see to it that the 
medication changes were put into effect, that he would follow up 
with Dr. ___ that he would discuss his maintenance 
dexamethasone dose with Dr. ___ it seems fairly 
high) as well as the incidentally noted prostatic enlargement.
.
At the time of discharge, Mr. ___ was fully ambulatory and 
symptom free.
.

Discharge Instructions:
INSTRUCTIONS AFTER ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY:

- You were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal 
to feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling 
should improve over the first few days to week. 
- Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow 
your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times.

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
-Weightbearing as tolerated right lower extremity, in ___ 
locked in extension

MEDICATIONS:
  1)  Take Tylenol ___ every 6 hours around the clock. This is 
an over the counter medication.
  2)  Add oxycodone as needed for increased pain. Aim to wean 
off this medication in 1 week or sooner.  This is an example on 
how to wean down:
Take 1 tablet every 3 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every 4 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every 6 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every 8 hours as needed x 2 days, 
then 1 tablet every 12 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every before bedtime as needed x 1 day.  
Then continue with Tylenol for pain.
  3)  Do not stop the Tylenol until you are off of the narcotic 
medication.
  4)  Per state regulations, we are limited in the amount of 
narcotics we can prescribe. If you require more, you must 
contact the office to set up an appointment because we cannot 
refill this type of pain medication over the phone. 
  5)  Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you 
should drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and continue 
following the bowel regimen as stated on your medication 
prescription list. These meds (senna, colace, miralax) are over 
the counter and may be obtained at any pharmacy.
  6)  Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate 
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
  7)  Please take all medications as prescribed by your 
physicians at discharge.
  8)  Continue all home medications unless specifically 
instructed to stop by your surgeon.
      
ANTICOAGULATION:
- Please take aspirin 325 mg daily for 4 weeks

WOUND CARE:
- You may shower. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken 
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.
- Incision may be left open to air unless actively draining. If 
draining, you may apply a gauze dressing secured with paper 
tape.
- Splint must be left on until follow up appointment unless 
otherwise instructed.
- Do NOT get splint wet.

DANGER SIGNS:
Please call your PCP or surgeon's office and/or return to the 
emergency department if you experience any of the following:
- Increasing pain that is not controlled with pain medications
- Increasing redness, swelling, drainage, or other concerning 
changes in your incision
- Persistent or increasing numbness, tingling, or loss of 
sensation
- Fever ___ 101.4
- Shaking chills
- Chest pain
- Shortness of breath
- Nausea or vomiting with an inability to keep food, liquid, 
medications down
- Any other medical concerns

THIS PATIENT IS EXPECTED TO REQUIRE ___ DAYS OF REHAB

Physical Therapy:
Activity:   Activity:  Out of bed w/ assist
 Right lower extremity:  Full weight bearing
 Left lower extremity:  Full weight bearing
Knee immobilizer or ___: At all times, locked in extension
Encourage turning, deep breathing and coughing qhour when awake.

Treatments Frequency:
Any staples or superficial sutures you have are to remain in 
place for at least 2 weeks postoperatively.  Incision may be 
left open to air unless actively draining.  If draining, you may 
apply a gauze dressing secured with paper tape.  You may shower 
and allow water to run over the wound, but please refrain from 
bathing for at least 4 weeks postoperatively.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo woman with PMH of HTN/HLD presenting with left neck pain 
and generalized weakness.      

#Neck pain: One week of neck pain without clear etiology as no
clear precipitating factors. Patient had recent viral illness 
but
denies f/c, n/v, headache, vision changes, other neurologic
changes which would be concerning for meningitis so no need for
LP. Pain is focal on left side of neck without
notable exam findings. Pt reports intermittent arm weakness but
neurological exam completely intact, Spurling test negative, no
point tenderness over spine or signs of spinal injury. No bruit
or thrill no raise concern for vascular abnormality, no mass or
lymphadenopathy to raise concern for infection. XR and CT of 
C-spine show severe cervical DJD as well as calcification of 
carotids R>L. Pain improved with ibuprofen and home tramadol on 
which she was discharged, may benefit from longstanding tx with 
COX-2 inhibitor as allergic to APAP. 

#Weakness/anorexia/gait abnormality: Exam relatively 
unremarkable, patient mentating well, but appears to
be failing at home based on multiple recent admissions. Poor PO
intake appears to be slow recovery from recent viral illness, 
but
could be part of overall subacute decline. Continued on home 
mirtazapine. Evaluated by nutrition who felt that patient has 
good diet but would benefit from Ensure supplementation. 
Evaluated by ___ who cleared patient for home without additional 
services. In conversation with patient, daughter, and social 
work, team able to get collateral information that patient has 
numerous services at home through elder services and daughter is 
considering applying for assisted living but has been anxious 
about mother's ability to function at home. Overall, patient is 
largely healthy, cognitive intact, and safe to ambulate on her 
own. Will benefit from maximal services available from elder 
services but is largely functioning well with good supports. 

#HTN: EKG with LBBB and LVH, exam notable for S4 making some end
organ damage from longstanding hypertension likely. Chem 7 wnl. 
Stable on home losartan. 
 Will follow up with PCP regarding HTN management, consideration 
of TTE, and ophthalmology f/u given evidence of end organ 
damage. 

#GERD: Stable on home omeprazole

#Anemia: Hgb 10.3->9.4 with unclear baseline. Likely ___ 
dilution as all cell lines down. Patient on home iron 
supplementation and aware of anemia. Will need ongoing 
outpatient monitoring, discharged with home iron 
supplementation. 

Transitional issues:
-Found to have extensive DJD of the cervical spine. Would 
consider outpatient discussion of longterm medications such as 
COX-2 inhibitors. 
-Extensive calcification of the right carotid bifurcation with 
less significant left carotid calcification seen on CT C-spine. 
Follow up with PCP. 
-Patient and family interested in referral to geriatrics for 
ongoing primary care. 
-Patient would benefit from maximal resources from elder 
services including access to nutritional supplementation 
-Given LVH on EKG and S4 on exam, may benefit from outpatient 
TTE for evaluation of structural heart disease. Additionally 
would benefit from ophthalmology eval as outpatient given 
evidence of end organ damage from HTN.

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the orthopedic surgery service and 
was taken to the operating room for above described procedure. 
Please see separately dictated operative report for details. 
Patient received perioperative IV antibiotics.

Postoperative course was remarkable for the following:
On POD #1, patient was given 500ml IV fluid bolus for 
hypotension, which she responded to appropriately. Patient was 
noted to have some post-op delirium and dilaudid was decreased 
in dosage from ___ to 0.5-2mg every 4 hours as needed. 
Oxycodone and tramadol was avoided due to reported allergy. 
Morphine was avoided due to slightly elevated creatinine of 1.4. 
Overnight, patient was noted to have increased delirium with 
temp of 100.2 and urinalysis, repeat CBC was completed. UA was 
negative, hematocrit was 25.5 and WBC 12.8.

On POD #2, hematocrit was 24.2. and WBC 12.7. Patient was 
triggered for change in mental status in the afternoon and Tmax 
of 102.0. Patient was noted to have increased delirium with new 
oxygen requirement (88-90% on room air) and slightly tachycardic 
with HR in the low 100s. A fever work-up was completed, 
including urinalysis/cultures, blood cultures and chest x-ray. 
UA was borderline, showing moderate leukocytes, WBC 12, negative 
nitrates/epi. Chest X-ray showed pacification of the right and 
left lungs, with slight blurring of the pulmonary vessels 
represent atelectasis, however cannot exclude pneumonia. Patient 
was not given Tylenol due to reported allergy and was not given 
any other alternative PO anti-pyretic medication due to 
confusion at the time/inability to swallow pills. Cool pack/ice 
was given to the patient and fever resolved on its own. Patient 
remained afebrile overnight. Gabapentin was discontinued and no 
further narcotic medications were given. The Medicine team was 
consulted for co-management of care due to complex past medical 
history and recommended empiric treatment with Levaquin if cough 
develops or consideration of further testing to rule out PE if 
patient remained tachycardic or hypoxic.

On POD #3, hematocrit was 23.5, WBC 11.7 (downtrending) and 
creatinine improved to 1.2. Patient was alert and oriented to 
self, DOB, place. Patient reported right calf pain to palpation 
and a lower extremity ultrasound was obtained, which results 
were negative for DVT.

On POD #4, hematocrit was 22.3 and patient was transfused 1 unit 
packed red blood counts, which she tolerated well. 
Post-transfusion hematocrit was 29.4.

On POD #5, her hematocrit was stable at 25.9 and her creatinine 
was 1.3.  She was discharged to rehab with repeat lab follow-up 
(hematocrit and creatinine) within 2 days of discharge.  Her 
Lasix and Losartan continue to be held until creatinine 
stabilizes.  

Urine cultures showed mixed bacterial flora consistent with skin 
contamination, no treatment indicated. Blood cultures were 
pending at the time of discharge and patient will be contacted 
if further treatment is indicated.

Otherwise, the patient received Aspirin 325 mg twice daily for 
DVT prophylaxis starting on the morning of POD#1.  The surgical 
dressing will remain on until ___. The patient was seen daily 
by physical therapy. Labs were checked throughout the hospital 
course and repleted accordingly. At the time of discharge the 
patient was tolerating a regular diet and feeling well.  The 
patient was afebrile with stable vital signs.  The patient's 
hematocrit was acceptable and pain was adequately controlled on 
an oral regimen. The operative extremity was neurovascularly 
intact and the dressing was intact. 

The patient's weight-bearing status is weight bearing as 
tolerated on the operative extremity. 
 
Ms. ___ is discharged to rehab in stable condition.

Discharge Instructions:
1. Please return to the emergency department or notify your 
physician if you experience any of the following: severe pain 
not relieved by medication, increased swelling, decreased 
sensation, difficulty with movement, fevers greater than 101.5, 
shaking chills, increasing redness or drainage from the incision 
site, chest pain, shortness of breath or any other concerns.
 
2. Please follow up with your primary physician regarding this 
admission and any new medications and refills. 
 
3. Resume your home medications unless otherwise instructed.
 
4. You have been given medications for pain control. Please do 
not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while 
taking these medications. As your pain decreases, take fewer 
tablets and increase the time between doses. This medication can 
cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily 
and take a stool softener (such as Colace) as needed to prevent 
this side effect.  Call your surgeons office 3 days before you 
are out of medication so that it can be refilled.  These 
medications cannot be called into your pharmacy and must be 
picked up in the clinic or mailed to your house.  Please allow 
an extra 2 days if you would like your medication mailed to your 
home.
 
5. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your 
surgeon.
 
6. Please call your surgeon's office to schedule or confirm your 
follow-up appointment in three (3) weeks.
 
7. SWELLING: Ice the operative joint 20 minutes at a time, 
especially after activity or physical therapy. Do not place ice 
directly on the skin. You may wrap the knee with an ace bandage 
for added compression. Please DO NOT take any non-steroidal 
anti-inflammatory medications (NSAIDs such as Celebrex, 
ibuprofen, Advil, Aleve, Motrin, naproxen etc) until cleared by 
your physician.
 
8. ANTICOAGULATION: Please continue your Aspirin 325 mg twice 
daily with food for four (4) weeks to help prevent deep vein 
thrombosis (blood clots).  Continue Omeprazole home dose daily 
while on Aspirin to prevent GI upset.  If you were taking 
Aspirin prior to your surgery, take it at 325 mg twice daily 
until the end of the 4 weeks, then you can go back to your 
normal dosing.
 
9. WOUND CARE: Please remove Aquacel dressing on ___. It is 
okay to shower after surgery after 5 days but no tub baths, 
swimming, or submerging your incision until after your four (4) 
week checkup. Please place a dry sterile dressing on the wound 
after aqaucel is removed each day if there is drainage, 
otherwise leave it open to air. Check wound regularly for signs 
of infection such as redness or thick yellow drainage.  Staples 
will be removed by your doctor at follow-up appointment 
approximately 3 weeks after surgery.
 
10. ___ (once at home): Home ___, dressing changes as 
instructed, and wound checks.
 
11. ACTIVITY: Weight bearing as tolerated on the operative 
extremity. Mobilize with assistive devices (___) if 
needed.  Range of motion at the knee as tolerated. No strenuous 
exercise or heavy lifting until follow up appointment.

Active Issues:

#Acute on chronic Heart Failure with recovered Ejection fraction 

Patient was seen in the CDAC on the day prior to admission and 
received IV diuresis with Lasix and was sent home on increased 
dosages of p.o. Lasix.  She continued to develop lower extremity 
edema and increasing dyspnea on exertion.  She was admitted for 
continued IV diuresis.  She was able to transition to a new 
outpatient regimen of torsemide 60 mg p.o. daily and was 
continued on her home losartan, amlodipine, and metoprolol.

#Reactive airway disease
#Wheezing
Patient was found to be wheezing on examination and complaining 
of significant cough.  Initially felt to be due to cardiac 
wheezing, however the patient was given fluticasone, duo nebs, 
and as needed albuterol and and her lung sounds improved 
dramatically.  She symptomatically improved.  She will be 
discharged on fluticasone and albuterol inhaler, she should be 
formally evaluated in the outpatient setting with PFTs for 
underlying lung disease.

#Chronic kidney disease
#Acute kidney injury
The patient's baseline creatinine is 0.9, she was admitted with 
a creatinine of 1.4. This improved with diuretics. The most 
likely cause was the patient's heart failure. Her discharge 
creatinine was 1.3

___ disease
The patient will be moving in with her daughter who will be 
managing her medications. The patient was frequently missing 
medications at home and will be important that her daughter 
helps her to manage her chronic disease.

metoprolol

#PCOMM aneurysm
The patient is now s/p right crani PCOMM aneurysm clipping 
performed ___. She was transferred from the PACU to the ___ 
for Q2h neuro checks and ongoing care and surveillance. She 
remained neurologically intact throughout her time in the ___ 
and was made floor status on POD#2. On POD#3, patient received 
IV decadron x1 for right periorbital edema.

#Pain Control
On POD1, the patient continued to have headaches that were 
controlled with PO and IV management. Acute pain management was 
consulted. After evaluating the patient, they recommended 
switching her Oxycodone PO prn to Dilaudid ___ Q4hrs prn 
severe pain. She remained on APAP prn, Fioricet prn, 
Cyclobenzaprine prn, Gabapentin and Tizanadine. Her IV pain 
medications were discontinued on POD#2.

#Asymptomatic hypotension
Overnight on POD#3, patient experienced a brief episode of 
asymptomatic hypotension likely secondary to the combination of 
medications she recieved. Medication management was discussed 
with the patient prior to discharge and she voiced 
understanding. Her lisinopril dose was decreased from 20mg to 
5mg. Patient should follow up with her PCP regarding this 
medication dose change.

Mental Status: Clear and coherent.

Discharge Instructions:
Call your neurosurgeons office and speak to the Nurse 
Practitioner if you experience:

- Any neurological issues, such as change in vision, speech or 
movement

- Swelling, drainage, or redness of your incision

- Any problems with medications, such as nausea vomiting or 
lethargy

- Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit

- Headaches not relieved with prescribed medications

Activity:
- Start to resume all activities as you tolerate  but start 
slowly and increase at your own pace.

- Do not operate any motorized vehicle for at least 10 days 
after your surgery  your Nurse Practitioner can give you more 
detail at the time of your suture removal.  

Incision Care:

- Keep your wound clean and dry.

- Do not use shampoo until your sutures are removed. 

- When you are allowed to shampoo your hair, let the shampoo run 
off the incision line.  Gently pad the incision with a towel to 
dry.

- Do not rub, scrub, scratch, or pick at any scabs on the 
incision line.

- You need your sutures removed 7 to 10 days after surgery

Post-Operative Experiences: Physical

- Jaw pain on the same side as your surgery; this goes away 
after about a month

- You may experience constipation.  Constipation can be 
prevented by:

o Drinking plenty of fluids
oIncreasing fiber in your diet by eating vegetables, prunes, 
fiber rich breads and cereals, or fiber supplements
oExercising
oUsing over-the-counter bowel stimulants or laxatives as needed, 
stopping usage if you experience loose bowel movements or 
diarrhea

- Fatigue which will slowly resolve over time

- Numbness or tingling in the area of the incision; this can 
take weeks or months to fully resolve

- Muffled hearing in the ear near the incision area

- Low back pain or shooting pain down the leg which can resolve 
with increased activity

Post-Operative Experiences: Emotional

- You may experience depression.  Symptoms of depression can 
include

o Feeling down or sad
o Irritability, frustration, and confusion
o Distractibility
o Lower Self-Esteem/Relationship Challenges
o Insomnia
o Loneliness

- If you experience these symptoms, you can contact your Primary 
Care Provider who can make a referral to a Psychologist or 
Psychiatrist

- You can also seek out a local Brain Aneurysm Support Group in 
your area through the Brain Aneurysm Foundation

o More information can be found at ___

Brief Hospital Course:
Pt. medically cleared and admitted to ___ inpatient 
psychiatry service after spending 2 days in ED for agitated 
behavior requiring multiple chemical restraints. Patient 
evaluated upon arrival to unit and placed on 15 min checks. Pt. 
refused to sign a CV.

Psych: Pt. initial presentation consisted of psychotic symptoms, 
namely grandiose and paranoid delusions, of being ___ the 
___, being able to speak in tongues, thinking people had 
spit in his water. ___ also beleived that he could read the 
mind of the the young girl he pushed and believed that she was 
making fun of his breasts and acne scars. He consistently denied 
any auditory hallucinations. ___ thought disorder and 
disorganization of speech were quite striking during his initial 
presentation and early part of his hospitalization, 
characterized by extreme looseness of associations, bordering on 
pressured and angry derailed tirades. ___ also presented with 
noticeably flat affect despite his angry and irritable behavior 
early on in his admission. He initially refused to take any 
medication and denied anything was wrong. An affadavit for court 
commitment was filed prior to expiration of ___ and ___ 
was committed to unit for 45 days, and required to take 
medication. ___ was started on Geodon 40 mg BID, which was 
quickly titrated up to 60 mg BID and eventually 80 mg BID after 
5 days. He also received Ativan 1 mg q6 PRN anxiety and poor 
sleep which he used regularly. He tolerated the medications with 
minimal side effects, though some ? stiffness was noted and 
patient was given Cogentin as well with each dose of Geodon. In 
the second week of medication, ___ developed an episode of 
orthostatic hypotension and his dose was decreased to 60 mg BID 
for 1 week. His orthostatis resolved with increased PO intake, 
and ___ was able to be titrated back up to 80 mg BID, Cogentin 
was also d/c'd. It was felt Geodon would be an appropriate 
antipsychotic for ___ given its neutral metabolic profile, 
ability for IM dosing if needed, lower risk for EPS, and little 
risk of prolaction elevation (given concern over breasts). ___ 
responded very slowly over the first 2 weeks of medication, 
showing improvement in his thought disorder and speech 
organization. The most striking feature of ___ hospital 
course, though, were his marked negative sxs which seemed to 
worsen during his stay: flat affect, alogia, withdrawal, apathy, 
and demoralization. It was thought that ___ likely was 
suffering from post-psychotic depression. Through discussions 
about his presentation and literature review, it was thought 
___ might benefit from initiation of Mirtazapine to help with 
negative sxs. He was started on 15 mg HS. Unfortunately, ___ 
did not tolerate the medication well, and developed intolerable 
sedation. The medication was thus discontinued on ___.  The 
patient was continued on the Geodon 60mg PO BID which he 
tolerated and was also continued on Cogentin 1mg PO BID PRN and 
Ativan 1mg PO TID PRN. The patient was discharged with 
prescriptions for the above medications and with a plan to 
follow up with his psychiatrist in two weeks.

As far as Mr. ___ diagnosis. He is ___ yo male admitted with 
bizarre and agitated behavior, exhibiting grandiose and paranoid 
delusions, and severe thought disorder. Patient has a ___ year 
history dating back to age ___ of depressive sxs and obsessive 
traits, 1 pior SA, and suffered the loss of his mother to CA at 
age ___. Last ___ patient had ___ psychotic episode, initially 
thought to be manic as well, but from discussions with outpt. 
psychiatrist and viewing d/c summary, there is little evidence 
of a manic episode. Based on current presentation and past 
history, it appears that Mr. ___ is suffering from the early 
beginnings of Schizophrenia, likely paranoid type, with 
pronounced negative symptoms and subsequent post-psychotic 
depression.

In the future, if patient does not show adequate remission of 
symptoms with geodon, it may be reasonable to try Risperdone, 
given the availability of a long-acting injectable form. Also, a 
re-trial of Mirtazapine may also be a consideration in the 
future if ___ negative/cognitive sxs continue to be an issue, 
though a lower starting dose would be recommended with slow 
upward titration.

Medical: ___ initially complained is some hand pain and 
tingling in his right hand secondary to injury from concert. 
Physical exam of this region was benign. No imaging was felt to 
be necessary. Patient was managed with PRN Ibuprofen with good 
effect. One episode of orthostasis as noted above on unit, 
responded well to decrease in Geodon dose and increased PO 
intake. The patient did not experience any other medical issues 
during his hospitalization. His vitals were monitored daily and

Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
BPH

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
-Do not lift anything heavier than a phone book (10 pounds) or 
drive until you are seen by your Urologist in follow-up

-You may continue to periodically see small amounts of blood in 
your urine--this is normal and will gradually improve

-Resume all of your pre-admission medications, except HOLD 
aspirin until you see your urologist in followup AND your foley 
has been removed (if not already done)

-Continue taking PROSCAR (Finasteride) AND/OR your other 
prostate shrinking medications until you are otherwise advised 
.

-You MAY be discharged home with a medication called PYRIDIUM 
that will help with the "burning" pain you may experience when 
voiding. This medication may turn your urine
bright orange.

-Colace has been prescribed to avoid post surgical constipation 
and constipation related to narcotic pain medication. 
Discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea develops. Colace is a 
stool softener, NOT a laxative, and available over the counter.  
The generic name is DOCUSATE SODIUM.  It is recommended that you 
use this medication.

-Do not eat constipating foods for ___ weeks, drink plenty of 
fluids to keep hydrated

-No vigorous physical activity or sports for 4 weeks and while 
Foley catheter is in place. 

-Tylenol should be your first line pain medication, a narcotic 
pain medication has been prescribed for breakthrough pain >4. 
Replace Tylenol with narcotic pain medication.

-Max daily Tylenol (acetaminophen) dose is 4 grams from ALL 
sources, note that narcotic pain medication also contains 
Tylenol

-Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics and do not 
operate dangerous machinery. Also, if the Foley catheter and Leg 
Bag are in place--Do NOT drive (you may be a passenger).

IF YOU ARE DISCHARGED HOME WITH A FOLEY CATHETER:

-Please refer to the provided nursing instructions and handout 
on Foley catheter care, waste elimination and leg bag usage.

-Your Foley should be secured to the catheter secure on your 
thigh at ALL times until your follow up with the surgeon.

-Follow up in 1 week for wound check and Foley removal. DO NOT 
have anyone else other than your Surgeon remove your Foley for 
any reason.

-Wear Large Foley bag for majority of time, leg bag is only for 
short-term when leaving house.

-Start prescribed antibiotic on discharge.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___, 

You have undergone a laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy, recovered 
in the hospital and are now preparing for discharge with the 
following instructions:

Please call your surgeon or return to the Emergency Department 
if you develop a fever greater than ___ F, shaking chills, chest 
pain, difficulty breathing, pain with breathing, cough, a rapid 
heartbeat, dizziness, severe abdominal pain, pain unrelieved by 
your pain medication, a change in the nature or severity of your 
pain, severe nausea, vomiting, abdominal bloating, severe 
diarrhea, inability to eat or drink, foul smelling or colorful 
drainage from your incisions, redness, swelling from your 
incisions, or any other symptoms which are concerning to you.
Diet: Stay on Stage III diet until your follow up appointment; 
please refer to your work book for detailed instructions. Do not 
self- advance your diet and avoid drinking with a straw or 
chewing gum. To avoid dehydration, remember to sip small amounts 
of fluid frequently throughout the day to reach a goal of 
approximately ___ mL per day. Please note the following signs 
of dehydration: dry mouth, rapid heartbeat, feeling dizzy or 
faint, dark colored urine, infrequent urination. 

Medication Instructions:
Please refer to the medication list provided with your discharge 
paperwork for detailed instruction regarding your home and newly 
prescribed medications.  
Some of the new medications you will be taking include:
1.  Pain medication: You will receive a prescription for liquid 
oxycodone, an opioid pain medication.  This medication will make 
you drowsy and impair your ability to drive a motor vehicle or 
operate machinery safely. You MUST refrain from such activities 
while taking these medications. You may also take acetaminophen 
(Tylenol) for pain management; do not exceed 4000 mg per 24 hour 
period.
2. Constipation: This is a common side effect of opioid pain 
medication.  If you experience constipation, please reduce or 
eliminate opioid pain medication.  You may trial 2 ounces of 
light prune juice and/or a stool softener (i.e. crushed docusate 
sodium tablets), twice daily until you resume a normal bowel 
pattern.  Please stop taking this medication if you develop 
loose stools. Please do not begin taking laxatives including 
until you have discussed it with your nurse or surgeon.
3. Antacids: You will be taking famotidine tablets, 20 mg twice 
daily, for one month. This medicine reduces stomach acid 
production. Please crush.
4. You must not use NSAIDS (non-steroidal anti-inflammatory 
drugs). Examples include, but are not limited to Aleve, 
Arthrotec, aspirin, Bufferin, diclofenac, Ecotrin, etodolac, 
ibuprofen, Indocin, indomethacin, Feldene, ketorolac, 
meclofenamate, meloxicam, Midol, Motrin, nambumetone, Naprosyn, 
Naproxen, Nuprin, oxaprozin, Piroxicam, Relafen, Toradol and 
Voltaren. These agents may cause bleeding and ulcers in your 
digestive system. If you are unclear whether a medication is 
considered an NSAID, please ask call your nurse or ask your 
pharmacist.
5.  Vitamins/ minerals: You may resume a chewable multivitamin, 
however, please discuss when to resume additional vitamin and 
mineral supplements with your bariatric dietitian.

Activity:
You should continue walking frequently throughout the day right 
after surgery; you may climb stairs.  
You may resume moderate exercise at your discretion, but avoid 
performing abdominal exercises or lifting items greater than10 
to 15 pounds for six weeks.

Wound Care:
You may remove any remaining gauze from over your incisions.  
You will have thin paper strips (Steri-Strips) over your 
incision; please, remove any remaining Steri-Strip seven to 10 
days after surgery.   
You may shower 48 hours following your surgery; avoid scrubbing 
your incisions and gently pat them dry.  Avoid tub baths or 
swimming until cleared by your surgeon. 
If there is clear drainage from your incisions, cover with 
clean, dry gauze. 
Please call the doctor if you have increased pain, swelling, 
redness, cloudy, bloody or foul smelling drainage from the 
incision sites. 
Avoid direct sun exposure to the incision area for up to 24 
months.
Do not use any ointments on the incision unless you were told 
otherwise.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You have undergone removal of your gallbladder, recovered in the 
hospital and are now preparing for discharge to home with the 
following instructions:

Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the 
Emergency Department for any of the following:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.
*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.
*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience a discharge.
*Your pain in not improving within ___ hours or is not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or 
back.
*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern 
you.

Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed.

Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times 
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. Avoid lifting 
weights greater than ___ lbs until you follow-up with your 
surgeon.

Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain 
medications.

Incision Care:
*Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner if you have 
increased pain, swelling, redness, or drainage from the incision 
site.
*Avoid swimming and baths until your follow-up appointment.
*You may shower, and wash surgical incisions with a mild soap 
and warm water. Gently pat the area dry.
*If you have staples, they will be removed at your follow-up 
appointment.
*If you have steri-strips, they will fall off on their own. 
Please remove any remaining strips ___ days after surgery.

30___s), INR 21.2, venous lactate 10.7, Cr 3.6 (baseline 1.4 - 
1.9), troponin 0.02, CK 81. The patient was given 2 units pRBC, 
2 units FFP, panoprazole 40 mg IV X 1, and vit K 10 mg IV X 1. 
Given elevated venous lactate, a CTA abd/pelvis was performed 
that showed no signs of mesenteric ischemia, bibasilar lung 
opacities, non-specific bilateral perinephric stranding possibly 
related to renal failure, and ascites, pericholecystic fluid, 
and RV enlargement suggestive of R sided heart failure. She was 
seen by GI consult and admitted to the MICU for further care.  
.
In the MICU, GI performed EGD and noted esophagitis/gastritis 
and to have large clot in stomach but no active bleeding. 
Hematocrit nadir was 27, transfused 2 units w/ appropriate 
increase. Reversed anticoagulation w/ vitamin K, now on heparin 
gtt as INR<2 w/o new bleeding. Also patient noted to have a 
history of interstitial lung disease (f/b Dr. ___ and 
does not have home O2 but currently w/ O2 requirement s/p IVF 
resuscitation on arrival given hypovolemic hypotension in 
setting of bleed. Her O2 requirement has been lessening w/ 
diuresis. The morning of transfer, the patient was noticed to be 
slightly confused and does have a h/o sundowing. A head CT was 
negative for bleed and then found +U/A so started ciprofloxacin 
which was changed to ceftriaxone for concerns of deleriogenesis. 

.
Please see the following problem list for the pt's course once 
called out to the medical floor:
.
*) Increasing O2 requirement: Likely ___ volume overload from 
diastolic heart failure in combination with known interstitial 
lung disease. s/p echo ___ with EF 60-70%. Pt received IV lasix 
to a goal of -1.5L for approx 5 days and was transitioned to PO 
lasix when no longer exhibited signs of fluid overload. She 
continued to have a fluctuating O2 requirement and NC was 
titrated to >93%. On discharge, patient was satting well on 2L 
off of lasix.
.
*) Upper GI bleed: In setting of supratherapeutic INR. s/p 2u 
pRBC. Resolved and Hct stable s/p transfusion and Vit K. EGD 
with esophagitis, gastritis, clot but no acute bleeding. 
Continued BID protonix. Daily hcts were stable and increased 
throughout stay.  
.  
*) Anti-Coagulation/MVR - Patient on IV heparin with goal 50-70 
for anticogagulation for MVR. Initially on coumadin 2mg QD, 
which was eventually increased to her home regimen of 10mg 
___ and 15mg ___. On discharge, INR was 3.1 and heparin gtt 
discontinued. Patient to have close follow up with ___ 
Clinic.
.
*) Confusion/dementia: Pt with occasional severe agitation. Last 
episode ___ AM (pulled out IVs, refusing PO meds and O2NC). 
Likely secondary to underlying dementia/sundowning. Pt received 
zyprexa and haldol prn. Per daughter, this is her baseline.
.  
*) Acute on chronic renal failure: Prerenal, baseline Cr 
1.4-1.6. Followed Cr daily. On discharge, creatinine was 1.5.
.  
*) Cardiac - EF 60-70%. Continued metoprolol and transitioned to 
XL. Lisinopril was decreased as BPs were low normal. Continued 
statin.
.
*) UTI: Pt received cipro x 3d. Cx negative.
.  
*) s/p MVR - Mechanical valve. Heparin as above.  
.  
*) Hypothryoidism - Continued synthroid at home doses. TSH 0.68, 
free T4 normal.  
.  
*) DM II - Continue ISS while in house, but pt with little 
requirement. D/C'd on HD#12. Restarted metformin 1 day prior to 
discharge.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old female admitted to the hospital with  abdominal 
pain, nausea, and elevated white blood cell count.  Upon 
admission, the patient was made NPO, given intravenous fluids, 
and underwent imaging which showed perforated appendicitis. She 
was started on a course of antibiotics ceftriaxone and flagyl 
and underwent serial abdominal examinations. 

The patient was taken to the operating room on HD # 3 where she 
underwent a laparoscopic appendectomy.  Intra-operative findings 
were notable for acute perforated appendicitis with phlegmon and 
an abscess.  There was a 100 cc blood loss.  The patient was 
extubated after the procedure and monitored in the recovery 
room.  

During the post-operative course, she was febrile with an 
elevated white blood cell count. Her surgical pain was 
controlled with intravenous analgesia. Because of the 
temperature spikes, the patient underwent a cat scan of the 
abdomen on POD #5 and she was reported to have a right lower 
quadrant collection.  She was taken to interventional radiology 
where a drain was placed. Her abdominal pain persisted and she 
underwent another cat scan of the abdomen which showed an 
additional fluid collection posterior to the uterus.  She 
returned to ___ on POD #11 where another drain was placed.  Over 
the next ___ hours her white blood cell count began to normalize. 
 She continued on her course of ceftriaxone and flagyl.  

The patient was discharged home on POD #14.  Her antibiotics 
were discontinued and her white blood cell count was stable at 
11. She was transitioned to oral analgesia and was voiding 
without difficulty.  She had return of bowel function.  Her 
vital signs were stable and she was afebrile.  Discharge 
instructions were reviewed and questions answered.  A follow-up 
appointment was made in the Acute care clinic.

+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

Of note, during the patient's hospitalization, she noted a left 
leg lesion.  The Dermatology service was consulted and advised 
removal of the lesion.  An appointment was made for follow-up by 
the Dermatology service.   They will call the patient with the 
time and place of the appointment.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You were admitted to the hospital with abdominal pain and found 
to have a perforation in your appendix. You were given IV 
antibiotics but continued to have pain and signs and symptoms of 
infection. You were taken to the operating room to have your 
appendix removed laparoscopically, and the infection washout out 
of your abdomen. After surgery, you continued to an elevation in 
your white blood cell count.  On imaging, you were reported to 
have fluid collections in your abdomen for which drains were 
placed.  Since then, your white blood cell count and your pain 
has decreased.  You continue on antibiotics.  Your are preparing 
for discharge home with ___ services for drain care assistance 
with the following instructions:

Please follow up at the appointment in clinic listed below. We 
also generally recommend that patients follow up with their 
primary care provider after having surgery. We have scheduled an 
appointment for you listed below.
ACTIVITY:
 
Do not drive until you have stopped taking pain medicine and 
feel you could respond in an emergency.
You may climb stairs. 
You may go outside, but avoid traveling long distances until you 
see your surgeon at your next visit.
Don't lift more than ___ lbs for ___ weeks. (This is about the 
weight of a briefcase or a bag of groceries.) This applies to 
lifting children, but they may sit on your lap.
You may start some light exercise when you feel comfortable.
You will need to stay out of bathtubs or swimming pools for a 
time while your incision is healing. Ask your doctor when you 
can resume tub baths or swimming.
 
HOW YOU MAY FEEL: 
You may feel weak or "washed out" a couple weeks. You might want 
to nap often. Simple tasks may exhaust you.
You may have a sore throat because of a tube that was in your 
throat during surgery.
You could have a poor appetite for a couple days. Food may seem 
unappealing.
All of these feelings and reactions are normal and should go 
away in a short time.  If they do not, tell your surgeon.
 
YOUR INCISION:
Tomorrow you may shower and remove the gauzes over your 
incisions. Under these dressings you have small plastic bandages 
called steristrips. Do not remove steri-strips for 2 weeks. 
(These are the thin paper strips that might be on your 
incision.) But if they fall off before that that's okay.
Your incisions may be slightly red around the stitches. This is 
normal.
You may gently wash away dried material around your incision.
Avoid direct sun exposure to the incision area.
Do not use any ointments on the incision unless you were told 
otherwise.
You may see a small amount of clear or light red fluid staining 
your dressing or clothes. If the staining is severe, please call 
your surgeon.
You may shower. As noted above, ask your doctor when you may 
resume tub baths or swimming.
 
YOUR BOWELS:
Constipation is a common side effect of narcotic pain 
medicaitons. If needed, you may take a stool softener (such as 
Colace, one capsule) or gentle laxative (such as milk of 
magnesia, 1 tbs) twice a day. You can get both of these 
medicines without a prescription.
If you go 48 hours without a bowel movement, or have pain moving 
the bowels, call your surgeon. 
 
PAIN MANAGEMENT:
It is normal to feel some discomfort/pain following abdominal 
surgery. This pain is often described as "soreness". 
Your pain should get better day by day. If you find the pain is 
getting worse instead of better, please contact your surgeon.
You will receive a prescription for pain medicine to take by 
mouth. It is important to take this medicine as directed. Do not 
take it more frequently than prescribed. Do not take more 
medicine at one time than prescribed. Do not drink alcohol or 
drive while taking narcotic pain medication.
Your pain medicine will work better if you take it before your 
pain gets too severe.
Talk with your surgeon about how long you will need to take 
prescription pain medicine. Please don't take any other pain 
medicine, including non-prescription pain medicine, unless your 
surgeon has said its okay.
If you are experiencing no pain, it is okay to skip a dose of 
pain medicine.
Remember to use your "cough pillow" for splinting when you cough 
or when you are doing your deep breathing exercises.
If you experience any of the following, please contact your 
surgeon:
- sharp pain or any severe pain that lasts several hours
- pain that is getting worse over time
- pain accompanied by fever of more than 101
- a drastic change in nature or quality of your pain
 
MEDICATIONS:
Take all the medicines you were on before the operation just as 
you did before, unless you have been told differently.
If you have any questions about what medicine to take or not to 
take, please call your surgeon.
 
DANGER SIGNS:
Please call your surgeon if you develop:
- worsening abdominal pain
- sharp or severe pain that lasts several hours
- temperature of 101 degrees or higher
- severe diarrhea
- vomiting
- redness around the incision that is spreading
- increased swelling around the incision
- excessive bruising around the incision
- cloudy fluid coming from the wound
- bright red blood or foul smelling discharge coming from the 
wound
- an increase in drainage from the wound

You will also need to follow-up with Dermatology to have 
excision of lesion left lower leg.
 
 
 
 
  
  
  
 
.
.
.
. 

You are now doing better, tolerating a regular diet and ready to 
be discharged home to continue your recovery.

Ms. ___ is a ___ with history of recent appendectomy for 
perforated appendicitis on ___ complicated by

discharged ___, who re-presented to the ___ ED this 
admission with ___ days of abdominal pain.  CT scan demonstrated

clear abnormality of the adjacent bowel, no drainable 
collection, bowel obstruction, or drainable fluid collections.  
She was admitted to the Acute Care Surgery service for serial 
abdominal exams and she was made NPO with IV fluid. 

On HD2, her abdominal pain improved, but she remained tender to 
palpation in the LUQ.  She passed flatus.  She had a repeat CT 
abdomen/pelvis which demonstrated  persistent mild inflammatory 
wall thickening of the cecum and surrounding soft tissues in the 
right lower quadrant.  A c.diff toxin was sent which came back 
positive.  PO vancomycin was initiated.  The patient's abdominal 
pain improved.  Her diet was advanced to a regular diet which 
she tolerated.

and hemodynamically stable.  The patient was tolerating a diet, 
ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.  The patient received discharge teaching and 
follow-up instructions with understanding verbalized and 
agreement with the discharge plan.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You were admitted to the hospital with abdominal pain and had 
abdominal/pelvic CT scans showing mild inflammation of your 
colon.  You tested positive for clostridium difficile, a 
bacteria in the colon, which can lead to bowel inflammation and 
diarrhea.  You were started on a medication, called Vancomycin, 
to treat this bacterial infection.  You are now tolerating a 
regular diet and are ready to be discharged from the hospital.

Please note the following discharge instructions:

Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the 
Emergency Department for any of the following:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.
*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.
*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience a discharge.
*Your pain in not improving within ___ hours or is not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or 
back.
*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern 
you.

Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed.

Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times 
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. Avoid lifting 
weights greater than ___ lbs until you follow-up with your 
surgeon.
Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain 
medications.

bridged with heparin to a therapeutic INR on warfarin and 
underwent TEE/cardioversion with successful converstion to sinus 
rhythm. However, after cardioversion, pt developed >4.5 sec 
sinus pauses and bradycardia to ___. For this reason, she was 
not discharged on a beta blocker. She was set up to have an 
event monitor, with a plan to start low dose metoprolol 
succinate if she no longer has sinus pauses. INR was 3.6 on day 
of discharge; pt was prescribed warfarin 1mg, with instructions 
to hold the warfarin until INR check at ___ 
___ clinic on the day after discharge. 

# sinus pauses: occurred overnight after cardioversion, >4.5 
sec, asymptomatic. Unclear if these pauses occurred while 
patient was lying supine; she was not wearing CPAP at the time. 
Differential includes OSA vs. excessive nodal blockade vs. sick

was counseled on the importance of CPAP for preventing sinus

fibrillation. Betablockade was held as above. Pt observed for 24
