Discharge Instructions:
It was a pleasure to take care of you during your stay at ___. 
You came in with shortness of breath and were found to have an 
abnormal fast heart rhythm called atrial fibrillation. We were 
unable to slow down your heart rate with medicines, so we 
scheduled you for an echocardiogram (ultrasound of the heart) 
which showed no clot, and then shocked the heart. This 
successfully converted your heart back to normal rhythm. 

You had a little extra fluid on your body from your heart not 
pumping efficiently while it was in Afib. We diuresed you with 
lasix and will be sending you home a small dose of lasix 20mg to 
take daily at home.

After the conversion, you had some very long pauses of your 
heart beat. Because of this we want you to wear a heart rhythm 
monitor for ___ weeks at home, to make sure you are not having 
more pauses, and also monitor if you go back into Afib. ___ 
___ will be in touch with you about this heart monitor, 
which you will receive at home in the mail within 3 business 
days.

We discussed the importance of wearing your CPAP to prevent 
converting back to Afib, and also to prevent the pauses we 
observed. Talk to your PCP about getting reconnected to a sleep 
center to keep your CPAP machine maintained and make sure you 
have the best-fitting mask.

When people are in atrial fibrillation, they are at risk of 
developing clots in the heart, which can break off and cause a 
stroke. To prevent this risk, you will need to take a blood 
thinner called warfarin, in case you go back into atrial 
fibrillation.  You will have to get your INR (a measure of how 
thin your blood is) checked regularly with the ___ 
clinic at ___ to make sure you are on the right 
dose of warfarin. You should get your INR checked tomorrow, 
___.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is an ___ y/o woman with a past medical history of 
chronic kidney injury (stage V), chronic anemia (EPO-dependent), 
CAD, HFpEF, HTN, and T2DM, who presented with shortness of 
breath, chest discomfort, and dizziness with blood pressures 
>200/90. 

# HFpEF exacerbation | Hypertensive Urgency | Volume Overload:
Initial concern for pneumonia, given possible retrocardiac 
opacity on plain film; however, final read of CXR negative for 
new infiltrate. Influenza negative. Cough with subjective fevers 
at home without leukocytosis. Exam and work-up suggestive of 
volume overload in the setting of diastolic HF and end-stage 
renal disease. TTE showed severe diastolic dysfunction, but no 
significant change from prior. She had minimal troponinemia 
without ischemic EKG changes attributed by cardiology to demand 
and poor renal clearance. Patient was initially started on IV 
hydralazine and nitroglycerin drip and continued on her home 
blood pressure medications (isosorbide 
mononitrate/carvedilol/doxazosin) for blood pressure lowering 
and aggressive diuresis with IV furosemide (80-120mg). She 
diuresed well, with improvement in her shortness of breath and 
lower extremity edema. Renal was consulted and recommended slow 
blood pressure lowering with permissive hypertension and target 
SBP 160s in the first few days with avoidance of DBP lowering 
below the ___. She was subsequently weaned off the nitroglycerin 
drip and the hydralazine and started on amlodipine 5mg daily, 
with improved blood pressure control. Dizziness, which was not 
accompanied by focal neurologic deficits, resolved with improved 
antihypertensive control. At discharge, her blood pressure was 
120-150s/50-60s. She also was started on torsemide 20mg PO daily 
for maintenance diuresis.

# Right Knee Gout: 
Patient developed right knee swelling on ___ in the setting of 
aggressive diuresis. The knee joint was aspirated and sent for 
gram stain, culture, cell counts, and crystal analysis. Crystal 
analysis was consistent with negatively birefringent MSU 
crystals. After a negative gram stain and 36h with negative 
cultures, the knee joint was injected with 40mg of 
methylprednisolone, given limited treatment options otherwise 
(NSAIDs, colchicine suboptimal due to ESRD, systemic prednisone 
suboptimal due to hypertension and fluid overload). Knee X-ray 
showed enlarged joint space and diffuse small lucencies 
throughout visualized bones, with periarticular spurring. MRI 
was obtained and showed changes consistent with osteopenia with 
no concern for malignancy.

# Acute-on-chronic normocytic anemia:
Likely in the setting of ESRD. No evidence of hemolytic anemia. 
Guaiac negative x3. Received 2U of pRBCs for nadir Hgb of 6.6 
for Hgb threshold of 9 per nephrology, with appropriate 
improvement in Hgb. Continued ferrous sulfate 325 mg daily.

# Thrombocytopenia: Platelet count nadired in the 130s, likely 
due to physiologic stress and brief antibiotic treatment on 
admission, normalized prior to discharge without dedicated 
intervention.

# Acute-on-chronic kidney injury (stage V):
Mild elevation of BUN/Cr compared to baseline. At baseline, she 
has declined HD in the past. Most likely cardiorenal in 
etiology, given severe diastolic dysfunction and fluid overload 
on exam in the setting of severe hypertension. FeUrea consistent 
with intrinsic renal disease, which is expected given her stage 
V chronic kidney injury. Nephrology consulted, and patient did 
not need urgent dialysis. Cr remained 4.3 at discharge, likely 
her new baseline in the setting of diuresis.

# Strep bovis bacteriuria: She was found to have asymptomatic 
Strep bovis bacteriuria without pyuria. Antibiotic treatment was 
deferred due to absence of symptoms and lack of clear true UTI. 

CHRONIC ISSUES
# CAD
- continued aspirin 81 mg daily
- continued pravastatin 20 mg qPM
- continued isosorbide mononitrate 60 mg daily

# T2DM
- Humalog insulin sliding scale and glargine 10 units qhs
- held glipizide and sitagliptin

# GERD
- continued pantoprazole 40 mg q24h

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

It was a pleasure taking care of you. You were admitted to the 
___ because you were short of 
breath and your blood pressure was very elevated. This was 
thought to be related to a large amount of fluid that your body 
had accumulated because of your heart failure and your kidney 
problems. We gave you the same medication in your water pills at 
home, but in intravenous form, which helped improve your 
breathing and lower your blood pressure. We also made changes to 
your home blood pressure medication regimen to ensure that your 
blood pressure remains under control.

While you were in the hospital, you developed right knee pain 
and swelling. We took a small sample of the fluid in your knee 
and analyzed it and found out that you had condition known as 
gout. Gout is due to crystals accumulating in your joints. You 
were treated with a steroid injection in the knee with good 
results. 

Wishing you a speedy recovery,
Your ___ Care Team

not walk. She came to ED for evaluation. No F/C. No N/V/D or

Brief Hospital Course:
A/P: ___ y/o female with a PMH of HTN, hyperlipidemia, and breast 
cancer who presented to the ED s/p mechanical fall and was found 
to be hypoxic.   
.  
# s/p mechanical fall: In the emergency department the patient 
had a plain film done of her left hip as well as CT scan of the 
pelvis which showed no evidence of fracture. She did have some 
initial improvement in her hip pain with addition of Percocet 
and tramadol as needed, however still had some unsteadiness on 
her feet due to pain. The physical therapy team evaluated her 
and felt that she would be safest to go to a rehabilitation 
facility to rebuild her strength before going home. She 
continued to improve with each physical therapy session.
.
# Hypoxia: The patient was noted to have an O2 sat of <85% on RA 
on the ED and was started on 4L O2 NC. This was then weaned to 
2L. On room air she repeatedly had O2 sats between 85-88% and 
<88% upon ambulation on room air. Upon review of the records 
this appears to be a common occurrence upon hospitalization that 
she has been hypoxic and requiring oxygen. She however, has been 
completely asymptomatic related to this. She had a CTA which 
showed no evidence of PE, but did show evidence of diffuse 
emphysema which was in accordance with what was seen on prior 
CTA a year ago. As a result she was scheduled for follow-up in 
___ clinic with Dr. ___ at the end of ___. She 
remained asymptomatic throughout her hospital stay.
.  
# UTI: Pt was asymptomatic, however had a urinalysis revealing 
many WBCs in her urine upon arrival to the emergency department. 
She was initially treated with levofloxacin and then switched to 
ciprofloxacin for a total of a three day course. She would 
benefit from repeat U/A and culture after discharge given a 
history of frequent UTIs in the past and episode of urosepsis on 
past admission requiring ICU care.
.  
# Acute renal failure: Pt with a rise in creatinine from 1.0 to 
1.3 on day of discharge. Her HCTZ was held and she was 
encouraged to drink plenty of liquids. This level should be 
checked upon discharge and she may need IV hydration if unable 
to take enough po for likely prerenal etiology.
.
# HTN: She had good blood pressure control with SBPs in 
120s-140. She was continued on home amlodipine, metoprolol and 
valsartan. 
.  
# Type II DM: She was continued on her home dose of glipizide 
and monitored with Humalog sliding scale infrequently as needed.

Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital after a fall for left hip pain 
and unsteadiness on your feet. You had a CT scan of your hip 
which showed no evidence of break or fracture and you most 
likely suffered a bad bruise. You were treated with Percocet to 
help with your pain and you were evaluated by the physical 
therapy team who felt that you would benefit from a short stay 
in a rehabilitation facility.
.
Also, while you were in the hospital you were found to have a 
low oxygen saturation in your blood. You had a CT scan of your 
chest which showed no blood clot in your lungs or lung mass, but 
did show evidence of emphysema. You have been scheduled to see a 
pulmonologist (lung specialist) for further evaluation and might 
be recommended to use home oxygen or take a medication to help 
protect your lungs.
.
If you experience worsening leg pain, fall, swelling, feel 
unsteady on your feet, difficulty breathing, chest pain, leg 
pain or swelling, upon discharge seek immediate medical 
attention.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ F with history of CKD, dementia, HTN, DMII, presenting from 
clinic with worsening hypertension, altered mental status and 
acute renal failure.

# Delirium - the patient was found to be delirious on admission. 
 Initial workup, including blood work, cultures and head CT scan 
was negative.  A paronychia of her right large toe was found 
which was drained; pain from the paronychia may have contributed 
to her initial delirium. Geriatrics was consulted, and the 
patient received supportive measures such as better pain 
control, a bowel regimen and attempts to preserve her sleep wake 
cycle.  She was agitated at times, and responded poorly to 
olanzapine but did improve with daily seroquel 6.25 at night, 
which was later increased to 12.5 to help improve her sleep/wake 
cycle.  A urinalysis was later re-checked which did demonstrate 
a urinary tract infection and she was treated with IV 
ceftriaxone for 3 days. Finally, her delirium might have been 
worsened by constipation, which was treated with disimpaction.

# Urinatry tract infection - treated as above.

# Hypertension - the patient had a blood pressure elevated with 
systolic pressures in the 200s at clinic prior to admission.  
She was continued on valsartan and amlodipine, and hydralazine 
10mg bid was added to her regimen, resulting in good blood 
pressure control.

# Diabetes - the patient was not on any oral anti-hyperglycemics 
on admission as her PCP had discontinued these 3 weeks prior.  
She was started on a humalog sliding scale and lantus.

#Acute renal failure - This resolved quickly with IV fluids. 

#Code status: The patient was confirmed to be DNR/DNI with the 
family.

#Transition of care issues: Geriatrics recommended discontinuing 
the rosuvastatin and omeprazole if they are not needed.  This 
should be discussed with the patient's primary care provider.

___ with history of CML with new fatigue who was found to have

# Accelerated phase CML: Patient was anemic on admission and 
transfused.  It was decided that patient should undergo 
myeloablative induction for possible allogeneic stem cell 
transplant.  Patient started induction chemotherapy on ___ 
with cytarabine and idarubicin (7+3) according to protocol.  Her 
dasatinib was held.  Her ANC nadir was ___. Her course was 
complicated by fevers for which she was started on vancomycin 
and cefepime and her PICC line was removed.  Blood cultures, 
urine cultures and stool cultures remained negative. She 
developed a diffuse rash, and dermatology was consulted.  It was 
felt that this may have been a drug rash related to cefepime, 
vancomycin or hydralazine and she was treated with topical 
steroids.  Hydralazine and cefepime were stopped and aztreonam 
was started.  She spiked a temperature of 101 on ___ and 
aztreonam was changed to meropenem.  She defervesced and 
remained afebile for the remainder of her hospitalization.  
Cultures remained negative.  Her ___ recovered to 1829 on 
___.  A pre transplant work up was completed as an inpatient, 
including infectious disease consultation and dental 
consultation.

# History of CAD: Patient was continued on her home dose of 
statin.  She was ruled out for myocardial infarction with serial 
cardiac biomarkers.  Her metoprolol was uptitrated during this 
admission due to hypertension and she was discharged on 100 mg 
PO tid. 

# HTN: Patient was initially started on her home dose of 
metoprolol.  She had several episodes of elevated blood pressure 
and her metoprolol was uptitrated to 100mg PO tid.  She was 
started on hydralazine, but it was later stopped ___ drug rash.  
She was started on valsartan 80mg PO daily, with improved 
control of her blood pressure.

periodically transfused with PRBCs to maintain her hematocrit 
above 25 and platelets to maintain her platelets above 10.  
 
# FEN: Neutropenic diet, Mg, K and Phos were repleted by 
protocol.

Brief Hospital Course:
#. Accelerated Phase Chronic Myeloid Leukemia: Patient was 
treated with busulfan/cytoxan conditioning per protocol.  She 
experienced some nausea and emesis which was controlled with 
zofran.  Stem cell transplant was performed. Her course was 
complicated by neutropenic fever and she was treated with 
antibiotics. She remained culture negative. She developed 
esophagitis and was found to be negative for CMV but esophaheal 
biopsy suggested esophageal GHVD and also had evidence of skin 
GHVD. She received a tapered course of steroids and improved. 
She also developed intense headaches while she was 
thrombocytopenic. Head CT showed no acute intracranial 
hemorrhage or mass effect, with a few vague dense areas noted in 
the brainstem/posterior fossa, likely being artifactual. Her 
headaches resolved. She was discharged to the oncology 
apartments and will follow closely with the ___ and 
her primary oncologist.
.
#. Hypertension.  On admission, patients metoprolol was 
continued but her valsartan was held out of concern for renal 
toxicity with chemotherapy.  Her blood pressure trended up 
during her conditioning and her metoprolol dose was increased. 
Subsequently nifedipine was also added and she was discharged on 
nifedpine and metoprolol with good blood pressure control. She 
had serial EKGs performed given her cardiac history, and her 
cardiac status should continue to be monitored as an outpatient. 


.

Brief Hospital Course:
#N/V/D: the pt p/w reported having several loose stools and 
sporadic vomiting throughout the past week prior to 
presentation. She also reported decreased po intake since 
___ with accompanying nausea/vomiting. Additionally, pt had 
hx suggestive of upper GI GVHD. She was started empirically on 
methylprednisolone 30 mg IV BID, in addition to her Budensonide 
3 mg PO TID, and cyclosporine 125 mg IV q12 for possible GVH 
colitis. Zofran and omeprazole were ordered for her 
nausea/vomiting.  Stools were sent for o&p, bact cultures, viral 
cultures, and clostridium difficile toxin.  Due to her 
continuing diarrhea, CT abdomen done on HD3 which showed 
uncomplicated ileocolitis with continuous involvement of distal 
ileum up to proximal transverse colon just beyond the hepatic 
flexure, suggestive of graft versus host disease or 
infectious/inflammatory etiologies.  The pt. was placed NPO on 
HD3 for colonoscopy, but given her poor PO intake while in the 
hospital, was evaluated and started on TPN by HD4.   While on 
the high dose steroids, the pt's diarrhea did not improve much, 
and she wast started on empiric abx therapy with metronidazole  
500 mg IV qday and levofloxacin 750 mg IV qday (as she was 
allergic to cefepime/possibly penicillins) on HD4.  Stool 
studies all came back negative for infectious etiologies of her 
diarrhea.  Bx results from her colonoscopy were negative for CMV 
but positive for severe graft versus host colitis throughout the 
colon.  Her antibiotics were discontinued, and she was started 
on mycophenolate mofetil 1000 mg po BID and her cyclosporine was 
increased from 175 mg po BID to ___ qAM/qHS.  Her 
diarrhea began to improve, TPN was dc'd on HD 9, and she was 
discharged home on HD12 on CSA, MMF, and IV methylprednisolone 
for control of her GVH colitis.  
.  
#Hx of CML s/p alloSCT: she was continued on immunosuppressive 
therapy per above.  Additionally, she was continued on ppx 
therapy with changes in her home fluconazole to PO voriconazole 
___ concern of hepatic interaction, continuation of her 
Acyclovir 400 mg q12hr, Sulfameth/Trimethoprim DS 1 TAB PO MWF, 
and ursodiol 300 mg BID.  No further issues were encountered 
during her hospital stay.  She was discharghed home on 
acyclovir, and voriconazole.  SMX/TMP was held due to 
administration of pentamidine while in house.  Will f/u with her 
hematologist/oncologist as an outpatient for adjustment of her 
medications.
.  
#Hx of HTN: pt. had a hx of intractable htn while on 
cyclophosphamide.  Blood pressures were elevated in the 130-160 
SBP range while in house.  She was continued on her home 
nefidipine CR 90mg qday, and metoprolol tartrate 50 mg PO BID 
and discharged home on these medications. 
.
# Hx of hypomagnesemia:  secondary to CSA use.  Put on sliding 
scale magnesium repletion while in house.   Discharged on 
Magnesium oxide-Magnesium AA chelate 133 mg po TID.

Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital due to nausea, vomiting, and 
diarrhea for several days duration.  You had a CT scan of you 
abdomen which showed inflammation.  You were given medications 
for a possible infection in your colon for several days, as well 
as medications for possible Graft Versus Host Disease of the 
colon.  You were evaluated by colon specialists 
(gastroenterologists) who performed a procedure to look at the 
inside of you colon and take biopsies (colonoscopy).  It was 
determined that your diarrhea was NOT from an infection, but due 
to Graft-Versus-Host-Disease (a complication that can happen in 
people with allogenic stem cell transplants).  You were placed 
on large doses of immunosuppressants (Methylprednisolone, 
Cyclosporin, Mycophenolate Mofetil, and Budenoside) to stop your 
immune system from attacking your colon.  Your diarrhea began to 
improve, you were placed on a full low bacteria diet, and 
discharged from the hospital.
.

can be cut in half, take ___ a pill 2x a day.  If it cannot, DO 
NOT TAKE THIS MEDICATION****** 
.

___ with CML, s/p allogeneic SCT D 163 (on discharge) with 
post-transplant period complicated by upper and lower GI GVH 
(biopsy ___, s/p treatment with steroids, currently on 
cyclosporin 50 in am, 25 in pm and atovaquone, who presents with 
persistent nausea, vomitting, and diarrhea. Anemic on 
presentation and transfused 2 units of RCC and following a 
seemingly inadequate response on lab tests received a further 2 
units. Started on IV methylprednisolone for ? GVHD and converted

.
#Nausea, vomiting and diarrhea: Presented with 5 days of 
symptoms which were improving on admission. For concerns of GVHD 
(see previous history) she was started on IV methylprednisolone 
30mg bid and this was converted to an oral prednisone taper 
following resolution of symptoms by the day after admission. PRN 
ondansetron for nausea. She was found to have moderate LeukE on 
UA although there were only 3WBCs on urine microscopy. She was 
commenced on a 3-day course of oral levofloxacin for her UTI 
(note sensitive to ciprofloxacin on sensitivity testing). Stool 
cultures were negative.
.
#Anemia: She was noted to have a Hb/Hct of 7.1/20.2 in clinic 
and was transfused 2 units RCC. Post transfusion HCt was only 
20.5 (cause unclear) and she received a further 2 units RCC with 
post transfusion labs Hb 9.9 HCt 29.1. Retic count was suitably 
elevated for degree of anemia and other hemolysis screen was 
negative.
.
# CML #/p stem cell transplant: continue acyclovir 400 mg Tablet 
q8 and atovaquone [Mepron] 750 mg/5 mL Suspension 10 ml by mouth 
daily. Will follow with Dr ___ on ___.
.
# Possible GVHD: Her symptoms were thought to perhaps represent 
mild GVHD although the presence of a UTI may be the cause. She 
was started on a IV methylprednisolone and converted to an oral 
steroid taper. Her cyclosporin dose was increased to 50mg am 
75mg pm following a low cyclosporin level of <30. Continued 
budesonide.
.
#Elevated LFTs: She was noted to have deranged LFTs on admission 
which were not present on previous laboratory testing. There was 
evidence of a transaminitis and increased during admission. She 
will have her blood repeated on ___ with results faxed to Dr 
___.
.
# Likely peripheral neuropathy: Tingling in hands and feet, 
absent AJs and decreased temp sensation to mid shins 
bilaterally. Likely secondary to chemo.
.

nifedipine [Nifediac CC] 90 mg Tablet Sustained Release DAILY

Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old woman with CML, s/p MRD allo SCT ___ with 
Busulfan/Cyclophosphamide. Her post-transplant course was 
complicated with GVH of the upper and lower GI tract that 
required hopitalization for IV steroids and increased 
immunosuppression. She was admitted for investigation of 
worsening LFTs. She was treated with high dose IV 
methylprednisolone, oral Mycophenolate mofetil and increasing 
cyclosporin doses. She quickly developed symptoms suggestive of 
GI GVHD with cramping ___ pain, nausea and vomiting. LFTs 
worsened during admission but she did not necessitate a liver 
biopsy due to considerable improvement in these following 
increased immunosuppression. The general picture was that of 
severe multi-organ GVHD. Her GI symptoms worsened with abdominal 
pain and profuse watery diarrhea and she had a CT scan which 
demonstrtaed confluent small bowel enteritis. At this point she 
was placed on bowel rest and administered TPN. GVHD was 
confirmed at endoscopy and biopsy where mucosa was noted to be 
friable and extensively ulcerated in keeping with severe GVHD. 
Her cyclosporin was titrated up and her symptoms improved 
although diarrhea persisted despite a considerable period of 
bowel rest on TPN. Her Hb/HCt had been slowly falling and her 
stool was found to be guaiac +ve felt likely 2o to her bowel 
inflammation. She was found to have a swollen left arm shortly 
after a PICC line was placed and there was evidence of an 
extensive LUE DVT extending to the subclavian vein. This was 
treated conservatively as anticoagulation was felt to be 
inadvisable in the setting of her continued bowel inflamation 
and guaiac +ve stools. Due to problmes of low cyclosporin levels 
her cyclosporina nd mycophenolate were changed to IV on ___. 
WBC count progressively dropped ? cause and she may need a bone 
marrow biopsy soon if her counts do not improve. She was 
continued on IV methylprednisolone mycophenolate and cyclosporin 
w/continued TPN for bowel rest. Blood glucoses high and 
titrating up insulin in TPN in addition to addingNPH low dose 
BID on ___. Gradually, diarrhea improved and pt was able to be 
transitioned slowly to PO medications. Levels of cyclosporin 
were monitored to ensure therapuetic range and absorptions. 
Slowly pt's diet was also advanced and at discharge pt was off 
TPN. Closes follow-up was planned on ___.
.
# Rising LFTs:  This was found to be liver GVHD.  Progressively 
settling following GVHD treatment. Mildly elevated on previous 
admission in week prior to current admission. She was initially 
asymptomatic although latterly developed severe diarrhea, nausea 
and vomiting. Her steroids initially oral prednisone were 
increased to IVMP 30mg bid and cyclosporin was gradually 
uptitrated. She had ___ U/S ___ which showed focal fatty 
infiltrate and nil else. Bil rose from 1.6 on ___ and 
transaminases were progressively rising. MRCP on ___ showed 
hemosiderosis of liver and spleen, thickening of duodenum and 
___ jejunum in keeping with inflammatory/infectious etiology 
and a small stone in GB. Seen by hepatology ___ and lab 
investigations for vit D,  Hep B/C/Adeno/CMV/HHV6/EBV PCRs, Hep 
A Ab, HSV Ab. These all came back -ve save vit D level which was 
low and seh was sterted on vitamin D supplementation. Put on 
bowel rest and started on TPN. Bil rose from 1.6 to 5.7 on ___ 
with improved transaminases. By repeat on ___ Bil level had 
dropped to 5.1 and by ___ Bil dropped to 2.9 with improved 
transaminases. She therefore did not go for liver bx. LFTs 
continued to trend down with high levels of immunosuppression. 
Slowly immunosuppression was titrated down and LFTs remained 
stable as diarrhea continued to improve. Transition to PO 
fluconazole resulted in rise in LFTs w/out evidence of other 
worsening GVHD symptoms so pt was restarted on home 
voriconazole. LFTs will continued to be monitored as meds are 
titrated on an outpt basis.
.
# CML: s/p allo SCT. She continues to recover from her 
transplant. Guaiac +ve stol ___ and transfused 1 unit 
___. Transfusion goal HCt >25 Plt >20. 
.
# GVHD ___ pain, nausea and  vomiting and elevated LFTs): 
Previous significant upper and lower GI GVHD. She ws found on 
this admission to again have severe GVHD in his case involving 
the small bowel and liver. On admission she was started on IV 
methylpred 30mg bid. Whilst she was asymptomatic on admission, 
she quickly developed abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting felt 
likely to be GVHD. Increased cyclosporin to 75mg bid, added 
mycophenolate 500mg bid and voriconazole 200mg bid on ___. 
Increased mycophenolate to 1g bid on ___. Cyclosporin 119 and 
increased cyclosporin to 100mg bid ___ then 125mg bid ___. As 
high level changed to 125/100 on ___. Cyclopsorin increased to 
125mg bid ___ and 150mg bid ___ due to persistently low 
levels and felt that this was likely due to poor absorption from 
the gut. SShe had suprapubic tenderness with diarrhea as of ___ 
- NOT peritonitic. Initially felt to be ? inadequately treated 
UTI (Enterobacter in UCx in week prior and Rx levo for 3 days). 
Rpt UA and UCx were -ve. Started on oral cipro ___.. Due to 
diarrhea was changed to IV cipro/metronidazole ___. MRI showed 
duodenitis/jejunitis ? infectious ? inflammatory. Supportive IV 
fluids where given and then TPN was started for nutritional 
support. High stool output. Seen by GI ___ who recommended 
stool studies which were negative. Changed Abx to IV meropenem 
___. ___ ___ showed small bowel enteritis 
encompassing most of small bowel with no dilatation. UGIE and bx 
___ showed abnormal, friable mucosa throughout approximately 
75% of the duodenum which was denuded with a shiny erythematous 
base and could be consistent with known history of GVHD. IV 
meropenem stopped ___. Awaiting CMV immunostaining. EBV 20 
copies and was repeated ___ and was not amplifyable although 
the sample was slightly hemolysed. She symptomatically improved 
although had persistent diarrhea despite bowel rest. She was 
treated with loperamide. Gradually symptoms improved and pt was 
able to be transition from IV meds to PO meds and diet advanced 
slowly while TPN continued until pt was able to tolerated PO 
diet at a sufficient level to maintain calorie needs. At time of 
d/c TPN had been stopped and pt was taking only POs.
.

# L UE DVT: Swollen L arm post PICC insertion. Had U/S and 
doppler ___ which showed edema but no hematoma or localised 
edema but repeat U/S showed Left Basilic DVT ___.  PICC was 
removed on ___. She did not receive anticoagulation given low 
Plts, guaiac +ve stool and significant ulceration on bx 
suggestive of continued significant bowel inflammation. Later pt 
had some intermittent residual swelling in the arm which was 
attibutated to mild edema because of lingering partial occlusion 
in the veins. Repeat US was negative at that time.
.
Recommend considering chelation therapy for treatment of iron 
overload. Monitor nutritional status and PO intake as well as GI 
symptoms of GVHD

Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital because of rising liver 
function tests and concern that you were experiencing GVHD 
(rejection symptoms). You had recently been admitted for nausea, 
vomiting, and diarrhea and had responded to immunosupressive. 
You were again admitted to help manage your symptoms by placing 
you on bowel rest, giving you IV forms of your medications and 
supporting you with IV nutrition. Your symptoms gradually 
improved and your diet was able to be slowly advanced. Your 
immunosupressive meds were also titrated to help prevent future 
flairs without oversuppresion of your immune system and bone 
marrow.
.

PATHOLOGY:
Muscle biopsy, r4 rectus femoris muscle:
Inflammatory myopathy, see note.
Note: Section showed myofibers with prominent inflammatory 
infiltrate composed of foamy macrophages, lymphocytes, and 
plasma cells.  Degenerative and regenerative fibers are seen.  
In some areas, myofibers are replaced by adipose and connective 
tissue, consistent with a subacute clinical picture. CD3 labeled 
prominent T cell infiltrate with numerous CB8 positive cytotoxic 
and scattered CD4 positive helper cells, while CD20 labeled B 
lymphocytes are rare in perivascular zones. CD68 highlighted 
abundant macrophages, some involved in myophagocytosis. The 
findings would be consistent with GVH myositis in the clinical 
context of CML status post alloSCT and history of GI and liver 
GVH disease. GVH myositis is indistinguishable histologically 
from sporatic polymyositis. Further studies including 
biochemical panel will be reported as an addendum.
.
R forearm: pending at time of discharge

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ female with CAD s/p CABG, accelerated phase CML s/p 
allo SCT ___ complicated by upper and lower GI GVHD ___ 
and liver GVHD ___ presenting from OSH electively intubated 
for hypoxic and hypercarbic failure in the setting of myopathy. 
.
# Hypercarbic hypoxic respiratory failure: Pt was initially 
electively intubated given diffuse myopathy affecting 
respiratory muscles. Pt was managed on endotracheal intubation 
for 11 days before being trached on ___. Her ___ NIF has 
remained (-14)-(-18). During trials on trach collar, she has 
maintained her oxygen saturation and respiratory rate, however 
her blood pressure elevates and she reports subjective feelings 
of dyspnea and fatigue. Goal now for weaning her from the vent 
is treatment of her diffuse myositis to improve respiratory 
failure in the long term with gentle weaning to trach collar.
.
# Motor weakness: Based on muscle biopsy, inflammation is 
consistent with GVHD.  Muscle biopsy shows impressive 
inflammation despite having been on steriods prior to biopsy. 
Muscle strength appeared to initially improve on steroids, 
though now has been stable x 1 week. Following muscle biopsy, 
she was started on cyclosporine 25mg IV BID and received 1 dose 
of IVIG. She has had minimal improvement in her strength and is 
aware that this will be a prolonged recovery process.
.
# Mold on BAL: Sparse growth seen on bronchial aspirate from 
___. Given clinical improvement and radiological improvement 
on CT scan ___, we do not feel that this is likely a pathogenic 
organism. We do recommend repeat CT chest in ___ weeks for 
continued monitoring. 
.
# depression: Ms ___ has started to appear overwhelmed and 
frustrated by her current condition and long term recovery that 
is necessary. We have deferred starting an SSRI but this should 
be reconsidered outside of an acute hospitalization.
.
# Pancytopenia: Developed in setting of starting cyclosporine. 
Her CBC has been stable and she has not required any recent 
transfusions. Threshold for transfusion would be platelets <10, 
hct <25
.
# bilateral hand bullae: First noticed on ___. Dermatology was 
consulted and felt that her purpura was due to trauma and her 
coagulopathy.  The bullae were probably the result of hemorrhage 
into thin skin. They were drained and per derm, continued with 
light pressure dressings to prevent re-accumulation.
.
# Hypertension: Pt has history of hypertension and had been 
managed at home on amlodipine 5mg, and metoprolol succinate 
300mg ___. These were initially held on presentation, but 
resumed as she improved clinically. She has been stable on 
amlodipine 5mg ___, metoprolol tartrate 100mg q6hr, and 
captopril 12.5mg TID. She has been noted to get hypertensive to 
170s when on trach collar. We would expect this to resolve as 
she becomes more comfortable on the trach collar and her 
strength improves. It would be possible to up titrate her 
captopril if she requires.
.
# DVT: Pt has bilateral DVT, however in setting of diffuse 
ecchymoses and hematomas, heparin drip was held. Pt had CTA at 
outside hospital to r/o PE and had an IVC filter placed.  She 
was placed on compression stockings to avoid further 
complications of thrombophlebitis.
.
# Elevated LFTs: LFT have been stably elevated during this 
hospitalization, likely secondary to her known GVHD.
.
# elevated PTT: Unclear etiology since patient has been off 
heparin drip for 1 week now. She is still getting heparin SQ TID 
and suspect that given decreased muscle mass, she may be 
supratheraputic from SQ heparin alone. Further work up is 
pending, including ___, anti-cardiolipin antibody, and 
anti-lupus antibody.
.
CHRONIC ISSUES:
.
# CML s/p allogeneic stem cell tx: Pt was continued on acyclovir 
and atovaquone for prophylaxis. She had been on budesonide, 
however this has been held recent as it cannot be given through 
her dobhoff. She has been started on cyclosporin and IVIG for 
diffuse myositis.
.
# CAD: s/p CABG in ___. Continued home medications. Repeat ECHO 
here showed no wall motion abnormalities. She also had cardiac 
catheterization at outside hospital for workup of initial 
presenting dyspnea which revealed clean coronary arteries.
.

Pt is full code.
.
She will require repeat IVIG either ___ or ___ per 
rheumatology recs.
.
She should have repeat CT chest in ___ weeks for follow up on

.
We have decreased her heparin SQ to BID given persistently

.
We have resumed home blood pressure medications. If necessary,

.
Patient and her husband are aware that she will have a prolonged

a pneumonia, though this looks like it has resolved on your most 
recent CT scan. Your feeding tube was left in place for you to 
get adequate nutrition until your muscle strength improves.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ year old woman with a history of 
accelerated CML s/p allo-MRD SCT ___ complicated by GVHD of 
the liver, gut, myositis necessitating intubation due to 
respiratory muscle weakness.  She presented with worsening 
blood-streaked diarrhea and elevated LFTs, with hospitalization 
complicated by multiple DVTs and resulting BRBPR caused by 
heparin gtt, with BRBPR, and recurrent C. diff infection.
.
#. DIARRHEA: ___ GVHD and recurrent C diff. Patient has been 
having blood-streaked diarrhea since admission likely secondary 
to GVHD, which progressed to BRBPR with clots after starting 
heparin gtt for DVTs (see below). Heparin was discontinued, but 
patient with continued diarrhea. On ___ C. diff toxin was 
found positive. Pt has had multiple episodes of C diff in past, 
and prophylactic PO vanco had been discontinued on ___. She 
was started on IV flagyl on ___ for her positive C diff), then 
switched to vanco 500mg PO q6hrs per GI recs (used for recurrent 
c diff: 250-500mg PO q6hrs x14 days, then taper). Diarrhea 
progressively improved after this. Patient also has chronic gut 
and liver GVHD. She had EGD and colonoscopy on ___, which 
showed 2 whitish cecal plaques/nodules with biopsy showing focal 
active ileitis, rare apoptotic crypt cells in 
ileum/ascending/transverse colon consistent with (but not 
specific for) GVHD. Also had ileocecal valve nodules composed of 
"predominantly fibrinopurulent exudate consistent with ulcer and 
a very minute strip of surface epithelium". EGD/colonoscopy 
biopsies were found negative for AFB, fungi, CMV, viruses. For 
her C diff, patient is discharged on Vancomycin 500mg PO q6 
hours for 14 days (first day = ___, last day = ___. After 
this, she should restart suppressive therapy: vancomycin 250mg 
q6 hours chronically. For her GVHD, she is discharged on 
prednisone 30mg by mouth daily, and cyclosporine 50mg by mouth 
twice daily. 
.
#. BRBPR: pt admitted with blood-streaked stools, found likely 
secondary to GVHD (confirmed by colonoscopy on ___. When 
heparin gtt was started for multiple ___ DVTs, patient developed 
frank BRBPR with clots. This resolved after discontinuing 
heparin gtt; patient guaiac negative afterward. She was started 
on enoxaparin 40mg BID for DVT prophylaxis with no ensuing 
complications.   
.
#. ELEVATED LFTs: Patient has known GVHD of the liver.  LFTs on 
admission showed elevated AST, ALT and Alk Phosph, found likely 
___s voriconazole, which she is taking for h/o 
paelomyces (___). Her cyclosporine was uptitrated from 25 
BID to 50mg qAM and 75mg qPM. When cyclosporine was decreased to 
50BID, her LFTs rose again (AST 59, ALT 72, Alk Phosph 178). 
**Cyclosporine was increased/decreased/not changed....***
.
#. GVHD: manifested as gut, liver, and muscle GVHD. During 
hospitalization her cyclosporine was increased from 25mg BID to 
50mg BID as it was felt that her diarrhea on presentation was 
from GVHD. Her prednisone was decreased to 30mg by mouth daily. 
Due to her muscle GVHD (diagnosed by rheumatology), patient is 
extremely weak in her ___ flexor muscles. She will continue 
physical therapy at rehab. She was also incidentally found to 
have diffuse airway narrowing consistent with possible early 
bronchiolitis obliterans on chest CT on ___, although no 
clinical signs/symptoms and currently appropriately treated with 
steroids and cyclosporine. 
.
# MULTIPLE ___ DVTs: patient had left ___ swelling during 
hospitalization. ___ on ___ showed multiple BLE DVTs 
involving common femoral, superficial femoral, popliteal and 
posterior tibial and peroneal veins on L>R. ___ swelling L>R. Pt 
started on heparin gtt overnight ___, with a goal PTT of 
60-80. She also has an IVC filter in place. Unfortunately, she 
then had BRBPR overnight with a supratherapeutic PTT (150).  The 
heparin gtt was held. She was started on enoxaparin 40mg BID for 
DVT prophylaxis, without further guaiac positive stools.  
.
# DYSPHAGIA, REDUCED VOCAL CORD MOBILITY: patient has h/o 
dysphagia secondary to muscle GVHD. She had repeat swallow study 
on ___ which showed no aspiration, also noted reduced right 
vocal cord mobility for which she should have outpatient ENT 
followup with Dr. ___ # ___. Swallow eval 
recs were soft solids, nectar thickened liquids, pills crushed 
in puree.
.
#. PAECILOMYCES ON BRONCHIOALVEOLAR LAVAGE: pt found to have 
paecilomyces growth on BAL on ___ (her last 
hospitalization) in Legionella bottle. She was discharged at 
that time on voriconazole with plan to follow up in 2 weeks. 
Voriconazole was continued throughout hospitalization. She will 
need outpatient ID follow-up in ___. 
___ with repeat chest CT prior to appointment, where it will be 
determined whether or not to continue Voriconazole. Beta glucan 
was rechecked and found to be 52 (down from 92 on ___.  
.
# CML s/p MRD AlloSCT: pt is s/p allogeneic SCT on ___. She 
is currently in remission, with no evidence of leukemia at this 
time. Her course has been complicated by GVHD. During 
hospitalization her acyclovir and atovaquone prophylaxis were 
continued. 
.
# MACROCYTIC ANEMIA: normal B12, folate, TSH. Likely anemia of 
chronic disease. B12 and folate supplementation were continued 
during hospitalization. 
.
# TRACHEOSTOMY: pt has h/o tracheostomy after intubation on last 
hospitalization due to respiratory muscle weakness from GVHD. 
Trach was decannulated on ___ by IP without incident. 
Patient was not dyspneic throughout hospitalization. 
.
# HYPERTENSION: home metoprolol and captopril were continued. 
Amlodipine was decreased from 10mg daily to 5mg daily.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old woman with a history of CML s/p allo stem cell 
transplant in ___ complicated by GVHD and pulmonary 
Paecilomyces infection who presented with several days of new 
cough found to be RSV positive.  
.
# Dyspnea - Patient presented with SOB which worsened despite 
treatment with azithromycin. CT chest showed evidence of 
multifocal pneumonia. She was initially started on levofloxacin 
and vancomycin. The infectious disease team was consulted. 
Respiratory viral screen returned positive for RSV. Patient was 
treated with Palivizumab. Antibiotics were discontinued. 
Respiratory symptoms improved. Patient was discharged with plans 
to treat cough and nasal congestion symptomatically and follow 
up with her hematologist/oncologist and infectious disease 
specialist as scheduled. 
.
# GVHD: continued Azathioprine, cyclosporine, prednisone. Her 
prednisone dose was increased to 40 mg during the week of 
admission. It was tapered down to 30 mg ___ at time of 
discharge. 
.
# History of Paecilomyces Pulmonary Infection: Patient's 
voriconazole was changed to posaconazole given concern that it 
may be contributing to elevated LFTs. 
.
# History of DVT: Patient on Coumadin. INR fluctuated likely in 
the setting of many medication changes. Patient was discharged 
with alternating doses of 5 mg and 2.5 mg ___. She has plans 
to have her INR checked on ___ at her PCP's office.  
.
# Hypertension: continued home dose Metoprolol, Captopril, and 
amlodipine
.
# History of Clostridium difficile colitis: continued oral 
Vancomycin at prophylactic dosing
.
# Infection Prophylaxis - Continued Bactrim and acyclovir
.

- no labs pending at time of discharge
- patient's INR will need close monitoring and Coumadin dose 
will likely need further adjustment 
- patient full code on this admission

Bone Marrow Bx 
HYPOCELLULAR BONE MARROW WITH TRILINEAGE HEMATOPOIESIS AND 
DECREASED MEGAKARYOCYTES.  NO MORPHOLOGIC EVIDENCE OF 
TRANSFORMATION OR HEMOPHAGOCYTIC SYNDROME ARE SEEN.  SEE NOTE.

Note: The findings overall suggest marrow suppression, perhaps 
related to TKIs, rather than hemophagocytic syndrome, i.e. there 
are only occasional hemophagocytic macrophages present, with 
hemosiderin-laden macrophages predominating, and no overt marrow 
"damage" seen. 

Colon Bx:
Random colon, mucosal biopsies:
Colonic mucosa with focal crypt atrophy and dropout with rare 
basal crypt epithelial cell apoptoses consistent with graft 
versus host disease in the appropriate clinical setting; no 
viral cytopathic effect seen; see note.
Note: Given rare neutrophilic crypt abscesses, a concomitant 
acute infectious process cannot entirely be excluded. 
Immunostain for cytomegalovirus is in progress and will be 
reported in an addendum.

controls.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is ___ with accelerated CML s/p allo transplant 
___ complicated by GVHD, pneumonia, myositis, and DVTs who 
initially presented with fatigue, diarrhea, pancytopenia in the 
setting of Cellcept and Ponatinib therapy.

# Diarrhea: Patient presented with 4 weeks of watery diarrhea 
with ___ bowel movements daily and poor appetite. Symptoms were 
most likely secondary to cellcept toxcity or ponatinib toxicity. 
Colon biopsy results were consisted with shallow crypts that are 
typically seen with GVHD or cellcept toxicity. While GVHD is a 
possible etiolgy, chronic GVHD is much less likely to present 
with acute diarrhea. An extensive infectious work up including 
norovirus, CMV, cdiff, adenovirus, parvovirus, HHV6, and O&P 
were negative. Ms. ___ improved with decreased cellcept 
dosing. She was transitioned from 1000mg BID to ___ BID at 
time of discharge. She continues to have ___ loose bowel 
movements daily. However, she continues to trend in a positive 
direction at the time of discharge. She did require 2 weeks of 
TPN but is now tolerating a PO diet at the time of discharge.

# Pancytopenia: Pt was noted to have progressive pancytopenia on 
outpatient labs over weeks preceeding admission. Pancytopenia is 
thought to be secondary to ponatinib toxicity as all cell lines 
improved after holding drug. Ms. ___ has experienced 
pancytopenia on previous TKI treatments as well. She was also 
transitioned from bactrim to atovaquone for PCP ___. A 
bone morrow biopsy was hypocellular but without concern for 
recurrent CML. A Graft chimerism study notable for 100% donor. 
Pt did also have HSV oral lesion and there may have been a 
component of HSV marrow suppression as her counts also improved 
with acyclovir therapy. Ponatinib is held at the time of 
discharge.

# Nephrotic syndrome:  The patient presented with acute on 
chronic CKD with creatinine around 2 this admission. Her 
creatinine has been gradually uptrending over the last year. It 
was never worked up and thought to be secondary to TKI therapy. 
She was found to have 4+ proteinuria this admission with low 
serum albumin and elevated triglycerides. A  renal biopsy was 
notable for acute on chronic microangiopathic disease, 
glomerular sclerosing and fibrosis of kidney. Etiology of 
changes remains unclear but differential is broad including 
effects of TKI treatment. There was no hydro or obtruction on 
renal us. Complement levels were normal and no serum 
cyroglobins. She was started on losartan 100mg daily and 
lisinopril 5mg for proteinuria. Pt was also started on aggresive 
IV diuresis for anasarca with improvement in fluid status. She 
will be discharged on 40mg PO Lasix with goal of maintaining 
within 2kg of her discharge weight, which was 143.6 lbs. 
Creatinine was stable around 2 at time of discharge. 

#Dyspnea: Patient promoted dyspnea during admission but never 
developed hypoxia. Symptoms were initially thought to be 
secondary to pulmonary edema and did improve with initial 
diuresis. However, symptoms did not completely resolve. A CT 
Chest was notable for some scattered ground glass opacities and 
a 4 mm right upper lobe nodule. PFTS show mixed obstructive and 
restrictive physiology. Fungal work up unrevealing. Pulmonology 
recommended a course of azithromycin for atypical pneumonia with 
follow up CT scan in 1 month. Dyspnea continued to improve at 
time of discharge following course of azithromycin. She was also 
started on pulmonary prophylaxis with FAM: daily fluticasone, 
azithromycin 3x/wk, monteleukast every other day.

#R lower extremity pain: Pt noted to have partial DVT of right 
superficial femoral vein which is unchanged from prev study in 
___ and most likely represents remnent from previous distal 
DVT which were treated with 6 months of anticoagulation. 
Vascular surg evaluated vascular appearing lesion on right lower 
extreity and are uncertain regarding etiology. ___ be secondary 
to smaller superficial thrombi in smaller leg veins. Recommend 
continued warm compresses, compression,and elevation of leg. 
Further anticoagulation at prophylactic dosing should be 
discussed as an outpatient once platlets are stable.

# Seizure like activity: Pt has 3 episodes of right neck 
twitching and mental status changes on ___ which appeared 
seizure like to staff. There was no tongue biting or generalized 
activity. An MRI Head was normal and LP without concern for 
bacterial infection. Viral cultures were all negative from CSF. 
An EEG was notable for encephalopathy without epileptical 
discharges. Pt experienced no further concerning neurologic 
changes following ___.

# HSV:Pt promoted oral pain on admission and was found to have 
several ulcerative lesions. An oral swab of lesions was positive 
for HSV. Symptoms and ulcers improved on acyclovir. She will 
continue prophylactic dosing as an outpatient.

#CML: Ms. ___ is status ___ allogenic transplant in ___ 
with recurrent disease in late ___. Disease has currently been 
well controlled on ponatinib with BCR-ABL PCR .09. However,has 
now been discontinued as drug toxicity outweighing benefits of 
treatment. As noted above, repeat bone marrow bx this admission 
without concern for recurrent disease. Chimerism study showed 
100% donor.

# GVHD: Has had GI  and skin involvement in past in addition to 
myositis. Has been well controlled on current MMF and prednisone 
dosing. While there was initial concern for GVHD as etiology to 
current presentation, it is uncommon to have diarrhea with 
chronic GVHD. Cellcept and prednisone doses were decreased this 
admission. She will need to closely monitor with recent decrease 
in immunosuppresion. 

#HTN: Ms. ___ had poorly controlled hypertension this 
admission. Most likely related to pregressive kidney disease. 
She was started on losartan, which was uptitrated to 100mg with 
good BP control by discharge.

#Hypogammablobulinemia: Likely ___ nephrotic syndrome and 
protein wasting. At admission, IgG level was 82 and she received 
an IVIg transfusion at 0.4g/kg. On ___, she received a second 
IVIg transfusion at the same dose for an IGg level of 300. 
During the second transfusion, she had some mild upper back pain 
and chills, which resolved with slowing the infusion.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ y/o F with hx of accelerated phase CML s/p sibling allo D0 
___ presenting with diarrhea x 4 days and nausea/decreased 
PO intake w/ weight loss over the past 1 month.  

# CML
CML s/p sibling allo D0 ___ complicated by GVHD.  No longer 
on TKI given multiple side effects.  Previous chimerism and 
BCR-ABL gene rearrangement study shows no residual disease 
however repeat test showed increased level of BCR-ABL gene.  
Here mycophenylate was stoooped to increase graft versus. 
leukemia effect.  We continued her current prednisone regiemtn 
15mg alternating with 20mg.  Her acyclovir and atovaquone were 
continued. 

# Nausea/Weight Loss
History of 1 month of worsening nausea and decreased PO intake 
correlated with 5 pound weight loss.  Concern for upper GI GVHD 
given decrease in steroids and nausea.  EGD and flex sig 
negative for signs of GVHD.  Her gastric empyting study was 
inconclusive.  Her symptoms improved with zyprexa and zofran.  
She was able to tolerate a diet at time of discharge and her 
symptoms were well-controlled.
 
# Sinus Congestion
Concern for sinus infection given symptoms and immunocompromised 
state.  CT sinus shows mucosal thickening w/o bone involvement.  
She was started on levofloxacin for a total of 14 days of 
treatment.  Her symptoms were imporved with afrin, flonase, and 
saline irrigation.  She will follow-up in ___ clinic in 1 month.

# Diarrhea
Presents with diarrhea x4 days and overnight had more non-bloody 
watery diearrhea.  Most likely secondary to viral or bacterial 
gastroenteritis.  However could be due to GVHD and recent 
decrease in prednisone dosing. Also could be medication side 
effects from mycophenylate.  On previous admission, had diarrhea 
and her mycophenylate dose was decreasd with improvement in his 
symptoms.  Her TKI was also disconinued during this admission.  
Diarrhea has been improving and flex sig was without signs of 
GVHD.  Stool studies were negative for infection.  On discharge 
her diarrhea had resolved.
 
# Non-Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis 
Elevated bicarb w/ hypercholemia most likely due to combination 
of chronic kidney diease, diarrhea, and NS fluids.  We started 
oral bicarb replacement and her serum bicarb level normalized at 
time of discharge.

# Acute on Chronic Renal Failure
Elevated Cr to 2.6 from baseline 1.9-2.3 likely pre-renal 
etiology secondary to diarrhea and poor PO intake.  Also could 
possibly be due to renal GVHD.  Improved with fluids to 1.8.

# HTN
Her lasix, losartan, metoprolol, and amlodipine were continued.

# CAD
We continued here ASA 81.

Brief Hospital Course:
BRIEF HOSPITAL COURSE:  

Ms. ___ is a ___ y/o F with history of accelerated phase CML 
s/p sibling allo transplant on ___ complicated by upper and 
lower GI GVHD ___, liver GVHD in setting of reducing 
immunosuppression ___, GVHD related myopathy resulting in 
weakness and respiratory failure ___ who presented for 
presyncope. Her lightheadedness improved significantly with IV 
fluids and she had no further episodes of presyncope. She had 
elevated creatinine above baseline that resolved with IV fluids. 
She was found to have an elevated troponin that trended down 
thought to be likely due to demand ischemia in the setting of 
anemia in addition to poor clearance in the setting of acute on 
chronic kidney injury. Her BCR-ABL load was elevated compared to 
prior levels and her prednisone immunosuppression was decreased 
to improve control of her CML. She was also found to have an 
elevated EBV viral load with concern for PTLD/lymphoma and had a 
CT Torso which showed no evidence of PTLD. She received 1 dose 
of rituximab on ___ and tolerated well.

On reduction of the pt.'s prednisone, she developed severe 
myalgias and respiratory distress thought to be ___ muscle 
weakness, hypervolemia, and flash pulmonary edema with BPs in 
220s/110s. She was transferred to the ICU, required intubation, 
and was diuresed.  She was extubated and her respiratory status 
returned to baseline. She was found to have both a new 
consolidation on CXR evaluated by both the pulmonary service and 
infectious disease service who both recommended a course of 
antibiosis for HCAP. She also had an elevated troponin during 
this episode. Cardiology evaluated pt and determined her to have 
an NSTEMI in the setting of elevated troponin and new focal wall 
motion abnormality on echocardiogram. She continued to have 
myalgias and had a muscle biopsy and EMG to better assess the 
cause of her myalgias. ___ results indicate no signs of 
active GVHD or GVHD myasthenia ___. Final results are 
pending. She remained hemodynamically stable and was discharged 
to rehab on her admission dose of prednisone.
 
ACTIVE ISSUES

# Acute Myalgias and Muscle Weakness:  On admission, pt. reports 
diffuse muscle weakness and myalgias.  Following reduction of 
prednisone from alternating 15mg/20mg daily, pt. had significant 
worsening of symptoms.  CK was mildly elevated.  For concern of 
worsening symptoms ___ to ongoing levofloxacin (has been 
associated with increased risk of tenosynovitis in pt.'s on 
chronic steroids), this medication was discontinued.  An EMG was 
done showing no evidence of GVHD induced myasthenia ___.  
___ muscle biopsy performed on ___ of the left biceps 
femoris biopsy returned negative for any evidence of 
inflammation.  The most likely etiology of the patient's 
symptoms were thought to be ___ profound deconditioning with a 
possible component of steroid induced myopathic fibroatrophy 
given ongoing steroids over the last ___ years.  GVHD less likely 
given no evidence of myositis on ___ path, although pt.'s 
physical exam is somewhat consistent with chronic GVHD. 

# Respiratory Failure:  Following reduction of patient's 
steroids, pt. developed profound muscle weakness.  In this 
setting, she became hypoxic and later hypertensive with BPs in 
220s/110s.  She had a presumed episode of flash pulmonary edema 
which resulted in her transfer to the ICU and subsequent 
intubation.  Pt. was diuresed significantly and extubated 
without issue.  She was thought to be volume overloaded 
secondary to initial resuscitation following her pre-syncopal 
presentation.  Pt. continued to respond well to diuresis and was 
transferred back to the medical floor.

# Hospital Acquired Pneumonia:  Pt. had a new consolidation on 
CXR on this admission.  Started on HCAP coverage with 
vanc/meropenem.  The patient initially responded well and was 
d/c'ed off vanc.  Given concern for worsening pneumonia and 
respiratory distress, pulmonary was consulted for possible 
bronchoscopy.  ___ then recommended cardiology evaluation given 
ongoing elevated troponin and question of ischemic changes seen 
on TTE and EKG.  ID also saw pt. and recommended continuation of 
levofloxacin for total of 5 day course for atypical coverage and 
meropenem for total of 8 day course.  For concern that 
levofloxacin was contributing to pt.'s myalgias/ tendonitis, pt. 
was discontinued 1 day earlier than completion of full course.  
At time of discharge, pt. had ongoing improving cough.  She had 
a repeat CXR (___) negative for consolidation or pulmonary 
edema.  

# NSTEMI:  In the setting of episode of flash pulmonary edema, 
pt. had an elevated troponin.  Cardiology evaluated the patient 
who recommended a repeat TTE which revealed showed decrease in 
EF to 40% and akinesis of the anteroseptal wall.  Given her 
known CAD, this was thought to most likely be related to either 
a type 1 primary coronary event or type 2 demand ischemia in the 
setting of recent hypertensive emergency and flash pulmonary 
edema.  Given that pt. was a poor cath candidate with ongoing 
acute on chronic kidney injury, will proceed with medical 
optimization at this time.  As such, pt. was discharged on ASA 
81mg Daily, metoprolol and amlodipine for afterload reduction.  
A statin was held at this time given ongoing myalgias.  Her 
losartan was held for resolving acute on chronic kidney injury.  


# Admission Troponin elevation:  Pt. had admission Troponin peak 
at 1.07, CK-MB 11. Patient did not have chest pain at this time, 
but did report dizziness and dyspnea which may be her anginal 
equivalent. ECG on admission was not suggestive of ischemia.  
Pt. evaluated for ACS but noted to have downtrending trops in 
setting of resolving anemia and resolving acute on chronic 
kidney injury.  Initial TTE showed hyperdynamic function 
consistent with her volume depleted status.  In the setting of 
known CAD, pt. also had a persantine stress MIBI which was 
negative for evidence of malperfusion/ischemia.  Likely cause of 
admission troponin elevation was thought to be due to demand 
ischemia in the setting of anemia in addition to poor clearance 
in the setting of acute on chronic kidney injury.  

# Poor appetite:  Patient not taking good PO at home. Signs of 
anasarca on exam with diffuse dependent edema.  Pt. states that 
she is eating more on this hospitalization compared to any other 
time recently.  Denies nausea/vomiting, abdominal symptoms, 
diarrhea.  Pt. was started on marinol for appetite stimulation 
but developed excess sedation.  This medication was 
discontinued. 

# Anemia:  On admission, pt. found to have Hct drop from 27 to 
19.  She received fluids in clinic of unknown quantity.  No 
history of bleeding.  Anemia work-up was negative for hemolysis 
with normal TSH level.  Pt. did have a retic count which was low 
given the level of anemia consistent with decreased production 
likely ___ pt's CML.  Her Hct remained stable after initial 
transfusion throughout the remainder of admission.

# Presyncope/lightheadedness:  Pt. presented with orthostatic 
hypotension in the setting of poor PO intake and ongoing 
antihypertensive/diuretic therapy making hypovolemia the most 
likely etiology. Given troponin elevation, considered cardiac 
etiology however stress MIBI negative.  Her lightheadedness 
resolved after giving IV fluids.  Her home furosemide and 
amlodipine were discontinued.  The patient was discharged on a 
reduced hypertensive regimen as described in transitional 
issues. 

# Acute on chronic kidney injury:  On admission, pt. was found 
to have creatinine elevated to 2.6 from baseline of 1.5 to 2.0.  
Likely pre-renal given hypovolemia with orthostasis.  She 
received IV fluids and her creatinine returned to baseline.  Pt. 
then had second episode of acute on chronic kidney injury ___ 
poor forward flow in the setting of flash pulmonary edema and 
NSTEMI.  Her renal function returned to baseline with diuresis.  
She was noted to have an elevated uric acid at this time which 
dramatically decreased following one dose of rasburicase. 

# CML
Accelerated phase CML s/p sibling allo D0 ___ now relapsed 
CML.  BCR-ABL returned slightly elevated compared to prior.  We 
continued prophylaxis on home acyclovir, atovaquone, fluconazole 
at renal dosing.  Her prednisone was attempted to be reduced to 
15mg daily to improve control of CML with evidence of increasing 
BCR-ABL.  The pt. did not tolerate this as above.  She has a 
repeat BCR ABL and kinase domain mutation pending.  TKI should 
be considered as an outpatient.

# Elevated EBV Viral Load
EBV was elevated on last admission and more elevated on this 
admission.  HHV6/Parvo B19 negative.  For concern of 
PTLD/lymphoma, pt. was evaluated with CT Torso which showed no 
evidence of PTLD.  Pt. given 1 dose of rituximab on ___ and 
tolerated it well.  

# Sinusitis 
Pt. received course of levofloxacin with resolution of symptoms.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

It was a pleasure taking care of you at the ___ 
___.  You were admitted to the hospital 
because you felt as though you were going to faint and were not 
eating or drinking well.  You received fluids through your IV 
and your lightheadedness improved.  You also had worsening 
kidney function likely due initially to poor oral intake and 
later to heart dysfunction.  Your heart enzymes were found to be 
elevated both on admission and during your hospitalization.  The 
ultrasound of your heart initially was normal as well as a 
stress test.  A repeat ultrasound did show some wall damage 
indicating that you most likely had a small heart attack.  
Additionally, your EBV virus level was high.  You received one 
dose of rituximab to treat the EBV virus.

You prednisone dose was decreased to help improve control of 
your CML.  However, you developed worsening muscle pain and 
required help breathing with an airway tube in the Intensive 
Care Unit.  We removed excess fluid which improved your 
breathing.  You were also found to have a pneumonia at this time 
which was treated with antibiotics.  We obtained a muscle biopsy 
and an EMG to better assess your muscle pain.  These tests are 
currently pending.  Your condition improved and you were 
discharged with close follow-up.

All the best,

Your ___ Team

IMPRESSION:

femoral vein, 
unchanged since ___.

REASON FOR EXAMINATION:  Evaluation of the patient with CML 
transformation into AML and blast crisis with persistent cough. 
Portable AP radiograph of the chest was reviewed in comparison 
to ___. 
The right central venous line tip is at the cavoatrial 
junction/proximal right atrium.  Heart size and mediastinum are 
stable.  There is new left 
retrocardiac opacity, not seen on the prior study, concerning 
for left lower lobe pneumonia associated with small amount of 
pleural effusion.  No pneumothorax is seen. 

___ TTE
The left atrium is mildly dilated. There is mild symmetric left 
ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity size. There is mild 
to moderate regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with 
near-akinesis of the septum, and hypokinesis of the basal-mid 
anterior wall. No masses or thrombi are seen in the left 
ventricle. There is no ventricular septal defect. Right 
ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The 
aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened. The mitral valve 
leaflets are mildly thickened. Mild (1+) mitral regurgitation is 
seen. The tricuspid valve leaflets are mildly thickened. The 
estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure is normal. There is 
no pericardial effusion. There is an anterior space which most 
likely represents a prominent fat pad. 

IMPRESSION: Regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction 
consistent with LAD ischemia/infarction. Mild mitral 
regurgitation. 

Compared with the prior study (images reviewed) of ___ and 
___, the function of the septum and anterior wall are 
similar (septal function was described as mildly hypokinetic on 
the most recent study but it was severely hypokinetic then 
also). The function of the mid to distal inferior wall has 
improved. Mild mitral regurgitation is seen.  

PATHOLOGY:
___ IMMUNOPHENOTYPING
Increased number of blasts. In a context of patient's known CML, 
this is concerning for acute blast crisis.  Correlation with 
clinical findings and morphology (see separate report 
___ is recommended.  Flow cytometry immunophenotyping 
may not detect all abnormal populations due to topography, 
sampling or artifacts of sample preparation

___ Bone marrow bx
 Chronic Myelogeneous leukemia - Blast phase (CML-BP), see note.
Note: This represents acute myelegenous transformation of the 
patient's
previously diagnosed CML; ie., CML-BP. CD34 and CD117 are 
increased and
highlight blasts occupying estimated 70-80% of the overall 
cellularity.
 CD20 highlights rare B cells.  CD3 stains interstitial T 
lymphocytes.
CD42 is present in the megakaryocytes, which do not appear 
increased.
TdT is negative.  MP0 is not expressed in blasts.  Glycophorin
highlights erythroid precursors, but is negative in the blasts.

___ Skin bx
PATHOLOGIC DIAGNOSIS:

Skin, left mid back; punch biopsy:

 - Mild spongiosis with dyskeratosis, patchy interface 
inflammation and
focal intra-epidermal eosinophils,  with superficial 
perivascular
mononuclear cell infiltrate and dermal eosinophils (see 
comment).
 - No fungal organisms identified on a PAS stain.
 - Multiple tissue levels examined.

Comment:  The histologic differential diagnosis includes both a
hypersensitivity reaction and graft versus host disease. The 
presence
of eosinophils is compatible with the clinical suspicion of a 
drug
eruption, although they do not exclude graft versus host 
disease.
Clinical correlation is recommended.

 

 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ with CML s/p sibling allo D0 ___, complicated by chronic 
GVHD with gut, liver, muscle involvement presenting from ___ 
clinic with hyperkalemia, hyperuricemia, hypercalcemia, ___ on 
CKD and pancytopenia, now with conversion to AML.
 
#CML/AML: BCR/ABL trended up from 0 to 2 to 5 to 104 to 162. 
Presented with hyperuricemia and pancytopenia likely due to 
conversion to AML and rapid cell turn over. No evidence of 
bleeding. Hemolysis unlikely with normal coag studies and Tbili. 
 Retic count 1.8 with retic index 0.88% showed poor red cell 
production. CMV/EBV/HHV6 negative. BM bx shows conversion to AML 
with as much as 65% blasts on smear with absolute blast count as 
high as 1200 and 0% neutrophils. Treated with 12 days of 
nilotinib with no improvement. Given continued decline and poor 
prognosis, transitioned to comfort measures only after which she 
expired. 

#Cough/HCAP: Patient had intermittently productive cough for ___ 
weeks with negative workup on last admission including CXR, CT 
Chest, V/Q scan, rapid resp viral panel. Clear lung exam, 
negative CXR at rehab prior to admission. RRV panel and cx, 
beta-glucan, galactomannan negative. BNP >40K so volume overload 
potentially played a partial role especially given LVEF 40-45% 
on TTE. PE unlikely as patient not hypoxic, no evidence of right 
heart strain on EKG, no evidence of infarct on CT Chest; 
regardless, anticoagulation held in setting of thrombocytopenia 
and no hemodynamic compromise. CT showed ?infectious process, in 
the setting of worsening cough/resp status portable CXR showed 
likely LLL PNA. On ___ patient met ___ SIRS criteria 
(tachycardic, tachypneic, low WBC) so cx drawn and started on 
empiric vanc/meropenem. Received benzonatate, codeine, 
guaifenesin-dextromethorphan as well as levalbuterol/ipratropium 
nebs prn for symptomatic relief. With continued worsening 
respiratory status patient started on morphine for SOB O2 
supplementation prn. Given prognosis, she was transitioned to 
comfort measures only with withdrawal of abx, scopalamine patch, 
and morphine gtt, on which she expired. 

#Hypercalcemia: Baseline high 8s-9s, on admission 10.7. Unclear 
etiology, given elevated alk phos in the setting of CKD could 
have increased bony release of calcium though increased bone 
turnover would likely cause a higher phosphate level. PTH 6 
which rules out hyperparathyroidism and makes hypercalcemia in 
the setting of worsening CML more likely especially with Vit D 
wnl but PTHrP elevated. Received IVF, furosemide, ___ dose 
pamidronate ___ and calcitonin ___ while calcium 
carbonate/Vit D held and calcium downtrended to 8.4.

#UTI: Found to have citrobacter/klebsiella UTI on culture taken 
after patient began to appear septic with ___ SIRS signs. 
Infection was covered by meropenem rx'ed for putative PNA. Foley 
catheter was left in place for comfort and abx discontinued when 
patient transitioned to comfort measures only. 

#CHF: Patient has known CHF likely of ischemic nature given CAD, 
found to have persistent LVEF 40-45% on TTE ___. Increased 
volume with IVF for hypercalcemia tx led to increasing dyspnea 
treated with oxygen supplementation, which improved after 
diuresis and PNA tx as above. At this point, IVF held as calcium 
dropped and for comfort reasons. 
 
#DVT in LLE: Left superficial femoral vein DVT found on last 
admission, discharged on SQ heparin for tx. Previously presented 
with acute worsening of LLE edema but now reduced compared to 
prior admission. LLE U/S shows unchanged partially occlusive 
clot of proximal superficial femoral vein. Anticoagulation held 
given thrombocytopenia, IVC filter placement held given 
stability of clot and goals of care. 

#Hyperuricemia: Uric acid on presentation 9.5. Pt treated on 
last admission with rasburicase and started on allopurinol and 
febuxostat. Discharged with uric acid 8.7. Febuxostat held on 
this admission due to drug rash. Elevated uric acid possibly due 
to worsening renal function in the setting of hypovolemia but 
given rising BCR-ABL and known CML->AML progression likely due 
to rapid cell turnover. Elevated uric acid unlikely to be 
contributing to poor kidney function given no urate crystals on 
urine sediment. Treated with rasburicase x1, uric acid dropped 
to but rose to 9.6 over several days. Allopurinol discontinued 
after patient transitioned to comfort measures only. 

#CKD: Baseline Cr 1.5-2.0 due to thrombotic microangiopathic 
injury with severe interstitial fibrosis and tubular atrophy 
possibly related to TKI shown on renal biopsy ___. Cr 2.2 on 
last discharge, presented with Cr 2.9. Most likely prerenal in 
the setting of poor po intake and hypovolemia; elevated uric 
acid unlikely to be causing renal damage after improvement with 
fluids and no urate crystals. Cr worsened to 2.5 after several 
doses of IV lasix. Urine output decreased ___. Further 
diuresis held, no further IVF or intervention to improve kidney 
function after transition to comfort care only. 

#GVHD: Known skin, gut, liver, muscle involvement. Aldolase 
mildly elevated consistent with known muscle disease but 
improved from ___. Rash likely drug related over acute GVHD 
per derm bx. Continued on prednisone 10mg then transitioned to 
4mg IV solumedrol BID given inability to tolerate PO prior to 
discontinuation of steroids given goals of care. 

#CAD s/p CABG: History of ?NSTEMI in past, ___ TTE with 
preserved EF 55%. ASA held due to thrombocytopenia. 

#Nutrition: Patient's weight has fallen from 141 to 127 lbs 
since ___, likely ___ poor PO intake. Copper level wnl, 
B6 low. Supplemented with ensure while taking PO prior to 
transition to comfort care.  

#Hypertension: 
-Stable on metoprolol and amlodipine until transition to comfort 
care at which point both rx dc'ed. 

Patient sadly died overnight ___ with her family 
present after comfort care for about 3 days.

was extubated, taken to the PACU until stable, then transferred 
to the ward for observation.

which was advanced to Roxicet

standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored.

standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. Good pulmonary 
toilet, early ambulation and incentive spirometry were 
encouraged throughout hospitalization. 
GI/GU/FEN: She was initially NPO, but after successfully 
demonstrating no constriction, and no leak on an UGI, she was 
advanced to a bariatric stage 1 diet, which was advanced 
sequentially to stage 3, and well tolerated. Patient's intake 
and output were closely monitored.

infection, of which there were none.

dyne boots were used during this stay; she was encouraged to get 
up and ambulate as early as possible.
 
At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
with stable vital signs.  The patient was tolerating a stage 3 
diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.  The patient received discharge teaching and 
follow-up instructions with understanding verbalized and 
agreement with the discharge plan.

Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Band Prolapse
 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
 
Discharge Instructions:
Your band was removed, but that does not mean you have to 
abandon your efforts to improve your health.  Take this 
opportunity and incorporate what you have learned from your 
health care team.  Continue being active on a regular basis and 
follow these healthful guidelines (not diet!) for life long 
benefits.

In the hospital, you will be on a stage 3 diet for healing.  
This diet includes all liquid, high protein, low sugar and low 
fat supplements.  When you are discharged home, you may advance 
your diet as tolerated.  Below are some helpful tips to continue 


your journey of eating well and healthy living.

 

1.Keep an eye on calories.

2.Always eat at a table.  Avoid eating while driving, standing, 


sitting on the sofa, or lying in bed.  

3.Eat slowly.  Continue to take 30 minutes to eat a meal and 
chew your foods thoroughly. 

4.Surround yourself with healthy foods. Clean out your cabinets 


of any trigger or unsafe foods.

5.Keep a food journal or track your intake on-line.  Record 
what you eat, portion sizes, and the time you eat.  You may want 


to include your mood and hunger level, as well.

6.Avoid skipping meals.  Always eat at regular times to avoid 
overeating later in the day.

7.Listen to your body.  Eat when you are physically hungry and 
stop when you are full.

8.Be active.  Engage in at least ___ minutes of physical 
activity most (if not all) days of the week. 

9.Regularly check your weight.  Give yourself an acceptable 
range (i.e. 5 pounds).  This prevents slip ups from becoming 
bigger problems down the road.

10. Make small changes.  Set small, reasonable goals to keep on 


track. 

11. Reward yourself.  Treat yourself when you reach goals with 
a non-food treat (i.e. pedicure, movie). 

12. Ask for support. Call the ___ nutrition clinic for 
follow-up at ___. Join Weight Watchers, talk to friends 


and family or contact a local dietitian. 

13. Drink plenty of fluids. Stay hydrated.

Fluids & Diet
Fluid intake is extremely important the first month of your 
recovery. You must also take in enough liquids
to prevent dehydration. Dehydration can cause nausea, fatigue, 
lightheadedness and dark urine.  We recommend you track what you 


drink and eat each day. 
Most Frequent Problems

Discomfort
Abdominal soreness below your ribs on the left side is the most 
common site of tenderness after waking up. Despite this 
discomfort, it is very important that you get out of bed and 
take short walks.

Dehydration
Your most important job after surgery is drinking enough fluid. 
Dehydration is the most common reason to return to the hospital 
after surgery. Your goal is to drink 8 cups (64 oz) of fluid a 
day. You may not be able to drink this much fluid at first, but 
come as close as you can. Refer to your nutrition
packet for more details.

Wound Drainage & Infection
It is important to care for your incisions to prevent infection. 


You will have small fiber tapes on your wounds. This should keep 


your wound dry and closed. Leave them on until they fall off by 
themselves. Do not put band aids, ointments, lotions or powder 
on your incisions. You may get your incisions wet but
avoid scrubbing them. Pat them dry. It is not unusual for an 
incision to drain a little bloody fluid after you
go home. If you have some drainage, dab the wounds with diluted 
hydrogen peroxide (hydrogen
peroxide mixed half and half with water) and then cover with a 
dry gauze. Doing this twice a day will
speed your recovery.
Infections are uncommon and rarely serious after a laparoscopic 
operation. An infection will be red, warm,
firm, and tender. The infected fluid will look more like pus 
than like blood. If you notice this please call the
nurse at the Bariatric ___ Program to discuss your symptoms

isolated apbs, frequent, polymorphic vpbs, and several 
ventricular 
couplets throughout the study. Baseline systolic hypertension 
with an 
initial drop in systolic blood pressure during exercise. 
Appropriate increase in blood pressure response to exercise as 
it 
continued but the overall response was blunted. Blunted heart 
rate 
response to exercise in the presence of beta blocker therapy.

symptoms with 
uninterpretable ECG changes to achieved low workload. Resting 
systolic hypertension with abnormal blood pressure and blunted 
heart 
rate response to exercise. Echo report sent separately.
